   <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">
    Ghana
   </h1>
   <div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">
    <div class="noprint" id="siteSub">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div>
    <div id="contentSub">
    </div>
    <div class="mw-jump" id="jump-to-nav">
     Jump to:
     <a href="#mw-head">
      navigation
     </a>
     ,
     <a href="#p-search">
      search
     </a>
    </div>
    <div class="mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       This article is about the modern country of Ghana. For the Ghana Empire (
       <abbr title="circa">
        c.
       </abbr>
       300 – c. 1200) northwest of modern Ghana, see
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Empire" title="Ghana Empire">
        Ghana Empire
       </a>
       . For other uses, see
       <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Ghana_(disambiguation)" title="Ghana (disambiguation)">
        Ghana (disambiguation)
       </a>
       .
      </div>
      <p>

             Gonja
            </a>
            <small>
             (0.3
             <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Million" title="Million">
              mln
             </a>
             )
            </small>
           </li>
           <li>
            2.5%
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gurunsi" title="Gurunsi">
             Gurunsi
            </a>
            <small>
             (0.1
             <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Million" title="Million">
              mln
             </a>
             )
            </small>
           </li>
           <li>
            1.1%
            <a href="/wiki/Bissa_people" title="Bissa people">
             Bissa
            </a>
            /
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mande_peoples" title="Mande peoples">
             Mande
            </a>
            <small>
             (0.1
             <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Million" title="Million">
              mln
             </a>
             )
            </small>
           </li>
           <li>
            1.6% Other
            <small>
             (0.1
             <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Million" title="Million">
              mln
             </a>
             )
            </small>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>

          .gh
         </a>

      <p>
       <b>
        Ghana
       </b>
       (
       <span class="nowrap">
        <span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt">
         <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">
          /
          <span style="border-bottom:1px dotted">
           <span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">
            ˈ
           </span>
           <span title="/ɡ/: 'g' in 'guy'">
            ɡ
           </span>
           <span title="/ɑː/: 'a' in 'father'">
            ɑː
           </span>
           <span title="'n' in 'nigh'">
            n
           </span>
           <span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">
            ə
           </span>
          </span>
          /
         </a>
        </span>
        <small class="nowrap">
         (
         <span class="unicode haudio">
          <span class="fn">
           <span style="white-space:nowrap">
            <a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Ghana.ogg" title="About this sound">
             <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
            </a>
           </span>
           <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e4/En-us-Ghana.ogg" title="En-us-Ghana.ogg">
            listen
           </a>
          </span>
         </span>
         )
        </small>
       </span>
       ), officially the
       <b>
        Republic of Ghana
       </b>
       , is a
       <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">
        unitary
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Presidential_system" title="Presidential system">
        presidential
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constitutional_democracy" title="Constitutional democracy">
        constitutional democracy
       </a>
       , located along the
       <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Guinea" title="Gulf of Guinea">
        Gulf of Guinea
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">
        Atlantic Ocean
       </a>
       , in the
       <a href="/wiki/Subregion" title="Subregion">
        subregion
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/West_Africa" title="West Africa">
        West Africa
       </a>
       . Spanning a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Land_mass" title="Land mass">
        land mass
       </a>
       of 238,535 km², Ghana is bordered by the
       <a href="/wiki/Ivory_Coast" title="Ivory Coast">
        Ivory Coast
       </a>
       in the west,
       <a href="/wiki/Burkina_Faso" title="Burkina Faso">
        Burkina Faso
       </a>
       in the north,
       <a href="/wiki/Togo" title="Togo">
        Togo
       </a>
       in the east and the
       <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Guinea" title="Gulf of Guinea">
        Gulf of Guinea
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">
        Atlantic Ocean
       </a>
       in the south.
       <i>
        Ghana
       </i>
       means "Warrior King" in the
       <a href="/wiki/Soninke_language" title="Soninke language">
        Soninke language
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-warriorking_10-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-warriorking-10">
         [10]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The first permanent state in the territory of present-day Ghana dates back to the 11th century. Numerous kingdoms and empires emerged over the centuries, of which the most powerful was the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ashanti" title="Kingdom of Ashanti">
        Kingdom of Ashanti
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11">
        <a href="#cite_note-11">
         [11]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Beginning in the 15th century, numerous European powers contested the area for trading rights, with the British ultimately establishing control of the coast by the late 19th century. Following over a century of native resistance, Ghana's current borders were established by the 1900s as the
       <a href="/wiki/Gold_Coast_(British_colony)" title="Gold Coast (British colony)">
        British Gold Coast
       </a>
       . It became independent of the United Kingdom on 6 March 1957.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Universal_Newsreel_12-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Universal_Newsreel-12">
         [12]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-First_For_Sub-Saharan_Africa_13-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-First_For_Sub-Saharan_Africa-13">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Exploring_Africa_–_Decolinization_14-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Exploring_Africa_–_Decolinization-14">
         [14]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       A multicultural nation, Ghana has a population of approximately 27 million, spanning a variety of ethnic, linguistic and religious groups.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-popest_5-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-popest-5">
         [5]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Five percent of the population practices traditional faiths, 71.2% adhere to Christianity and 23.6% are Muslim. Its diverse geography and ecology ranges from coastal savannahs to tropical jungles.
      </p>
      <p>
       Ghana is a democratic country led by a president who is both
       <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">
        head of state
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Head_of_the_government" title="Head of the government">
        head of the government
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana:_CIA_World_FactBook_15-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana:_CIA_World_FactBook-15">
         [15]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ghana's growing economic prosperity and democratic political system have made it a
       <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">
        regional power
       </a>
       in West Africa.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-South_America_and_West_Africa_16-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-South_America_and_West_Africa-16">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">
        Non-Aligned Movement
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/African_Union" title="African Union">
        African Union
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Economic_Community_of_West_African_States" title="Economic Community of West African States">
        Economic Community of West African States
       </a>
       (ECOWAS),
       <a href="/wiki/Group_of_24" title="Group of 24">
        Group of 24
       </a>
       (G24) and the
       <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">
        Commonwealth of Nations
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17">
        <a href="#cite_note-17">
         [17]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
      </p>
      <div class="toc" id="toc">
       <div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en">

        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2">
         <a href="#History">
          <span class="tocnumber">

          </span>
          <span class="toctext">
           History
          </span>
         </a>
         <ul>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3">
           <a href="#Medieval_kingdoms">
            <span class="tocnumber">

            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Medieval kingdoms
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4">
           <a href="#European_contact_(15th_century)">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             2.2
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             European contact (15th century)
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5">
           <a href="#Transition_to_independence">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             2.3
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Transition to independence
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-6">
           <a href="#Operation_Cold_Chop_and_aftermath">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             2.4
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Operation Cold Chop and aftermath
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>

      <p>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">
        Etymology
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Etymology">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Etymology" title="Etymology">
        etymology
       </a>
       of the word
       <i>
        Ghana
       </i>
       means "
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Warriors" title="Warriors">
        warrior
       </a>
       king" and was the title accorded to the kings of the medieval
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Empire" title="Ghana Empire">
        Ghana Empire
       </a>
       in West Africa, but the empire was further north than the modern country of Ghana in
       <a href="/wiki/Guinea_(region)" title="Guinea (region)">
        the region of Guinea
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-etymology_18-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-etymology-18">
         [18]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
        History
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: History">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Ghana" title="History of Ghana">
        History of Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Medieval_kingdoms">
        Medieval kingdoms
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Medieval kingdoms">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ashanti" title="Kingdom of Ashanti">
        Kingdom of Ashanti
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Dagbon" title="Kingdom of Dagbon">
        Kingdom of Dagbon
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Akan_face.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1024" data-file-width="681" height="256" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Akan_face.jpg/170px-Akan_face.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Akan_face.jpg/255px-Akan_face.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Akan_face.jpg/340px-Akan_face.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Akan_face.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         16th – 17th century
         <a href="/wiki/Akan_people" title="Akan people">
          Akan
         </a>
         Terracotta,
         <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art" title="Metropolitan Museum of Art">
          Metropolitan Museum of Art
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Ghana was already recognized as one of the great kingdoms in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bilad_el-Sudan" title="Bilad el-Sudan">
        Bilad el-Sudan
       </a>
       by the ninth century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
        <a href="#cite_note-19">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <br/>
       Ghana was inhabited in the
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">
        Middle Ages
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Discovery" title="Age of Discovery">
        Age of Discovery
       </a>
       by a number of ancient predominantly
       <a href="/wiki/Akan_people" title="Akan people">
        Akan
       </a>
       kingdoms in the Southern and Central territories. This included the
       <a href="/wiki/Ashanti_Empire" title="Ashanti Empire">
        Ashanti Empire
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Akwamu" title="Akwamu">
        Akwamu
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bonoman" title="Bonoman">
        Bonoman
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Denkyira" title="Denkyira">
        Denkyira
       </a>
       , and the
       <a href="/wiki/Mankessim_Kingdom" title="Mankessim Kingdom">
        Mankessim Kingdom
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
        <a href="#cite_note-20">
         [20]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Although the area of present-day Ghana in West Africa has experienced many population movements, the
       <a href="/wiki/Akan_people" title="Akan people">
        Akans
       </a>
       were firmly settled by the 5th century BC.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-col_21-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-col-21">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
        <a href="#cite_note-22">
         [22]
        </a>
       </sup>
       By the early 11th century, the Akans were firmly established in the Akan state called
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bonoman" title="Bonoman">
        Bonoman
       </a>
       , for which the
       <a href="/wiki/Brong-Ahafo_Region" title="Brong-Ahafo Region">
        Brong-Ahafo Region
       </a>
       is named.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-col_21-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-col-21">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
        <a href="#cite_note-23">
         [23]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       From the 13th century, Akans emerged from what is believed to have been the Bonoman area, to create several Akan states of Ghana, mainly based on gold trading.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
        <a href="#cite_note-24">
         [24]
        </a>
       </sup>
       These states included Bonoman (
       <a href="/wiki/Brong-Ahafo_Region" title="Brong-Ahafo Region">
        Brong-Ahafo Region
       </a>
       ), Ashanti (
       <a href="/wiki/Ashanti_Region" title="Ashanti Region">
        Ashanti Region
       </a>
       ),
       <a href="/wiki/Denkyira" title="Denkyira">
        Denkyira
       </a>
       (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Region,_Ghana" title="Central Region, Ghana">
        Central region
       </a>
       ),
       <a href="/wiki/Mankessim_Kingdom" title="Mankessim Kingdom">
        Mankessim Kingdom
       </a>
       (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Region,_Ghana" title="Western Region, Ghana">
        Western region
       </a>
       ), and
       <a href="/wiki/Akwamu" title="Akwamu">
        Akwamu
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Region,_Ghana" title="Eastern Region, Ghana">
        Eastern region
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-col_21-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-col-21">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
       By the 19th century, the territory of the southern part of Ghana was included in the
       <a href="/wiki/Ashanti_Empire" title="Ashanti Empire">
        Kingdom of Ashanti
       </a>
       , one of the most influential states in sub-saharan Africa prior to the onset of colonialism.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-col_21-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-col-21">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Guinea_from_Milner%27s_Atlas.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="717" data-file-width="1008" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Guinea_from_Milner%27s_Atlas.jpg/220px-Guinea_from_Milner%27s_Atlas.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Guinea_from_Milner%27s_Atlas.jpg/330px-Guinea_from_Milner%27s_Atlas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Guinea_from_Milner%27s_Atlas.jpg/440px-Guinea_from_Milner%27s_Atlas.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Guinea_from_Milner%27s_Atlas.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         An 1850 map showing the
         <a href="/wiki/Akan_people" title="Akan people">
          Akan
         </a>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ashanti" title="Kingdom of Ashanti">
          Kingdom of Ashanti
         </a>
         within the
         <a href="/wiki/Guinea_(region)" title="Guinea (region)">
          Guinea region
         </a>
         and surrounding regions in West Africa
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Kingdom of Ashanti government operated first as a loose network, and eventually as a centralised kingdom with an advanced, highly specialised bureaucracy centred in the capital city of
       <a href="/wiki/Kumasi" title="Kumasi">
        Kumasi
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-col_21-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-col-21">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Prior to Akan contact with Europeans, the Akan
       <a href="/wiki/Ashanti_people" title="Ashanti people">
        Ashanti people
       </a>
       created an advanced economy based on principally gold and
       <a href="/wiki/Gold_bar" title="Gold bar">
        gold bar
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Commodity" title="Commodity">
        commodities
       </a>
       then traded with the states of Africa.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-col_21-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-col-21">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
        <a href="#cite_note-25">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The earliest known kingdoms to emerge in modern Ghana were the
       <a href="/wiki/Oti%E2%80%93Volta_languages" title="Oti–Volta languages">
        Mole-Dagbani
       </a>
       states.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-col_21-6">
        <a href="#cite_note-col-21">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Mole-Dagomba came on horseback from present-day
       <a href="/wiki/Burkina_Faso" title="Burkina Faso">
        Burkina Faso
       </a>
       under a single leader,
       <a href="/wiki/Na_Gbewa" title="Na Gbewa">
        Naa Gbewaa
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
        <a href="#cite_note-26">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
       With their advanced weapons and based on a central authority, they easily invaded and occupied the lands of the local people ruled by the
       <i>
        Tendamba
       </i>
       (land god priests), established themselves as the rulers over the locals, and made
       <a href="/wiki/Gambaga" title="Gambaga">
        Gambaga
       </a>
       their capital.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27">
        <a href="#cite_note-27">
         [27]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The death of Naa Gbewaa caused civil war among his children, some of whom broke off and founded separate state,s including
       <a href="/wiki/Dagomba_people" title="Dagomba people">
        Dagbon
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mamprusi_people" title="Mamprusi people">
        Mamprugu
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mossi_Kingdoms" title="Mossi Kingdoms">
        Mossi
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Nanumba_people" title="Nanumba people">
        Nanumba
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Wala_people" title="Wala people">
        Wala
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
        <a href="#cite_note-28">
         [28]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
        <a href="#cite_note-29">
         [29]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span id="European_contact_.2815th_century.29">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="European_contact_(15th_century)">
        European contact (15th century)
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: European contact (15th century)">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Gold_Coast_(region)" title="Gold Coast (region)">
        Gold Coast (region)
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ashanti_English_Medieval_Ewer.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1052" data-file-width="750" height="309" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/fc/Ashanti_English_Medieval_Ewer.jpg/220px-Ashanti_English_Medieval_Ewer.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/fc/Ashanti_English_Medieval_Ewer.jpg/330px-Ashanti_English_Medieval_Ewer.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/fc/Ashanti_English_Medieval_Ewer.jpg/440px-Ashanti_English_Medieval_Ewer.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ashanti_English_Medieval_Ewer.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         14th century medieval
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ewer" title="Ewer">
          ewer
         </a>
         looted from the Ashanti Empire in 1896 by British forces. The ewer was originally made for the court of
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Richard_II" title="Richard II">
          Richard II
         </a>
         . Currently housed at the British Museum. Historians are unsure how it came to reside with the Ashanti Empire in good condition after 500 years.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Akan trade with European states began after contact with
       <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">
        Portuguese
       </a>
       in the 15th century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30">
        <a href="#cite_note-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Early European contact by the
       <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">
        Portuguese people
       </a>
       , who came to the
       <a href="/wiki/Gold_Coast_(region)" title="Gold Coast (region)">
        Gold Coast region
       </a>
       in the 15th century to trade and then established the
       <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Gold_Coast" title="Portuguese Gold Coast">
        Portuguese Gold Coast
       </a>
       (Costa do Ouro), focused on the extensive availability of gold.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-History_31-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-History-31">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Portuguese built a trading lodge at a coastal settlement called Anomansah (the perpetual drink) which they renamed
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Elmina" title="Elmina">
         Elmina
        </a>
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-History_31-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-History-31">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1481, King
       <a href="/wiki/John_II_of_Portugal" title="John II of Portugal">
        John II of Portugal
       </a>
       commissioned
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diogo_d%27Azambuja" title="Diogo d'Azambuja">
        Diogo d'Azambuja
       </a>
       to build
       <a href="/wiki/Elmina_Castle" title="Elmina Castle">
        Elmina Castle
       </a>
       , which was completed in three years.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-History_31-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-History-31">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
       By 1598, the
       <a href="/wiki/Dutch_people" title="Dutch people">
        Dutch people
       </a>
       had joined the Portuguese people in gold trading, establishing the
       <a href="/wiki/Dutch_Gold_Coast" title="Dutch Gold Coast">
        Dutch Gold Coast
       </a>
       (Nederlandse Bezittingen ter Kuste van Guinea) and building forts at Komenda and Kormantsi.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_book_32-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_book-32">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1617, the Dutch captured the Olnini Castle from the Portuguese, and
       <a href="/wiki/Axim" title="Axim">
        Axim
       </a>
       in 1642 (Fort St Anthony).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_book_32-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_book-32">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Other European traders had joined in gold trading by the mid-17th century, most notably the
       <a href="/wiki/Swedes" title="Swedes">
        Swedish people
       </a>
       , establishing the
       <a href="/wiki/Swedish_Gold_Coast" title="Swedish Gold Coast">
        Swedish Gold Coast
       </a>
       (Svenska Guldkusten), and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Denmark-Norway" title="Denmark-Norway">
        Denmark-Norway
       </a>
       , establishing the
       <a href="/wiki/Danish_Gold_Coast" title="Danish Gold Coast">
        Danish Gold Coast
       </a>
       (Danske Guldkyst
       <i>
        or
       </i>
       Dansk Guinea).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-History_of_Ghana_33-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-History_of_Ghana-33">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">
        Portuguese
       </a>
       merchants, impressed with the gold resources in the area, named it
       <i>
        Costa do Ouro
       </i>
       or
       <i>
        Gold Coast
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-History_of_Ghana_33-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-History_of_Ghana-33">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aschanti_Gefecht_11_july_1824_300dpi.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1360" data-file-width="2781" height="108" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Aschanti_Gefecht_11_july_1824_300dpi.jpg/220px-Aschanti_Gefecht_11_july_1824_300dpi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Aschanti_Gefecht_11_july_1824_300dpi.jpg/330px-Aschanti_Gefecht_11_july_1824_300dpi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Aschanti_Gefecht_11_july_1824_300dpi.jpg/440px-Aschanti_Gefecht_11_july_1824_300dpi.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Aschanti_Gefecht_11_july_1824_300dpi.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Ashanti_wars" title="Anglo-Ashanti wars">
          first Anglo-Ashanti war
         </a>
         , 1823–31
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kwame_Nkrumah_(JFKWHP-AR6409-A).jpg">
         <img alt="Kwame Nkrumah" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="320" height="330" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Kwame_Nkrumah_%28JFKWHP-AR6409-A%29.jpg/220px-Kwame_Nkrumah_%28JFKWHP-AR6409-A%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/dc/Kwame_Nkrumah_%28JFKWHP-AR6409-A%29.jpg 1.5x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kwame_Nkrumah_(JFKWHP-AR6409-A).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Kwame_Nkrumah" title="Kwame Nkrumah">
          Kwame Nkrumah
         </a>
         , first President of Ghana
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       More than thirty forts and castles were built by the
       <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">
        Portuguese
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Swedes" title="Swedes">
        Swedish
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Denmark%E2%80%93Norway" title="Denmark–Norway">
        Dano-Norwegians
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Dutch_people" title="Dutch people">
        Dutch
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Germans" title="Germans">
        German
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Merchant" title="Merchant">
        merchants
       </a>
       ; the latter
       <a href="/wiki/Germans" title="Germans">
        German people
       </a>
       establishing the
       <a href="/wiki/Brandenburger_Gold_Coast" title="Brandenburger Gold Coast">
        German Gold Coast
       </a>
       (Brandenburger Gold Coast
       <i>
        or
       </i>
       Groß Friedrichsburg).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34">
        <a href="#cite_note-34">
         [34]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1874 Great Britain established control over some parts of the country assigning these areas the status of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Gold_Coast" title="British Gold Coast">
        British Gold Coast
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-colestablish_35-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-colestablish-35">
         [35]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Many
       <a href="/wiki/Engagement_(military)" title="Engagement (military)">
        military engagements
       </a>
       occurred between the British colonial powers and the various Akan nation-states and the Akan
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ashanti" title="Kingdom of Ashanti">
        Kingdom of Ashanti
       </a>
       defeated the British a few times in the
       <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Ashanti_wars" title="Anglo-Ashanti wars">
        Anglo-Ashanti wars
       </a>
       against the United Kingdom that lasted for 100 years, but eventually lost with the
       <a href="/wiki/War_of_the_Golden_Stool" title="War of the Golden Stool">
        War of the Golden Stool
       </a>
       in the early 1900s.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36">
        <a href="#cite_note-36">
         [36]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chronology_of_world_history_37-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Chronology_of_world_history-37">
         [37]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
        <a href="#cite_note-38">
         [38]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Transition_to_independence">
        Transition to independence
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Transition to independence">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_Ghana" title="Dominion of Ghana">
        Dominion of Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ghana_Independence_overprint_on_Gold_Coast_1s_stamp_1957.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="460" data-file-width="611" height="166" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Ghana_Independence_overprint_on_Gold_Coast_1s_stamp_1957.jpg/220px-Ghana_Independence_overprint_on_Gold_Coast_1s_stamp_1957.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Ghana_Independence_overprint_on_Gold_Coast_1s_stamp_1957.jpg/330px-Ghana_Independence_overprint_on_Gold_Coast_1s_stamp_1957.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Ghana_Independence_overprint_on_Gold_Coast_1s_stamp_1957.jpg/440px-Ghana_Independence_overprint_on_Gold_Coast_1s_stamp_1957.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ghana_Independence_overprint_on_Gold_Coast_1s_stamp_1957.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A postage stamp of Gold Coast overprinted for Ghanaian independence in 1957
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <div class="PopUpMediaTransform" id="mwe_player_1" style="width:220px;" videopayload='&lt;div class="mediaContainer" style="width:640px"&gt;&lt;video id="mwe_player_2" poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Ghana_%281957-03-07_A_New_Nation%29.ogv/640px--Ghana_%281957-03-07_A_New_Nation%29.ogv.jpg" controls="" preload="none" autoplay="" style="width:640px;height:480px" class="kskin" data-durationhint="55.013291666667" data-startoffset="0" data-mwtitle="Ghana_(1957-03-07_A_New_Nation).ogv" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons"&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/5a/Ghana_%281957-03-07_A_New_Nation%29.ogv/Ghana_%281957-03-07_A_New_Nation%29.ogv.480p.webm" type="video/webm;          <img alt="File:Ghana (1957-03-07 A New Nation).ogv" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Ghana_%281957-03-07_A_New_Nation%29.ogv/220px-seek%3D54.013291666667-Ghana_%281957-03-07_A_New_Nation%29.ogv.jpg" style="width:220px;height:165px"/>
         <a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5a/Ghana_%281957-03-07_A_New_Nation%29.ogv" target="new" title="Play media">
          <span class="play-btn-large">
           <span class="mw-tmh-playtext">
            Play media
           </span>
          </span>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ghana_(1957-03-07_A_New_Nation).ogv" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The commencing
         <a href="/wiki/Chronicle" title="Chronicle">
          chronicles
         </a>
         of Ghana on 6 March 1957 and
         <a href="/wiki/Kwame_Nkrumah" title="Kwame Nkrumah">
          Kwame Nkrumah
         </a>
         establishment of Ghanaian Republicanism, including
         <a href="/wiki/Ghanaian_presidential_election,_1960" title="Ghanaian presidential election, 1960">
          Ghanaian presidential election, 1960
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 1947, the newly formed
       <a href="/wiki/United_Gold_Coast_Convention" title="United Gold Coast Convention">
        United Gold Coast Convention
       </a>
       (UGCC) by
       <a href="/wiki/The_Big_Six_(Ghana)" title="The Big Six (Ghana)">
        The Big Six
       </a>
       called for "self-government within the shortest possible time" following the
       <a href="/wiki/Gold_Coast_legislative_election,_1946" title="Gold Coast legislative election, 1946">
        Gold Coast legislative election, 1946
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-History_of_Ghana_33-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-History_of_Ghana-33">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
        <a href="#cite_note-39">
         [39]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Kwame_Nkrumah" title="Kwame Nkrumah">
        Kwame Nkrumah
       </a>
       was the first
       <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Ghana" title="Prime Minister of Ghana">
        Prime Minister of Ghana
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Ghana" title="President of Ghana">
        President of Ghana
       </a>
       and formed the
       <a href="/wiki/Convention_People%27s_Party" title="Convention People's Party">
        Convention People's Party
       </a>
       (CPP) with the motto "self-government now".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-History_of_Ghana_33-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-History_of_Ghana-33">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Nkrumah won a majority in the
       <a href="/wiki/Gold_Coast_legislative_election,_1951" title="Gold Coast legislative election, 1951">
        Gold Coast legislative election, 1951
       </a>
       for the Gold Coast Legislative Assembly in 1952. Nkrumah was appointed leader of the Gold Coast's government business.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-History_of_Ghana_33-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-History_of_Ghana-33">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Gold Coast region declared independence from the United Kingdom on 6 March 1957 and established the nation of Ghana.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Universal_Newsreel_12-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Universal_Newsreel-12">
         [12]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-First_For_Sub-Saharan_Africa_13-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-First_For_Sub-Saharan_Africa-13">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Exploring_Africa_–_Decolinization_14-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Exploring_Africa_–_Decolinization-14">
         [14]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On 6 March 1957 at 12 a.m. Nkrumah declared Ghana's establishment and autonomy. On 1 July 1960, following the
       <a href="/wiki/Ghanaian_constitutional_referendum,_1960" title="Ghanaian constitutional referendum, 1960">
        Ghanaian constitutional referendum, 1960
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ghanaian_presidential_election,_1960" title="Ghanaian presidential election, 1960">
        Ghanaian presidential election, 1960
       </a>
       Nkrumah declared Ghana as a republic as the first
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Ghana" title="President of Ghana">
        President of Ghana
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-History_of_Ghana_33-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-History_of_Ghana-33">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Ghana" title="Flag of Ghana">
        flag of Ghana
       </a>
       , consisting of the colours red, gold, green, and a black star, became the new flag in 1957 when Gold Coast gained its name Ghana.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_flag_and_description_40-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_flag_and_description-40">
         [40]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It was designed by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Theodosia_Salome_Okoh" title="Theodosia Salome Okoh">
        Theodosia Salome Okoh
       </a>
       ; the red represents the blood that was shed towards independence, the gold represents the
       <a href="/wiki/Industrial_mineral" title="Industrial mineral">
        industrial minerals
       </a>
       wealth of Ghana, the green symbolises the rich
       <a href="/wiki/Grassland" title="Grassland">
        grasslands
       </a>
       of Ghana, and the black star is the symbol of the Ghanaian people and African emancipation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41">
        <a href="#cite_note-41">
         [41]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:165px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Akufo_Addo.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="190" data-file-width="163" height="190" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/3/34/Akufo_Addo.jpg" width="163"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Akufo_Addo.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Edward_Akufo-Addo" title="Edward Akufo-Addo">
          Edward Akufo-Addo
         </a>
         , ceremonial President of Ghana from 1969 to 1972 and founding member of the United Gold Coast Convention
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
          <a href="#cite_note-42">
           [42]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Nkrumah was the first African head of state to promote the concept of
       <a href="/wiki/Pan-Africanism" title="Pan-Africanism">
        Pan-Africanism
       </a>
       , which he had been introduced to during his studies at
       <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_University_(Pennsylvania)" title="Lincoln University (Pennsylvania)">
        Lincoln University, Pennsylvania
       </a>
       in the United States, at the time when
       <a href="/wiki/Marcus_Garvey" title="Marcus Garvey">
        Marcus Garvey
       </a>
       was becoming famous for his "Back to Africa Movement".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-History_of_Ghana_33-6">
        <a href="#cite_note-History_of_Ghana-33">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Nkrumah merged the teachings of Marcus Garvey,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Martin_Luther_King,_Jr." title="Martin Luther King, Jr.">
        Martin Luther King, Jr.
       </a>
       and the naturalised
       <a href="/wiki/Ghanaian_people" title="Ghanaian people">
        Ghanaian
       </a>
       scholar
       <a href="/wiki/W._E._B._Du_Bois" title="W. E. B. Du Bois">
        W. E. B. Du Bois
       </a>
       into the formation of 1960s Ghana.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-History_of_Ghana_33-7">
        <a href="#cite_note-History_of_Ghana-33">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Osagyefo Dr. Kwame Nkrumah, as he became known, played an instrumental part in the founding of the
       <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">
        Non-Aligned Movement
       </a>
       , and in establishing the
       <a href="/wiki/Kwame_Nkrumah_Ideological_Institute" title="Kwame Nkrumah Ideological Institute">
        Kwame Nkrumah Ideological Institute
       </a>
       to teach his ideologies of
       <a href="/wiki/Communism" title="Communism">
        communism
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Socialism" title="Socialism">
        socialism
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43">
        <a href="#cite_note-43">
         [43]
        </a>
       </sup>
       His life achievements were recognised by Ghanaians during his centenary birthday celebration, and the day was instituted as a
       <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Ghana" title="Public holidays in Ghana">
        public holiday in Ghana
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Founder%27s_Day_(Ghana)" title="Founder's Day (Ghana)">
        Founder's Day
       </a>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44">
        <a href="#cite_note-44">
         [44]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div style="clear:left;">
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Operation_Cold_Chop_and_aftermath">
        Operation Cold Chop and aftermath
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Operation Cold Chop and aftermath">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Ghana_(1966%E2%80%9379)" title="History of Ghana (1966–79)">
        History of Ghana (1966–79)
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The government of Osagyefo
       <a href="/wiki/Kwame_Nkrumah" title="Kwame Nkrumah">
        Dr. Kwame Nkrumah
       </a>
       was subsequently overthrown by a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coup" title="Coup">
        coup
       </a>
       by the
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Armed_Forces" title="Ghana Armed Forces">
        Ghana Armed Forces
       </a>
       codenamed "Operation Cold Chop." This occurred while Nkrumah was abroad with
       <a href="/wiki/Zhou_Enlai" title="Zhou Enlai">
        Zhou Enlai
       </a>
       in the People's Republic of China, on a fruitless mission to
       <a href="/wiki/Hanoi" title="Hanoi">
        Hanoi
       </a>
       in Vietnam to help end the
       <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">
        Vietnam War
       </a>
       . The coup took place on 24 February 1966, led by Col. Emmanuel K. Kotoka. National Liberation Council (N.L.C.) formed and chaired by Lt. General Joseph A. Ankrah.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-political_&amp;_social_thought_of_Kwame_Nkrumah_45-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-political_&amp;_social_thought_of_Kwame_Nkrumah-45">
         [45]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       A series of alternating military and civilian governments, often affected by economic instabilities,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46">
        <a href="#cite_note-46">
         [46]
        </a>
       </sup>
       from 1966 to 1981 ended with the ascension to power of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flight_Lieutenant" title="Flight Lieutenant">
        Flight Lieutenant
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Jerry_Rawlings" title="Jerry Rawlings">
        Jerry John Rawlings
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/Provisional_National_Defence_Council" title="Provisional National Defence Council">
        Provisional National Defence Council
       </a>
       (PNDC) in 1981.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Flight_Lieutenant_Jerry_John_Rawlings_(J.J_Rawlings)_47-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Flight_Lieutenant_Jerry_John_Rawlings_(J.J_Rawlings)-47">
         [47]
        </a>
       </sup>
       These changes resulted in the suspension of the
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Ghana" title="Constitution of Ghana">
        Constitution of Ghana
       </a>
       in 1981, and the banning of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Political_parties_in_Ghana" title="Political parties in Ghana">
        political parties in Ghana
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rawlings:_The_legacy_48-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Rawlings:_The_legacy-48">
         [48]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The economy soon declined, so Rawlings negotiated a structural adjustment plan changing many old economic policies, and economic growth soon recovered during the mid–1980s.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rawlings:_The_legacy_48-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Rawlings:_The_legacy-48">
         [48]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A new
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Ghana" title="Constitution of Ghana">
        Constitution of Ghana
       </a>
       restoring
       <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_system" title="Multi-party system">
        multi-party system
       </a>
       politics was promulgated in
       <a href="/wiki/Ghanaian_presidential_election,_1992" title="Ghanaian presidential election, 1992">
        Ghanaian presidential election, 1992
       </a>
       ; Rawlings was elected as president of Ghana then, and again in
       <a href="/wiki/Ghanaian_general_election,_1996" title="Ghanaian general election, 1996">
        Ghanaian general election, 1996
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Elections_in_Ghana_49-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Elections_in_Ghana-49">
         [49]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div style="clear:left;">
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="21st_century">
        21st century
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: 21st century">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kpetoee.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="667" data-file-width="1000" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Kpetoee.jpg/220px-Kpetoee.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Kpetoee.jpg/330px-Kpetoee.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Kpetoee.jpg/440px-Kpetoee.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kpetoee.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Traditional
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chieftaincy" title="Chieftaincy">
          chiefs
         </a>
         in Ghana in 2015
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Winning the
       <a href="/wiki/Ghanaian_general_election,_2000" title="Ghanaian general election, 2000">
        2000 Ghanaian elections
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/John_Kufuor" title="John Kufuor">
        John Agyekum Kufuor
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/New_Patriotic_Party" title="New Patriotic Party">
        New Patriotic Party
       </a>
       (NPP) was sworn into office as president of Ghana on 7 January 2001, and attained the presidency again in the
       <a href="/wiki/Ghanaian_general_election,_2004" title="Ghanaian general election, 2004">
        2004 Ghanaian elections
       </a>
       , thus also serving two
       <a href="/wiki/Term_of_office" title="Term of office">
        terms
       </a>
       (the
       <a href="/wiki/Term_limit" title="Term limit">
        term limit
       </a>
       ) as president of Ghana and thus marking the first time under the fourth republic of Ghana that power had been transferred from one legitimately elected
       <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">
        head of state
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">
        head of government
       </a>
       to another.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Elections_in_Ghana_49-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Elections_in_Ghana-49">
         [49]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Kufuor was succeeded to the presidency of the Republic of Ghana by John Atta Mills of the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Democratic_Congress_(Ghana)" title="National Democratic Congress (Ghana)">
        National Democratic Congress
       </a>
       (NDC) following the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ghanaian_presidential_election,_2008" title="Ghanaian presidential election, 2008">
        Ghanaian presidential election, 2008
       </a>
       . and
       <a href="/wiki/John_Atta_Mills" title="John Atta Mills">
        John Atta Mills
       </a>
       was inaugurated as the third president of the fourth republic of Ghana and eleventh president of Ghana on 7 January 2009,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50">
        <a href="#cite_note-50">
         [50]
        </a>
       </sup>
       prior to John Atta Mills being succeeded as president of Ghana by then vice-president of Ghana John Dramani Mahama on 24 July 2012.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
        <a href="#cite_note-51">
         [51]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Following the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ghanaian_presidential_election,_2012" title="Ghanaian presidential election, 2012">
        Ghanaian presidential election, 2012
       </a>
       , John Dramani Mahama became President-elect and was inaugurated as the 4th President of the Fourth Republic of Ghana and 7th President of Ghana on 7 January 2013, to serve one
       <a href="/wiki/Term_of_office" title="Term of office">
        term of office
       </a>
       of four-year term length as
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Ghana" title="President of Ghana">
        President of Ghana
       </a>
       until 7 January 2017,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghanaian_President_John_Dramani_Mahama_sworn_in_52-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghanaian_President_John_Dramani_Mahama_sworn_in-52">
         [52]
        </a>
       </sup>
       maintaining Ghana's status as a stable democracy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Elections_in_Ghana_49-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Elections_in_Ghana-49">
         [49]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       As a result of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ghanaian_presidential_election,_2016" title="Ghanaian presidential election, 2016">
        Ghanaian presidential election, 2016
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Nana_Akufo-Addo" title="Nana Akufo-Addo">
        Nana Akufo-Addo
       </a>
       became President-elect and was inaugurated as the 5th President of the Fourth Republic of Ghana and 8th President of Ghana on 7 January 2017, to serve one
       <a href="/wiki/Term_of_office" title="Term of office">
        term of office
       </a>
       of four-year term length as
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Ghana" title="President of Ghana">
        President of Ghana
       </a>
       , until 7 January 2021.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53">
        <a href="#cite_note-53">
         [53]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Historical_timeline">
        Historical timeline
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Historical timeline">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div style="width:75%; overflow:scroll">
       <div class="timeline-wrapper">
        <map name="timeline_6912cc8daaa69f5cdbe0251cf93b8686">
         <area alt="Nana Akufo-Addo" coords="660,262,798,286" href="/wiki/Nana_Akufo%2DAddo" shape="rect" title="Nana Akufo-Addo"/>
         <area alt="John Dramani Mahama" coords="606,243,771,267" href="/wiki/John_Dramani_Mahama" shape="rect" title="John Dramani Mahama"/>
         <area alt="John Atta Mills" coords="570,224,815,248" href="/wiki/John_Atta_Mills" shape="rect" title="John Atta Mills"/>
         <area alt="John Kufuor" coords="532,206,697,230" href="/wiki/John_Kufuor" shape="rect" title="John Kufuor"/>
         <area alt="Jerry Rawlings" coords="447,187,732,211" href="/wiki/Jerry_Rawlings" shape="rect" title="Jerry Rawlings"/>
         <area alt="Jerry Rawlings" coords="351,168,636,192" href="/wiki/Jerry_Rawlings" shape="rect" title="Jerry Rawlings"/>
         <area alt="Hilla Limann" coords="244,150,362,174" href="/wiki/Hilla_Limann" shape="rect" title="Hilla Limann"/>
         <area alt="Jerry Rawlings" coords="220,131,505,155" href="/wiki/Jerry_Rawlings" shape="rect" title="Jerry Rawlings"/>
         <area alt="Fred Akuffo" coords="216,112,615,136" href="/wiki/Fred_Akuffo" shape="rect" title="Fred Akuffo"/>
         <area alt="Ignatius Acheampong" coords="207,94,465,118" href="/wiki/Ignatius_Acheampong" shape="rect" title="Ignatius Acheampong"/>

        </map>
        <img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/timeline/6912cc8daaa69f5cdbe0251cf93b8686.png" usemap="#timeline_6912cc8daaa69f5cdbe0251cf93b8686"/>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">
        Geography
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Geography">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Ghana" title="Geography of Ghana">
        Geography of Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ghana_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1900" data-file-width="1900" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Ghana_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg/220px-Ghana_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Ghana_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg/330px-Ghana_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Ghana_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg/440px-Ghana_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ghana_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Ghana map of Köppen climate classification.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Ghana is located on the
       <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Guinea" title="Gulf of Guinea">
        Gulf of Guinea
       </a>
       , only a few degrees north of the
       <a href="/wiki/Equator" title="Equator">
        Equator
       </a>
       , therefore giving it a warm climate.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Geography_Physical_54-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Geography_Physical-54">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ghana spans an area of 238,535 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (92,099 sq mi), and has an Atlantic coastline that stretches 560 kilometres (350 miles) on the Gulf of Guinea in Atlantic Ocean to its south.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Geography_Physical_54-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Geography_Physical-54">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It lies between latitudes 4°45'N and 11°N, and longitudes 1°15'E and 3°15'W. The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prime_Meridian" title="Prime Meridian">
        Prime Meridian
       </a>
       passes through Ghana, specifically through the industrial
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Port_town" title="Port town">
        port town
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Tema" title="Tema">
        Tema
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Geography_Physical_54-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Geography_Physical-54">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ghana is geographically closer to the "centre" of the
       <a href="/wiki/Earth" title="Earth">
        Earth
       </a>
       geographical coordinates than any other country; even though the notional centre, (0°, 0°) is located in the Atlantic Ocean approximately 614 km (382 mi) off the south-east coast of Ghana on the Gulf of Guinea.
       <a href="/wiki/Grassland" title="Grassland">
        Grasslands
       </a>
       mixed with south coastal
       <a href="/wiki/Shrubland" title="Shrubland">
        shrublands
       </a>
       and forests dominate Ghana, with forest extending northward from the south-west coast of Ghana on the Gulf of Guinea in the Atlantic Ocean 320 kilometres (200 miles) and eastward for a maximum of about 270 kilometres (170 miles) with the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ashanti" title="Kingdom of Ashanti">
        Kingdom of Ashanti
       </a>
       or the southern part of Ghana being a primary location for mining of
       <a href="/wiki/Industrial_mineral" title="Industrial mineral">
        industrial minerals
       </a>
       and timber.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Geography_Physical_54-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Geography_Physical-54">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Ghana encompasses
       <a href="/wiki/Plain" title="Plain">
        plains
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Waterfall" title="Waterfall">
        waterfalls
       </a>
       , low hills, rivers,
       <a href="/wiki/Lake_Volta" title="Lake Volta">
        Lake Volta
       </a>
       , the world's largest artificial lake,
       <a href="/wiki/Dodi_Island" title="Dodi Island">
        Dodi Island
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Bobowasi_Island" title="Bobowasi Island">
        Bobowasi Island
       </a>
       on the south Atlantic Ocean coast of Ghana.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_low_plains_55-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_low_plains-55">
         [55]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The northernmost part of Ghana is Pulmakong and the southernmost part of Ghana is
       <a href="/wiki/Cape_Three_Points" title="Cape Three Points">
        Cape Three Points
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Geography_Physical_54-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-Geography_Physical-54">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">
        Climate
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Climate">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Ghana" title="Climate of Ghana">
        Climate of Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Climate" title="Climate">
        climate
       </a>
       of Ghana is
       <a href="/wiki/Tropical_climate" title="Tropical climate">
        tropical
       </a>
       and there are two main seasons: the
       <a href="/wiki/Wet_season" title="Wet season">
        wet season
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Dry_season" title="Dry season">
        dry season
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="width:90%; text-align:center; font-size:90%; line-height: 1.2em; margin:auto;">

      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Rivers">
        Rivers
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Rivers">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_rivers_of_Ghana" title="List of rivers of Ghana">
        Rivers of Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Ghana has a vast river system with an array of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tributaries" title="Tributaries">
        tributaries
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <div class="thumb noresize tnone" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right:auto; overflow:hidden; width:auto; max-width:908px;">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="">
        <div class="overflowbugx" style="overflow:auto;">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Volta_lake_from_the_Saint_Barbara_Church.JPG" title="Panorama and landscape view of Lake Volta in Volta Basin and Eastern Region of Ghana. Lake Volta by artificial surface area is the largest reservoir in the world. Lake Volta drains into the Gulf of Guinea on the Atlantic Ocean. Volta River has three main tributaries—the Black Volta, White Volta and Red Volta.">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="1332" data-file-width="3648" height="329" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Volta_lake_from_the_Saint_Barbara_Church.JPG/900px-Volta_lake_from_the_Saint_Barbara_Church.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Volta_lake_from_the_Saint_Barbara_Church.JPG/1350px-Volta_lake_from_the_Saint_Barbara_Church.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Volta_lake_from_the_Saint_Barbara_Church.JPG/1800px-Volta_lake_from_the_Saint_Barbara_Church.JPG 2x" width="900"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:center">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Volta_lake_from_the_Saint_Barbara_Church.JPG" title="File:Volta lake from the Saint Barbara Church.JPG">
          </a>
         </div>
         Panorama and
         <a href="/wiki/Landscape" title="Landscape">
          landscape
         </a>
         view of Lake Volta in
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volta_Basin" title="Volta Basin">
          Volta Basin
         </a>
         and
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Region,_Ghana" title="Eastern Region, Ghana">
          Eastern Region
         </a>
         of Ghana.
         <a href="/wiki/Lake_Volta" title="Lake Volta">
          Lake Volta
         </a>
         by artificial surface area is the largest reservoir in the
         <a href="/wiki/Earth" title="Earth">
          world
         </a>
         . Lake Volta
         <a href="/wiki/Drainage" title="Drainage">
          drains
         </a>
         into the
         <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Guinea" title="Gulf of Guinea">
          Gulf of Guinea
         </a>
         on the Atlantic Ocean.
         <a href="/wiki/Volta_River" title="Volta River">
          Volta River
         </a>
         has three main tributaries—the
         <a href="/wiki/Black_Volta" title="Black Volta">
          Black Volta
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/White_Volta" title="White Volta">
          White Volta
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Red_Volta" title="Red Volta">
          Red Volta
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Wildlife">
        Wildlife
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Wildlife">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Ghana" title="Wildlife of Ghana">
        Wildlife of Ghana
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Ghana" title="List of national parks of Ghana">
        National parks of Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Ghana has an array of
       <a href="/wiki/Wildlife" title="Wildlife">
        wildlife
       </a>
       that can be seen at
       <a href="/wiki/Zoo" title="Zoo">
        zoos
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/National_park" title="National park">
        national parks
       </a>
       in Ghana, although populations have been drastically reduced by habitat loss and poaching.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Government">
        Government
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Government">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ghana" title="Government of Ghana">
        Government of Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Ghana" title="Politics of Ghana">
        Politics of Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
