        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left;background-color:transparent">
         <a href="/wiki/Parliament_House_of_Ghana" title="Parliament House of Ghana">
          Parliament House of Ghana
         </a>
         seat of the Government of Ghana, the Supreme Court of Ghana and
         <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Ghana" title="Judiciary of Ghana">
          Judiciary of Ghana
         </a>
         buildings,
         <a href="/wiki/Osu_Castle" title="Osu Castle">
          Osu Castle
         </a>
         is the
         <i>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Defacto" title="Defacto">
           defacto
          </a>
         </i>
         residence of presidency and
         <a href="/wiki/The_Flagstaff_House" title="The Flagstaff House">
          The Flagstaff House
         </a>
         is the
         <a href="/wiki/Official_residence" title="Official residence">
          official residence
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Presidential_palace" title="Presidential palace">
          presidential palace
         </a>
         . First President of the Republic of Ghana
         <a href="/wiki/Kwame_Nkrumah" title="Kwame Nkrumah">
          Nkrumah
         </a>
         and Presidents of the 4th Republic of Ghana
         <a href="/wiki/Jerry_Rawlings" title="Jerry Rawlings">
          Rawlings
         </a>
         ;
         <a href="/wiki/John_Kufuor" title="John Kufuor">
          Kufuor
         </a>
         ;
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/John_Evans_Atta_Mills" title="John Evans Atta Mills">
          Mills
         </a>
         and
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/John_Dramani_Mahama" title="John Dramani Mahama">
          Mahama
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Ghana is a
       <a href="/wiki/Unitary_executive_theory" title="Unitary executive theory">
        unitary
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Presidential_system" title="Presidential system">
        presidential
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constitutional_democracy" title="Constitutional democracy">
        constitutional democracy
       </a>
       with a parliamentary
       <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_system" title="Multi-party system">
        multi-party system
       </a>
       and former alternating
       <a href="/wiki/Military_occupation" title="Military occupation">
        military occupation
       </a>
       . Following alternating military and civilian governments in January 1993, the Ghana military government gave way to the Fourth Republic of Ghana after
       <a href="/wiki/Ghanaian_presidential_election,_1992" title="Ghanaian presidential election, 1992">
        presidential elections
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ghanaian_parliamentary_election,_1992" title="Ghanaian parliamentary election, 1992">
        parliamentary elections
       </a>
       in late 1992. The 1992
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Ghana" title="Constitution of Ghana">
        constitution of Ghana
       </a>
       divides powers among a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commander-in-Chief" title="Commander-in-Chief">
        Commander-in-Chief
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Armed_Forces" title="Ghana Armed Forces">
        Ghana Armed Forces
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Ghana" title="President of Ghana">
        President of Ghana
       </a>
       ), parliament (
       <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Ghana" title="Parliament of Ghana">
        Parliament of Ghana
       </a>
       ), cabinet (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministers_of_the_Ghanaian_Government" title="Ministers of the Ghanaian Government">
        Ministers of the Ghanaian Government
       </a>
       ), council of state (
       <a href="/wiki/Council_of_State_(Ghana)" title="Council of State (Ghana)">
        Ghanaian Council of State
       </a>
       ), and an independent judiciary (
       <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Ghana" title="Judiciary of Ghana">
        Judiciary of Ghana
       </a>
       ). The
       <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ghana" title="Government of Ghana">
        Government of Ghana
       </a>
       is elected by
       <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">
        universal suffrage
       </a>
       after every four years.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cs_57-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-cs-57">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Electoral_Commission_of_Ghana" title="Electoral Commission of Ghana">
        Electoral Commission of Ghana
       </a>
       announced that former
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_Ghana" title="Vice President of Ghana">
        Vice President of Ghana
       </a>
       John Dramani Mahama had won the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ghana_presidential_election,_2012" title="Ghana presidential election, 2012">
        Ghana presidential election, 2012
       </a>
       on 7 December 2012 and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/John_Dramani_Mahama" title="John Dramani Mahama">
        John Dramani Mahama
       </a>
       was sworn in, amidst announcement of
       <a href="/wiki/Electoral_fraud" title="Electoral fraud">
        electoral fraud
       </a>
       , as the reigning
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Ghana" title="President of Ghana">
        President of Ghana
       </a>
       on 7 January 2013 to serve a four-year term that expired on Saturday, 7 January 2017.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghanaian_President_John_Dramani_Mahama_sworn_in_52-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghanaian_President_John_Dramani_Mahama_sworn_in-52">
         [52]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The 2012
       <a href="/wiki/Fragile_States_Index" title="Fragile States Index">
        Fragile States Index
       </a>
       indicated that Ghana is ranked the 67th least fragile state in the world and the 5th least fragile state in Africa after
       <a href="/wiki/Mauritius" title="Mauritius">
        Mauritius
       </a>
       , 2nd
       <a href="/wiki/Seychelles" title="Seychelles">
        Seychelles
       </a>
       , 3rd
       <a href="/wiki/Botswana" title="Botswana">
        Botswana
       </a>
       , and 4th
       <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">
        South Africa
       </a>
       . Ghana ranked 112th out of 177 countries on the index.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
        <a href="#cite_note-58">
         [58]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ghana ranked as the 64th least
       <a href="/wiki/Corruption" title="Corruption">
        corrupt
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Political_corruption" title="Political corruption">
        politically corrupt
       </a>
       country in the world out of all 174 countries ranked and Ghana ranked as the 5th least corrupt and politically corrupt country in Africa out of 53 countries in the 2012
       <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">
        Transparency International Corruption Perception Index
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
        <a href="#cite_note-59">
         [59]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
        <a href="#cite_note-60">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ghana was ranked 7th in Africa out of 53 countries in the 2012
       <a href="/wiki/Ibrahim_Index_of_African_Governance" title="Ibrahim Index of African Governance">
        Ibrahim Index of African Governance
       </a>
       . The Ibrahim Index is a comprehensive measure of African government, based on a number of different variables which reflect the success with which governments deliver essential political goods to its citizens.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
        <a href="#cite_note-61">
         [61]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Nkrumah was a Ghanaian nationalist leader who led the country from 1957 to 1966. Nkrumah’s political journey started when he entered Lincoln University in Pennsylvania in 1935. He graduated got his master's degrees from Lincoln and the University of Pennsylvania.He formed the Convention Peoples’ Party, The party initiated a “positive action” campaign involving non-violent protests, strikes and non-cooperation with the British authorities. Nkrumah was arrested and sentenced to one year imprisonment during this time. In the Gold Coast’s February 1951 general election, he was elected to Parliament and released from prison to become leader of government business. He became Prime Minister of the Gold Coast in 1952s leadership was authoritarian but he improved the infrastructure of the country and his Africanisation policies created better career opportunities for Ghanaians. He was deposed in a coup in 1966.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">
        Foreign relations
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Foreign relations">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Ghana" title="Foreign relations of Ghana">
        Foreign relations of Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:800px-Oyw_kofi.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="533" data-file-width="800" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/800px-Oyw_kofi.jpg/220px-800px-Oyw_kofi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/800px-Oyw_kofi.jpg/330px-800px-Oyw_kofi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/800px-Oyw_kofi.jpg/440px-800px-Oyw_kofi.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:800px-Oyw_kofi.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Kofi_Annan" title="Kofi Annan">
          Kofi Annan
         </a>
         , Ghanaian diplomat and United Nations Secretary-General 1997–2006
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Since independence, Ghana has been devoted to ideals of nonalignment and is a founding member of the
       <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">
        Non-Aligned Movement
       </a>
       . Ghana favours international and regional political and economic co-operation, and is an active member of the United Nations and the African Union.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-H._E._Mr._Ken_Kanda_62-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-H._E._Mr._Ken_Kanda-62">
         [62]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Ghana has a strong relationship with the United States. All of the last three U.S presidents--
       <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">
        Bill Clinton
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">
        George W. Bush
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">
        Barack Obama
       </a>
       --have made diplomatic trips to Ghana. Many Ghanaian diplomats and politicians hold positions in international organisations, including Ghanaian diplomat and former
       <a href="/wiki/Secretary-General_of_the_United_Nations" title="Secretary-General of the United Nations">
        Secretary-General of the United Nations
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Kofi_Annan" title="Kofi Annan">
        Kofi Annan
       </a>
       , International Criminal Court Judge
       <a href="/wiki/Akua_Kuenyehia" title="Akua Kuenyehia">
        Akua Kuenyehia
       </a>
       , former President
       <a href="/wiki/Jerry_Rawlings" title="Jerry Rawlings">
        Jerry John Rawlings
       </a>
       and former President John Agyekum Kuffour, who have both served as diplomats of the United Nations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cs_57-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-cs-57">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In September 2010, Ghana's former President
       <a href="/wiki/John_Atta_Mills" title="John Atta Mills">
        John Atta Mills
       </a>
       visited China on an official visit. Mills and China's former President
       <a href="/wiki/Hu_Jintao" title="Hu Jintao">
        Hu Jintao
       </a>
       , marked the 50th anniversary of diplomatic ties between the two nations, at the
       <a href="/wiki/Great_Hall_of_the_People" title="Great Hall of the People">
        Great Hall of the People
       </a>
       on 20 September 2010.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hu_Jintao-John_Atta_Mills_63-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Hu_Jintao-John_Atta_Mills-63">
         [63]
        </a>
       </sup>
       China reciprocated with an official visit in November 2011, by the Vice-Chairman of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Standing_Committee_of_the_National_People%27s_Congress_of_China" title="Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of China">
        Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of China
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Zhou_Tienong" title="Zhou Tienong">
        Zhou Tienong
       </a>
       who visited Ghana and met with Ghana's President
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/John_Dramani_Mahama" title="John Dramani Mahama">
        John Dramani Mahama
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Xinhua2011_64-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Xinhua2011-64">
         [64]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">
        Islamic Republic of Iran
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Iran" title="List of Presidents of Iran">
        6th
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Iran" title="President of Iran">
        President of Iran
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mahmoud_Ahmadinejad" title="Mahmoud Ahmadinejad">
        Mahmoud Ahmadinejad
       </a>
       met with the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_heads_of_state_of_Ghana" title="List of heads of state of Ghana">
        12th
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Ghana" title="President of Ghana">
        President of Ghana
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/John_Dramani_Mahama" title="John Dramani Mahama">
        John Dramani Mahama
       </a>
       on 16 April 2013 to hold discussions with President John Dramani Mahama on strengthening the
       <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">
        Non-Aligned Movement
       </a>
       and also co–chair a bilateral meeting between Ghana and Iran at the Ghanaian
       <a href="/wiki/Presidential_palace" title="Presidential palace">
        presidential palace
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Flagstaff_House" title="Flagstaff House">
        Flagstaff House
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ahmadinejad_65-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ahmadinejad-65">
         [65]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ahmadinejad2_66-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ahmadinejad2-66">
         [66]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CPP_welcomes_President_Ahmadinejad_visit_to_Ghana_67-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CPP_welcomes_President_Ahmadinejad_visit_to_Ghana-67">
         [67]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_welcomed_Iran's_President_Mahmoud_Ahmadinejad_68-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_welcomed_Iran's_President_Mahmoud_Ahmadinejad-68">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-President_Mahmoud_Ahmadinejad_69-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-President_Mahmoud_Ahmadinejad-69">
         [69]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ghana" title="Government of Ghana">
        Government of Ghana
       </a>
       reciprocated with an official
       <a href="/wiki/State_visit" title="State visit">
        state visit
       </a>
       on 5 August 2013 by the
       <a href="/wiki/Vice-President_of_Ghana" title="Vice-President of Ghana">
        Vice-President of Ghana
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kwesi_Amissah-Arthur" title="Kwesi Amissah-Arthur">
        Kwesi Amissah-Arthur
       </a>
       , who
       <a href="/wiki/Meeting" title="Meeting">
        met
       </a>
       with the Vice-President of Iran,
       <a href="/wiki/Eshaq_Jahangiri" title="Eshaq Jahangiri">
        Eshaq Jahangiri
       </a>
       on the basis of
       <a href="/wiki/Autarky" title="Autarky">
        autarky
       </a>
       and possible
       <a href="/wiki/Bilateral_trade" title="Bilateral trade">
        bilateral trade
       </a>
       at the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="Islamic Republic of Iran">
        Islamic Republic of Iran
       </a>
       's
       <a href="/wiki/Presidential_palace" title="Presidential palace">
        presidential palace
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sa%27dabad_Palace" title="Sa'dabad Palace">
        Sa'dabad Palace
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Iran_welcomes_expansion_of_trade_ties_with_Ghana:_Vice-president_70-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Iran_welcomes_expansion_of_trade_ties_with_Ghana:_Vice-president-70">
         [70]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">
        <div style="width: 155px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;">
          <div style="margin:35.5px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fokker_F-28-3000_Fellowship,_Ghana_-_Air_Force_AN0193478.jpg">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="674" data-file-width="1024" height="79" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Fokker_F-28-3000_Fellowship%2C_Ghana_-_Air_Force_AN0193478.jpg/120px-Fokker_F-28-3000_Fellowship%2C_Ghana_-_Air_Force_AN0193478.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Fokker_F-28-3000_Fellowship%2C_Ghana_-_Air_Force_AN0193478.jpg/180px-Fokker_F-28-3000_Fellowship%2C_Ghana_-_Air_Force_AN0193478.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Fokker_F-28-3000_Fellowship%2C_Ghana_-_Air_Force_AN0193478.jpg/240px-Fokker_F-28-3000_Fellowship%2C_Ghana_-_Air_Force_AN0193478.jpg 2x" width="120"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           <a href="/wiki/Fokker_F28_Fellowship" title="Fokker F28 Fellowship">
            Fokker F28 Fellowship
           </a>
           of the
           <a href="/wiki/President_of_Ghana" title="President of Ghana">
            President of Ghana
           </a>
           arrives on
           <a href="/wiki/State_visit" title="State visit">
            State visit
           </a>
           at the
           <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Capital_International_Airport" title="Beijing Capital International Airport">
            Beijing Capital International Airport
           </a>
           in Beijing, People's Republic of China
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">
        <div style="width: 155px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;">
          <div style="margin:30.5px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vladimir_Putin_with_Kofi_Annan-3.jpg">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="2224" data-file-width="3000" height="89" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Vladimir_Putin_with_Kofi_Annan-3.jpg/120px-Vladimir_Putin_with_Kofi_Annan-3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Vladimir_Putin_with_Kofi_Annan-3.jpg/180px-Vladimir_Putin_with_Kofi_Annan-3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Vladimir_Putin_with_Kofi_Annan-3.jpg/240px-Vladimir_Putin_with_Kofi_Annan-3.jpg 2x" width="120"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           Diplomat Kofi Annan
           <a href="/wiki/Meeting" title="Meeting">
            meeting
           </a>
           with
           <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">
            Vladimir Putin
           </a>
           in
           <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg" title="Saint Petersburg">
            Saint Petersburg
           </a>
           ,
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_Federation" title="Russian Federation">
            Russian Federation
           </a>
           .
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">
        <div style="width: 155px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;">
          <div style="margin:35px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LuladaSilvaeJohnKufuor.JPG">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="479" data-file-width="720" height="80" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/LuladaSilvaeJohnKufuor.JPG/120px-LuladaSilvaeJohnKufuor.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/LuladaSilvaeJohnKufuor.JPG/180px-LuladaSilvaeJohnKufuor.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/LuladaSilvaeJohnKufuor.JPG/240px-LuladaSilvaeJohnKufuor.JPG 2x" width="120"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           Presidents
           <a href="/wiki/John_Kufuor" title="John Kufuor">
            John Kufuor
           </a>
           of Ghana and
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lula_da_Silva" title="Lula da Silva">
            Lula da Silva
           </a>
           of
           <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">
            Brazil
           </a>
           meet in Accra.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">
        <div style="width: 155px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;">
          <div style="margin:35px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Obama_family_departure_from_Ghana.jpg">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="433" data-file-width="650" height="80" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Obama_family_departure_from_Ghana.jpg/120px-Obama_family_departure_from_Ghana.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Obama_family_departure_from_Ghana.jpg/180px-Obama_family_departure_from_Ghana.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Obama_family_departure_from_Ghana.jpg/240px-Obama_family_departure_from_Ghana.jpg 2x" width="120"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">
            Barack Obama
           </a>
           and
           <a href="/wiki/Michelle_Obama" title="Michelle Obama">
            Michelle Obama
           </a>
           , along with
           <a href="/wiki/Family_of_Barack_Obama" title="Family of Barack Obama">
            Malia Obama and Sasha Obama
           </a>
           , participate in
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_Arrival_Ceremony" title="State Arrival Ceremony">
            State Arrival Ceremony
           </a>
           at
           <a href="/wiki/Kotoka_International_Airport" title="Kotoka International Airport">
            Kotoka International Airport
           </a>
           .
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">
        <div style="width: 155px">
         <div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;">
          <div style="margin:47px auto;">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_diplomatic_missions_of_Ghana_(3).PNG">
            <img alt="" data-file-height="628" data-file-width="1357" height="56" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Map_of_diplomatic_missions_of_Ghana_%283%29.PNG/120px-Map_of_diplomatic_missions_of_Ghana_%283%29.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Map_of_diplomatic_missions_of_Ghana_%283%29.PNG/180px-Map_of_diplomatic_missions_of_Ghana_%283%29.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Map_of_diplomatic_missions_of_Ghana_%283%29.PNG/240px-Map_of_diplomatic_missions_of_Ghana_%283%29.PNG 2x" width="120"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="gallerytext">
          <p>
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diplomatic_missions_of_Ghana" title="Diplomatic missions of Ghana">
            Diplomatic missions of Ghana
           </a>
           .
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Law_enforcement_and_police">
        Law enforcement and police
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Law enforcement and police">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Ghana" title="Law enforcement in Ghana">
        Law enforcement in Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:762px;max-width:762px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:297px;max-width:297px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ghana_Police_Service_Motorbikes.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="214" data-file-width="413" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Ghana_Police_Service_Motorbikes.jpg/295px-Ghana_Police_Service_Motorbikes.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b5/Ghana_Police_Service_Motorbikes.jpg 1.5x" width="295"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a href="/wiki/Police_motorcycle" title="Police motorcycle">
           Police Motorcycle
          </a>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Highway_Patrol" title="Highway Patrol">
           Highway Patrol
          </a>
          Unit of the
          <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Police_Service" title="Ghana Police Service">
           Ghana Police Service
          </a>
          .
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:207px;max-width:207px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ghana_Police_Service_Boat_P-1_%26_P-2_(Marine_Police_Unit).jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Ghana_Police_Service_Boat_P-1_%26_P-2_%28Marine_Police_Unit%29.jpg/205px-Ghana_Police_Service_Boat_P-1_%26_P-2_%28Marine_Police_Unit%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Ghana_Police_Service_Boat_P-1_%26_P-2_%28Marine_Police_Unit%29.jpg/308px-Ghana_Police_Service_Boat_P-1_%26_P-2_%28Marine_Police_Unit%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Ghana_Police_Service_Boat_P-1_%26_P-2_%28Marine_Police_Unit%29.jpg/410px-Ghana_Police_Service_Boat_P-1_%26_P-2_%28Marine_Police_Unit%29.jpg 2x" width="205"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a href="/wiki/Water_police" title="Water police">
           Water Police
          </a>
          Unit of the
          <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Police_Service" title="Ghana Police Service">
           Ghana Police Service
          </a>
          .
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:252px;max-width:252px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ghana_Police_Service_Mowag_Piranha.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="254" data-file-width="415" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Ghana_Police_Service_Mowag_Piranha.jpg/250px-Ghana_Police_Service_Mowag_Piranha.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Ghana_Police_Service_Mowag_Piranha.jpg/375px-Ghana_Police_Service_Mowag_Piranha.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/26/Ghana_Police_Service_Mowag_Piranha.jpg 2x" width="250"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Militarized_police" title="Militarized police">
           Militarized Police
          </a>
          Unit of the
          <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Police_Service" title="Ghana Police Service">
           Ghana Police Service
          </a>
          in
          <a href="/wiki/Mowag_Piranha" title="Mowag Piranha">
           Mowag Piranhas
          </a>
          and
          <a href="/wiki/Armoured_fighting_vehicle" title="Armoured fighting vehicle">
           armoured fighting vehicles
          </a>
          .
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Police_Service" title="Ghana Police Service">
        Ghana Police Service
       </a>
       (GPS) and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Criminal_Investigation_Department" title="Criminal Investigation Department">
        Criminal Investigation Department
       </a>
       (CID) are the main law enforcement agencies of the Republic of Ghana, and are responsible for the detection of crime, maintenance of law and order and the maintenance of internal peace and security.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MINT_71-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MINT-71">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Ghana Police Service has eleven specialised police units including a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Militarized_police" title="Militarized police">
        Militarized Police
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Rapid_deployment_force" title="Rapid deployment force">
        Rapid deployment force
       </a>
       (RDF) and
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Police_Service#Marine_Police_Unit" title="Ghana Police Service">
        Marine Police
       </a>
       Unit (MPU).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNIT_72-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-UNIT-72">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-POLICE_73-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-POLICE-73">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Ghana Police Service operates in 12 divisions: ten covering the ten regions of Ghana, one assigned specifically to the seaport and industrial hub of
       <a href="/wiki/Tema" title="Tema">
        Tema
       </a>
       , and the twelfth being the Railways, Ports and Harbours Division.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-POLICE_73-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-POLICE-73">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Ghana Police Service's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maritime_police" title="Maritime police">
        Marine Police
       </a>
       Unit and Division handles issues that arise from the country's offshore
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oil_and_gas_industry" title="Oil and gas industry">
        oil and gas industry
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-POLICE_73-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-POLICE-73">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Prisons_Service" title="Ghana Prisons Service">
        Ghana Prisons Service
       </a>
       and the sub-division
       <a href="/wiki/Borstal_Institute_for_Juveniles" title="Borstal Institute for Juveniles">
        Borstal Institute for Juveniles
       </a>
       administers
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Incarceration" title="Incarceration">
        incarceration
       </a>
       in Ghana.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_Prisons_Service_General_Information_74-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_Prisons_Service_General_Information-74">
         [74]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ghana retains and exercises the death penalty for treason, corruption, robbery, piracy, drug trafficking, rape, and homicide.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_–_Death_Penalty_75-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_–_Death_Penalty-75">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Criminal_Code_and_Courts_76-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Criminal_Code_and_Courts-76">
         [76]
        </a>
       </sup>
       27 convicts (all men) were sentenced to death in Ghana in 2012 and the Ghana Prisons Service statistics of the total number of convicts sentenced to death in Ghana as at December 2012 was 162 men and 4 women,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_–_Death_Penalty_75-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_–_Death_Penalty-75">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with a total prison inmate population of 13,983 convicts as at 22 July 2013.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_Prisons_Service_Inmate_Statistics_77-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_Prisons_Service_Inmate_Statistics-77">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
       "The new sustainable development goals adopted by the United Nations call for the international community to come together to promote the rule of law; support equal access to justice for all; reduce corruption; and develop effective, accountable, and transparent institutions at all levels."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DIPNote:_Promoting_Peace,_Justice,_and_Strong_Institutions_in_the_Great_Lakes_78-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-DIPNote:_Promoting_Peace,_Justice,_and_Strong_Institutions_in_the_Great_Lakes-78">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Ghanaian_Drug_War_and_The_Narcotic_Control_Board">
        Ghanaian Drug War and The Narcotic Control Board
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Ghanaian Drug War and The Narcotic Control Board">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Drugtrade.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Drugtrade.png/220px-Drugtrade.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Drugtrade.png/330px-Drugtrade.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Drugtrade.png/440px-Drugtrade.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Drugtrade.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Ghana is among the sovereign states of West Africa used by
         <a href="/wiki/Drug_cartel" title="Drug cartel">
          drug cartels
         </a>
         and drug traffickers (shown in orange).
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Ghana is used as a key
       <a href="/wiki/Narcotic" title="Narcotic">
        narcotics
       </a>
       industry
       <a href="/wiki/Transshipment" title="Transshipment">
        transshipment
       </a>
       point by traffickers, usually from South America as well as some from other African nations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_hit_by_illegal_drug_trade_79-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_hit_by_illegal_drug_trade-79">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       "West Africa is completely weak in terms of border control and the big drug cartels from Colombia and Latin America have chosen Africa as a way to reach Europe."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DW_Made_for_minds:_Illegal_drug_use_on_the_rise_in_Africa_80-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-DW_Made_for_minds:_Illegal_drug_use_on_the_rise_in_Africa-80">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       There is not a wide or popular knowledge about the narcotics industry and intercepted narcotics within Ghana itself, due to the industry's operations and involvement in the
       <a href="/wiki/Black_market" title="Black market">
        underground economy
       </a>
       . The social context within which
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Narcotic_trafficking" title="Narcotic trafficking">
        narcotic trafficking
       </a>
       , storage, transportation, and repacking systems exist in Ghana and the state's location along the
       <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Guinea" title="Gulf of Guinea">
        Gulf of Guinea
       </a>
       within the Atlantic Ocean – only a few degrees north of the
       <a href="/wiki/Equator" title="Equator">
        Equator
       </a>
       – makes Ghana an attractive country for the narcotics business.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_hit_by_illegal_drug_trade_79-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_hit_by_illegal_drug_trade-79">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_could_be_taken_over_by_drug_barons_if_81-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_could_be_taken_over_by_drug_barons_if-81">
         [81]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Narcotics_Control_Board_(Ghana)" title="Narcotics Control Board (Ghana)">
        Narcotic Control Board
       </a>
       (NACOB), in collaboration with an internal counterpart, has impounded
       <a href="/wiki/Container_ship" title="Container ship">
        container ships
       </a>
       at the Sekondi Naval Base within the
       <a href="/wiki/Takoradi_Harbour" title="Takoradi Harbour">
        Takoradi Harbour
       </a>
       . These ships were carrying thousands of kilograms of cocaine, with a street value running into billions of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ghana_cedi" title="Ghana cedi">
        Ghana cedis
       </a>
       . However, drug seizures saw a decline in 2011.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_hit_by_illegal_drug_trade_79-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_hit_by_illegal_drug_trade-79">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_could_be_taken_over_by_drug_barons_if_81-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_could_be_taken_over_by_drug_barons_if-81">
         [81]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Drug_cartel" title="Drug cartel">
        Drug cartels
       </a>
       are using new methods in narcotics production and narcotics
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Exportation" title="Exportation">
        exportation
       </a>
       , to avoid Ghanaian security agencies.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_hit_by_illegal_drug_trade_79-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_hit_by_illegal_drug_trade-79">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_could_be_taken_over_by_drug_barons_if_81-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_could_be_taken_over_by_drug_barons_if-81">
         [81]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Underdeveloped institutions, porous open borders, and the existence of established
       <a href="/wiki/Smuggling" title="Smuggling">
        smuggling
       </a>
       organisations contribute to Ghana's position in the narcotics industry.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_hit_by_illegal_drug_trade_79-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_hit_by_illegal_drug_trade-79">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_could_be_taken_over_by_drug_barons_if_81-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_could_be_taken_over_by_drug_barons_if-81">
         [81]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/John_Atta_Mills" title="John Atta Mills">
        John Atta Mills
       </a>
       , president between 2009 and 2012, initiated ongoing efforts to reduce the role of airports in Ghana's drug trade.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_hit_by_illegal_drug_trade_79-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_hit_by_illegal_drug_trade-79">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Military">
        Military
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Military">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Armed_Forces" title="Ghana Armed Forces">
        Ghana Armed Forces
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:739px;max-width:739px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:294px;max-width:294px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ghanaian_air_force_special_forces_team.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="2111" data-file-width="3999" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Ghanaian_air_force_special_forces_team.jpg/292px-Ghanaian_air_force_special_forces_team.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Ghanaian_air_force_special_forces_team.jpg/438px-Ghanaian_air_force_special_forces_team.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Ghanaian_air_force_special_forces_team.jpg/584px-Ghanaian_air_force_special_forces_team.jpg 2x" width="292"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Air_Force" title="Ghana Air Force">
           Ghana Air Force
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special_forces" title="Special forces">
           Special Forces
          </a>
          Elite
          <a href="/wiki/Light_infantry" title="Light infantry">
           Light infantry
          </a>
          clears an area on a flight line before takeoff on
          <a href="/wiki/Mil_Mi-17" title="Mil Mi-17">
           Mil Mi-17
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Military_helicopter#Transport_helicopters" title="Military helicopter">
           Military Transport Helicopter
          </a>
          .
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:207px;max-width:207px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ghana_Air_Force_Harbin_Z9EH.JPG">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="2736" data-file-width="3648" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Ghana_Air_Force_Harbin_Z9EH.JPG/205px-Ghana_Air_Force_Harbin_Z9EH.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Ghana_Air_Force_Harbin_Z9EH.JPG/308px-Ghana_Air_Force_Harbin_Z9EH.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Ghana_Air_Force_Harbin_Z9EH.JPG/410px-Ghana_Air_Force_Harbin_Z9EH.JPG 2x" width="205"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Air_Force" title="Ghana Air Force">
           Ghana Air Force
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Commando" title="Commando">
           Commando
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Harbin_Z-9" title="Harbin Z-9">
           Harbin Z-9
          </a>
          EH Medium Multi-Purpose
          <a href="/wiki/Utility_helicopter" title="Utility helicopter">
           Military Utility Helicopter
          </a>
          .
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:232px;max-width:232px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ghana_Airforce_Reccep_Tayyip_Erdogan_Honor_Guard_at_Flagstaff_House.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="3648" data-file-width="5472" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Ghana_Airforce_Reccep_Tayyip_Erdogan_Honor_Guard_at_Flagstaff_House.jpg/230px-Ghana_Airforce_Reccep_Tayyip_Erdogan_Honor_Guard_at_Flagstaff_House.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Ghana_Airforce_Reccep_Tayyip_Erdogan_Honor_Guard_at_Flagstaff_House.jpg/345px-Ghana_Airforce_Reccep_Tayyip_Erdogan_Honor_Guard_at_Flagstaff_House.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Ghana_Airforce_Reccep_Tayyip_Erdogan_Honor_Guard_at_Flagstaff_House.jpg/460px-Ghana_Airforce_Reccep_Tayyip_Erdogan_Honor_Guard_at_Flagstaff_House.jpg 2x" width="230"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_President" title="Turkish President">
           Turkish President
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan" title="Recep Tayyip Erdoğan">
           Recep Tayyip Erdoğan
          </a>
          inspects
          <a href="/wiki/Guard_of_honour" title="Guard of honour">
           Honor Guards
          </a>
          mounted by the
          <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Air_Force" title="Ghana Air Force">
           Ghana Air Force
          </a>
          at the
          <a href="/wiki/Flagstaff_House" title="Flagstaff House">
           Flagstaff House
          </a>
          the Presidential Palace of Ghana in
          <a href="/wiki/Greater_Accra_Region" title="Greater Accra Region">
           Greater Accra
          </a>
          on 1 March 2016.
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 1957, the Ghana Armed Forces (GAF) consisted of its headquarters, support services, three battalions of infantry and a reconnaissance squadron with armoured vehicles.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Canada's_Military_Assistance_82-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Canada's_Military_Assistance-82">
         [82]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ghanaian Prime Minister and President Kwame Nkrumah aimed at rapidly expanding the GAF to support the
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_of_Africa" title="United States of Africa">
        United States of Africa
       </a>
       ambitions. Thus in 1961, 4th and 5th Battalions were established, and in 1964 6th Battalion was established, from a
       <a href="/wiki/Paratrooper" title="Paratrooper">
        parachute
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Airborne_forces" title="Airborne forces">
        airborne unit
       </a>
       originally raised in 1963.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
        <a href="#cite_note-83">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Today, Ghana is a
       <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">
        regional power
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Regional_hegemony" title="Regional hegemony">
        regional hegemon
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-South_America_and_West_Africa_16-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-South_America_and_West_Africa-16">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In his book
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Shake_Hands_with_the_Devil_(book)" title="Shake Hands with the Devil (book)">
         Shake Hands with the Devil
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canadian_Forces" title="Canadian Forces">
        Canadian Forces
       </a>
       commander
       <a href="/wiki/Rom%C3%A9o_Dallaire" title="Roméo Dallaire">
        Roméo Dallaire
       </a>
       highly rated the GAF soldiers and
       <a href="/wiki/Military_personnel" title="Military personnel">
        military personnel
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Canada's_Military_Assistance_82-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Canada's_Military_Assistance-82">
         [82]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Military_operation" title="Military operation">
        military operations
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Military_doctrine" title="Military doctrine">
        military doctrine
       </a>
       of the GAF are conceptualised on the
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Ghana" title="Constitution of Ghana">
        Constitution of Ghana
       </a>
       , Ghana's Law on
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Armed_Force" title="Armed Force">
        Armed Force
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_Strategy" title="Military Strategy">
        Military Strategy
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Kofi_Annan_International_Peacekeeping_Training_Centre" title="Kofi Annan International Peacekeeping Training Centre">
        Kofi Annan International Peacekeeping Training Centre
       </a>
       (KAIPTC) agreements to which GAF is attestator.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Defence_84-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Defence-84">
         [84]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana's_Regional_Security_Policy_85-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana's_Regional_Security_Policy-85">
         [85]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KAIPTC_86-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-KAIPTC-86">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       GAF military operations are executed under the auspices and imperium of the
       <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(Ghana)" title="Ministry of Defence (Ghana)">
        Ministry of Defense
       </a>
       (MoD)
       <a href="/wiki/Minister_for_Defence_(Ghana)" title="Minister for Defence (Ghana)">
        Minister for Defence
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Defence_84-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Defence-84">
         [84]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vision_&amp;_Mission_87-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Vision_&amp;_Mission-87">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Weapons_of_mass_destruction_and_tactical_nuclear_weapons">
        Weapons of mass destruction and tactical nuclear weapons
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Weapons of mass destruction and tactical nuclear weapons">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Border_Guard_Unit" title="Border Guard Unit">
        Border Guard Unit
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Bureau_of_National_Investigations" title="Bureau of National Investigations">
        Bureau of National Investigations
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:173px;max-width:173px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:171px;max-width:171px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CASA_C295_Ghana_Air_Force.JPG">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="2736" data-file-width="3648" height="127" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/CASA_C295_Ghana_Air_Force.JPG/169px-CASA_C295_Ghana_Air_Force.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/CASA_C295_Ghana_Air_Force.JPG/254px-CASA_C295_Ghana_Air_Force.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/CASA_C295_Ghana_Air_Force.JPG/338px-CASA_C295_Ghana_Air_Force.JPG 2x" width="169"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Air_Force" title="Ghana Air Force">
           Ghana Air Force
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Paratrooper" title="Paratrooper">
           Paratrooper
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Rapid_deployment_force" title="Rapid deployment force">
           Rapid Deployment
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Airborne_forces" title="Airborne forces">
           Airborne Forces
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/EADS_CASA_C-295" title="EADS CASA C-295">
           CASA C-295
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Military_transport_aircraft" title="Military transport aircraft">
           Military Transport Aircraft
          </a>
          at the
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Takoradi" title="Takoradi">
           Takoradi
          </a>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_airbase" title="Military airbase">
           Military Airbase
          </a>
          .
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Ghana adheres to a common credo ethos of the
       <a href="/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency" title="International Atomic Energy Agency">
        IAEA
       </a>
       . The Ghana atomic agency currently holds no intent for the production of Weapons of Mass Destruction. Although Ghana has no military use of its nuclear assets, options for scientific research into modern nuclear propelled submarine and aircraft carrier ships, design and development of same technology and its transfer from partner OECD for its military use are imminent. Ghana currently has a prototype nuclear power plant and is open to nuclear investors for the development of high tech nuclear power plants for a West Africa Electric Power Pool project. Although fragments of anti-nuclear power groups might critique nuclear proliferation, Ghana remains a safe candidate nation in sub-Saharan Africa to pioneer it. It is claimed that Ghana maintains several
       <a href="/wiki/Research_reactor" title="Research reactor">
        research reactors
       </a>
       ready for the processing of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Highly_enriched_uranium" title="Highly enriched uranium">
        highly enriched uranium
       </a>
       (HEU)).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Research_Reactors_88-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Research_Reactors-88">
         [88]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In an article titled "We're still vulnerable", renowned
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Political_scientist" title="Political scientist">
        political scientist
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bioterrorism" title="Bioterrorism">
        bioterrorism
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapon" title="Nuclear weapon">
        nuclear weapons
       </a>
       specialist
       <a href="/wiki/Graham_T._Allison" title="Graham T. Allison">
        Graham T. Allison
       </a>
       for the
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Boston_Globe" title="Boston Globe">
         Boston Globe
        </a>
       </i>
       , speculates that Ghana's orphaned
       <a href="/wiki/Research_reactor" title="Research reactor">
        research reactor
       </a>
       (at
       <a href="/wiki/Kwabenya" title="Kwabenya">
        Kwabenya
       </a>
       , Greater Accra) contains
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Highly_enriched_uranium" title="Highly enriched uranium">
        highly enriched uranium
       </a>
       (HEU) sufficient to make a number of
       <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapon" title="Nuclear weapon">
        nuclear weapons
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-We're_still_vulnerable_89-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-We're_still_vulnerable-89">
         [89]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">
        Administrative divisions
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Administrative divisions">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Ghana" title="Administrative divisions of Ghana">
        Administrative divisions of Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <center>
       <p>
        Ghana is divided into 10
        <a href="/wiki/Administrative_division" title="Administrative division">
         administrative
        </a>
        regions, sub-divided into 275 districts:
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
         <a href="#cite_note-90">
          [90]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">
         <a href="#cite_note-91">
          [91]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92">
         <a href="#cite_note-92">
          [92]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </p>
       <div style="overflow:auto;">
        <table class="wikitable">
         <tr>
          <th>

           </sup>

          </td>

            Kumasi
           </a>
          </td>

      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">
        Human rights
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Human rights">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Ghana" title="LGBT rights in Ghana">
        LGBT rights in Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Homosexuality" title="Homosexuality">
        Homosexual acts
       </a>
       are prohibited by law in Ghana.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
        <a href="#cite_note-93">
         [93]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Sometimes old women are accused of
       <a href="/wiki/Witchcraft" title="Witchcraft">
        witchcraft
       </a>
       , particularly in rural Ghana. Issues of witchcraft mainly remain as speculations based on superstitions within families. In some parts of northern Ghana, there exists what is called a
       <a href="/wiki/Witch_camp" title="Witch camp">
        witch camp
       </a>
       . This is said to house a total of around 1,000 people accused of witchcraft.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Camps_94-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Camps-94">
         [94]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Ghanaian government has announced that it intends to close the camps.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Camps_94-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Camps-94">
         [94]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">
        Transportation
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Transportation">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Ghana" title="Transport in Ghana">
        Transport in Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Transport and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Modes_of_transport" title="Modes of transport">
        modes of transport
       </a>
       in Ghana is accomplished by
       <a href="/wiki/Road_transport" title="Road transport">
        road transport
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Public_transport_bus_service" title="Public transport bus service">
        bus-based mass transit
       </a>
       system),
       <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport" title="Rail transport">
        railway
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Air_transport" title="Air transport">
        air transport
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Civil_aviation" title="Civil aviation">
        civil aviation
       </a>
       ) and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Water_transport" title="Water transport">
        water transport
       </a>
       (ferry).
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">
        Economy
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Economy">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Ghana" title="Economy of Ghana">
        Economy of Ghana
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/New_media_in_Ghana" title="New media in Ghana">
        New media in Ghana
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Manufacturing_in_Ghana#Automobile_manufacturing" title="Manufacturing in Ghana">
        Automobile manufacturing in Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Key_sectors">
        Key sectors
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Key sectors">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:254px;max-width:254px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:252px;max-width:252px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ghana_Vision_2020.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="273" data-file-width="270" height="253" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Ghana_Vision_2020.jpg/250px-Ghana_Vision_2020.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/33/Ghana_Vision_2020.jpg 1.5x" width="250"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left;background-color:transparent">
         Ghana Vision 2020 logo
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Accra_Market_(3106526668).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="701" data-file-width="960" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Accra_Market_%283106526668%29.jpg/220px-Accra_Market_%283106526668%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Accra_Market_%283106526668%29.jpg/330px-Accra_Market_%283106526668%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Accra_Market_%283106526668%29.jpg/440px-Accra_Market_%283106526668%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Accra_Market_(3106526668).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Accra market scene
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Ghana is an average
       <a href="/wiki/Natural_resource" title="Natural resource">
        natural resource
       </a>
       enriched country possessing
       <a href="/wiki/Industrial_mineral" title="Industrial mineral">
        industrial minerals
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Hydrocarbon" title="Hydrocarbon">
        hydrocarbons
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Precious_metal" title="Precious metal">
        precious metals
       </a>
       . It is an emerging designated
       <a href="/wiki/Digital_economy" title="Digital economy">
        digital economy
       </a>
       with
       <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">
        mixed economy
       </a>
       hybridisation and an
       <a href="/wiki/Emerging_markets" title="Emerging markets">
        emerging market
       </a>
       with 8.7% GDP growth in 2012. It has an
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Economic_plan" title="Economic plan">
        economic plan
       </a>
       target known as the "Ghana Vision 2020". This plan envisions Ghana as the first African country to become a
       <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">
        developed country
       </a>
       between 2020 and 2029 and a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Newly_industrialised_country" title="Newly industrialised country">
        newly industrialised country
       </a>
       between 2030 and 2039.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify">
          <span title='industrialization has come before developed status for every other country; currently, no "newly industrialized country" is considered developed (August 2017)'>
           clarification needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       This excludes fellow
       <a href="/wiki/Group_of_24" title="Group of 24">
        Group of 24
       </a>
       member and
       <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa">
        Sub-Saharan African
       </a>
       country South Africa, which is a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Newly_industrialised_country" title="Newly industrialised country">
        newly industrialised country
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">
        <a href="#cite_note-95">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ghana's economy also has ties to the
       <a href="/wiki/Renminbi" title="Renminbi">
        Chinese yuan renminbi
       </a>
       along with Ghana's vast gold reserves. In 2013, the
       <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_Ghana" title="Bank of Ghana">
        Bank of Ghana
       </a>
       began circulating the renminbi throughout Ghanaian state-owned banks and to the Ghana public as
       <a href="/wiki/Hard_currency" title="Hard currency">
        hard currency
       </a>
       along with the national
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ghana_cedi" title="Ghana cedi">
        Ghana cedi
       </a>
       for second national trade currency.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BoG_introduce_Chinese_Yuan_onto_the_FX_market_96-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-BoG_introduce_Chinese_Yuan_onto_the_FX_market-96">
         [96]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The state-owned
       <a href="/wiki/Volta_River_Authority" title="Volta River Authority">
        Volta River Authority
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_National_Petroleum_Corporation" title="Ghana National Petroleum Corporation">
        Ghana National Petroleum Corporation
       </a>
       are the two major electricity producers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_–_Gross_Domestic_Product_97-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_–_Gross_Domestic_Product-97">
         [97]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Akosombo_Dam" title="Akosombo Dam">
        Akosombo Dam
       </a>
       , built on the Volta River in 1965, along with
       <a href="/wiki/Bui_Dam" title="Bui Dam">
        Bui Dam
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kpong_Dam" title="Kpong Dam">
        Kpong Dam
       </a>
       , and several other
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hydroelectric_dam" title="Hydroelectric dam">
        hydroelectric dams
       </a>
       provide hydropower.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
        <a href="#cite_note-98">
         [98]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-New_fuel_for_faster_development_99-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-New_fuel_for_faster_development-99">
         [99]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In addition, the Government of Ghana has sought to
       <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_energy_in_Ghana" title="Nuclear energy in Ghana">
        build the second nuclear power plant in Africa
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Stock_Exchange" title="Ghana Stock Exchange">
        Ghana Stock Exchange
       </a>
       is the 5th largest on continental Africa and 3rd largest in sub-saharan Africa with a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Market_capitalisation" title="Market capitalisation">
        market capitalisation
       </a>
       of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ghana_Cedi" title="Ghana Cedi">
        GH¢
       </a>
       57.2 billion or
       <a href="/wiki/Renminbi" title="Renminbi">
        CN¥
       </a>
       180.4 billion in 2012 with the South Africa
       <a href="/wiki/JSE_Limited" title="JSE Limited">
        JSE Limited
       </a>
       as first.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
        <a href="#cite_note-100">
         [100]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Stock_Exchange" title="Ghana Stock Exchange">
        Ghana Stock Exchange
       </a>
       (GSE) was the 2nd best performing
       <a href="/wiki/Stock_exchange" title="Stock exchange">
        stock exchange
       </a>
       in sub-saharan Africa in 2013.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
        <a href="#cite_note-101">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Ghana also produces high-quality
       <a href="/wiki/Cocoa_bean" title="Cocoa bean">
        cocoa
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_Entering_A_Sweet,_Golden_Era_102-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_Entering_A_Sweet,_Golden_Era-102">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
       is the 2nd largest producer of cocoa globally,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_Entering_A_Sweet,_Golden_Era_102-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_Entering_A_Sweet,_Golden_Era-102">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">
        <a href="#cite_note-103">
         [103]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and is projected to become the world's largest producer of cocoa in 2015.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_will_reclaim_top_spot_in_cocoa_production_104-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_will_reclaim_top_spot_in_cocoa_production-104">
         [104]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Ghana is classified as a middle income country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMF_7-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-IMF-7">
         [7]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105">
        <a href="#cite_note-105">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_industry" title="Tertiary sector of industry">
        Services
       </a>
       account for 50% of GDP, followed by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Secondary_sector_of_industry" title="Secondary sector of industry">
        manufacturing
       </a>
       (24.1%),
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Primary_sector_of_industry" title="Primary sector of industry">
        extractive industries
       </a>
       (5%), and taxes (20.9%).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_–_Gross_Domestic_Product_97-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_–_Gross_Domestic_Product-97">
         [97]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Manufacturing">
        Manufacturing
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Manufacturing">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The Ghana economy is an emerging digital-based mixed economy hybrid similarly to that of
       <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">
        Taiwan
       </a>
       with an increasing primary manufacturing and exportation of digital technology goods along with assembling and exporting automobiles and ships, diverse resource rich exportation of
       <a href="/wiki/Industrial_mineral" title="Industrial mineral">
        industrial minerals
       </a>
       , agricultural products primarily cocoa, petroleum and natural gas,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana's_Jubilee_oil_field_nears_output_plateau_-operator_106-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana's_Jubilee_oil_field_nears_output_plateau_-operator-106">
         [106]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Industry" title="Industry">
        industries
       </a>
       such as
       <a href="/wiki/Information_and_communications_technology" title="Information and communications technology">
        information and communications technology
       </a>
       primarily via Ghana's state digital technology corporation
       <a href="/wiki/Rlg_Communications" title="Rlg Communications">
        Rlg Communications
       </a>
       which manufactures
       <a href="/wiki/Tablet_computer" title="Tablet computer">
        tablet computers
       </a>
       with
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Smart_phone" title="Smart phone">
        smart phones
       </a>
       and various
       <a href="/wiki/Consumer_electronics" title="Consumer electronics">
        consumer electronics
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_–_Gross_Domestic_Product_97-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_–_Gross_Domestic_Product-97">
         [97]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Top_5_Countries_for_ICT_in_Africa_107-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-The_Top_5_Countries_for_ICT_in_Africa-107">
         [107]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Petroleum_and_natural_gas_production">
        Petroleum and natural gas production
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Petroleum and natural gas production">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Ghana produces and exports an abundance of
       <a href="/wiki/Hydrocarbon" title="Hydrocarbon">
        hydrocarbons
       </a>
       such as
       <a href="/wiki/Sweet_crude_oil" title="Sweet crude oil">
        sweet crude oil
       </a>
       and natural gas.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Five_Countries_to_Watch_108-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Five_Countries_to_Watch-108">
         [108]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
        <a href="#cite_note-109">
         [109]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The 100% state-owned
       <a href="/wiki/Filling_station" title="Filling station">
        filling station
       </a>
       company of Ghana,
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Oil_Company" title="Ghana Oil Company">
        Ghana Oil Company
       </a>
       (GOIL) is the number 1 petroleum and gas filling station of Ghana and the 100% state-owned state oil company
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_National_Petroleum_Corporation" title="Ghana National Petroleum Corporation">
        Ghana National Petroleum Corporation
       </a>
       (GNPC) oversees
       <a href="/wiki/Hydrocarbon_exploration" title="Hydrocarbon exploration">
        hydrocarbon exploration
       </a>
       and production of Ghana's entire petroleum and natural gas reserves. Ghana aims to further increase output of oil to 2.2 million barrels (350,000 m
       <sup>
        3
       </sup>
       ) per day and gas to 34,000,000 cubic metres (1.2
       <span style="margin-left:0.2em">
        ×
        <span style="margin-left:0.1em">
         10
        </span>
       </span>
       <s style="display:none">
        ^
       </s>
       <sup>
        9
       </sup>
       cu ft) per day.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cs2_110-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-cs2-110">
         [110]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Ghana's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jubilee_oil_field" title="Jubilee oil field">
        Jubilee Oilfield
       </a>
       which contains up to 3 billion barrels (480,000,000 m
       <sup>
        3
       </sup>
       ) of
       <a href="/wiki/Sweet_crude_oil" title="Sweet crude oil">
        sweet crude oil
       </a>
       was discovered in 2007, among the many other offshore and inland oilfields in Ghana.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
        <a href="#cite_note-111">
         [111]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ghana is believed to have up to 5 billion barrels (790,000,000 m
       <sup>
        3
       </sup>
       ) to 7 billion barrels (1.1
       <span style="margin:0 .15em 0 .25em">
        ×
       </span>
       10
       <sup>
        9
       </sup>
       m
       <sup>
        3
       </sup>
       ) of petroleum in reserves,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112">
