        <a href="#cite_note-112">
         [112]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which is the fifth largest in Africa and the 21st to 25th
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_proven_oil_reserves" title="List of countries by proven oil reserves">
        largest proven reserves
       </a>
       in the world. It also has up to 1.7
       <span style="margin:0 .15em 0 .25em">
        ×
       </span>
       10
       <sup>
        11
       </sup>
       cubic metres (6
       <span style="margin-left:0.2em">
        ×
        <span style="margin-left:0.1em">
         10
        </span>
       </span>
       <s style="display:none">
        ^
       </s>
       <sup>
        12
       </sup>
       cu ft) of natural gas in reserves,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atuabo_gas_project_to_propel_more_growth_113-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Atuabo_gas_project_to_propel_more_growth-113">
         [113]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which is the sixth largest in Africa and the 49th
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_gas_proven_reserves" title="List of countries by natural gas proven reserves">
        largest natural gas proven reserves
       </a>
       in the world.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oil_and_gas_exploration" title="Oil and gas exploration">
        Oil and gas exploration
       </a>
       off Ghana's eastern coast on the Gulf of Guinea is ongoing, and the amount of both crude oil and natural gas continues to increase. The
       <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ghana" title="Government of Ghana">
        Government of Ghana
       </a>
       has drawn up plans to
       <a href="/wiki/Nationalization" title="Nationalization">
        nationalise
       </a>
       Ghana's entire petroleum and natural gas reserves to increase government revenue.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
        <a href="#cite_note-114">
         [114]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Industrial_minerals_mining">
        Industrial minerals mining
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Industrial minerals mining">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Known for its
       <a href="/wiki/Industrial_mineral" title="Industrial mineral">
        industrial minerals
       </a>
       , Ghana is the world's 7th largest producer of gold; producing over 102
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metric_ton" title="Metric ton">
        metric tons
       </a>
       of gold and the 10th
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_gold_production" title="List of countries by gold production">
        largest producer
       </a>
       of gold in the world in 2012; producing 89 metric tons of gold. Ghana is the 2nd largest producer of gold on the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_continent" title="African continent">
        Africa continent
       </a>
       behind South Africa.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
        <a href="#cite_note-115">
         [115]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ghana has the 9th largest reserves of diamonds in the world, and is the 9th largest producer of diamonds in the world with
       <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">
        Brazil
       </a>
       having the 10th largest reserves of diamonds in the world and being the 10th largest producer of diamonds in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
        <a href="#cite_note-116">
         [116]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Industrial_mineral" title="Industrial mineral">
        Industrial minerals
       </a>
       and exports from South Ghana are gold, silver, timber, diamonds,
       <a href="/wiki/Bauxite" title="Bauxite">
        bauxite
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Manganese" title="Manganese">
        manganese
       </a>
       ; South Ghana also has a great deposit of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Barite" title="Barite">
        barites
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Basalt" title="Basalt">
        basalts
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Clay_minerals" title="Clay minerals">
        clays
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Dolomite" title="Dolomite">
        dolomites
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Feldspar" title="Feldspar">
        feldspars
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Granite" title="Granite">
        granites
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Gravel" title="Gravel">
        gravels
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Gypsum" title="Gypsum">
        gypsums
       </a>
       ; iron ores;
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kaolin" title="Kaolin">
        kaolins
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Laterite" title="Laterite">
        laterites
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Limestone" title="Limestone">
        limestones
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Magnesite" title="Magnesite">
        magnesites
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Marble" title="Marble">
        marbles
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Mica" title="Mica">
        micas
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Phosphate" title="Phosphate">
        phosphates
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Phosphorus" title="Phosphorus">
        phosphorus
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Rock_(geology)" title="Rock (geology)">
        rocks
       </a>
       ; salts;
       <a href="/wiki/Sand" title="Sand">
        sands
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Sandstone" title="Sandstone">
        sandstones
       </a>
       ; silver;
       <a href="/wiki/Slate" title="Slate">
        slates
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Talc" title="Talc">
        talcs
       </a>
       ; and
       <a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">
        uranium
       </a>
       that are yet to be fully
       <a href="/wiki/Exploitation_of_natural_resources" title="Exploitation of natural resources">
        exploited
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
        <a href="#cite_note-117">
         [117]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Government of Ghana has drawn up plans to
       <a href="/wiki/Nationalization" title="Nationalization">
        nationalise
       </a>
       Ghana's entire mining industry to increase government revenues.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
        <a href="#cite_note-118">
         [118]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
        <a href="#cite_note-119">
         [119]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Real_estate">
        Real estate
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Real estate">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Luxury_Villa_House_(South_Ghana).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2112" data-file-width="2816" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Luxury_Villa_House_%28South_Ghana%29.jpg/220px-Luxury_Villa_House_%28South_Ghana%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Luxury_Villa_House_%28South_Ghana%29.jpg/330px-Luxury_Villa_House_%28South_Ghana%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Luxury_Villa_House_%28South_Ghana%29.jpg/440px-Luxury_Villa_House_%28South_Ghana%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Luxury_Villa_House_(South_Ghana).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A
         <a href="/wiki/Villa" title="Villa">
          villa
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/East_Ridge,_Accra" title="East Ridge, Accra">
          East Ridge
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The real estate and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Housing_market" title="Housing market">
        housing market
       </a>
       of Ghana has become an important and strategic
       <a href="/wiki/Economic_sector" title="Economic sector">
        economic sector
       </a>
       , particularly in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Urban_centre" title="Urban centre">
        urban centres
       </a>
       of south Ghana such as Accra, Kumasi, Sekondi-Takoradi and Tema.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economic_Update_120-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Economic_Update-120">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Real_Estate_Market_in_Ghana_121-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Real_Estate_Market_in_Ghana-121">
         [121]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Property_market_faces_brighter_growth_prospects_122-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Property_market_faces_brighter_growth_prospects-122">
         [122]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Kumasi is growing at a faster rate than Accra, and there is less competition in its real estate market.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economic_Update_120-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Economic_Update-120">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The gross rental
       <a href="/wiki/Income_tax" title="Income tax">
        income tax
       </a>
       of Ghana is withheld at 10%,
       <a href="/wiki/Capital_gain" title="Capital gain">
        capital gains
       </a>
       are taxed at 15% with a 5%
       <a href="/wiki/Gift_tax" title="Gift tax">
        gift tax
       </a>
       imposed on the transfer of properties and Ghana's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Real_estate_market" title="Real estate market">
        real estate market
       </a>
       is divided into 3 areas: public sector real estate development, emerging private sector real estate development, and private individuals.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economic_Update_120-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Economic_Update-120">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Real_Estate_Market_in_Ghana_121-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Real_Estate_Market_in_Ghana-121">
         [121]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The activities of these 3 groups are facilitated by the Ghanaian banks and the primary mortgage market which has demonstrated enormous growth potential.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Real_Estate_Market_in_Ghana_121-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Real_Estate_Market_in_Ghana-121">
         [121]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Recent developments in the Ghanaian economy has given birth to a boom in the construction sector, including the housing and public housing sector generating and injecting billions of dollars annually into the Ghanaian economy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economic_Update_120-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Economic_Update-120">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Real_Estate_Market_in_Ghana_121-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Real_Estate_Market_in_Ghana-121">
         [121]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The real estate market investment perspective and attraction comes from Ghana's tropical location and robust political stability.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economic_Update_120-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-Economic_Update-120">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Real_Estate_Market_in_Ghana_121-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-Real_Estate_Market_in_Ghana-121">
         [121]
        </a>
       </sup>
       An increasing number of the Ghanaian populace are investing in properties and the Ghana government is empowering the
       <a href="/wiki/Private_sector" title="Private sector">
        private sector
       </a>
       in the real estate direction.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economic_Update_120-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-Economic_Update-120">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Real_Estate_Market_in_Ghana_121-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-Real_Estate_Market_in_Ghana-121">
         [121]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Trade_and_exports">
        Trade and exports
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Trade and exports">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2014_Ghana_Products_Export_Treemap.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="520" data-file-width="750" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/2014_Ghana_Products_Export_Treemap.png/220px-2014_Ghana_Products_Export_Treemap.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/2014_Ghana_Products_Export_Treemap.png/330px-2014_Ghana_Products_Export_Treemap.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/2014_Ghana_Products_Export_Treemap.png/440px-2014_Ghana_Products_Export_Treemap.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2014_Ghana_Products_Export_Treemap.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Ghana Export Treemap by Product (2014) from Harvard Atlas of Economic Complexity
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123">
          <a href="#cite_note-123">
           [123]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:319px;max-width:319px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:317px;max-width:317px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tema_Harbour,_Greater_Accra.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="2331" data-file-width="5079" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Tema_Harbour%2C_Greater_Accra.jpg/315px-Tema_Harbour%2C_Greater_Accra.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Tema_Harbour%2C_Greater_Accra.jpg/473px-Tema_Harbour%2C_Greater_Accra.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Tema_Harbour%2C_Greater_Accra.jpg/630px-Tema_Harbour%2C_Greater_Accra.jpg 2x" width="315"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left;background-color:transparent">
         ■
         <i>
          1st image:
         </i>
         <a href="/wiki/Container_ship" title="Container ship">
          Container ships
         </a>
         and
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Merchant_ship" title="Merchant ship">
          Merchant ships
         </a>
         being loaded and unloaded at
         <a href="/wiki/Intermodal_freight_transport" title="Intermodal freight transport">
          Intermodal freight transport
         </a>
         of
         <a href="/wiki/Tema_Harbour" title="Tema Harbour">
          Tema Harbour
         </a>
         .
         <br/>
         ■
         <i>
          2nd image:
         </i>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Takoradi_Harbour" title="Takoradi Harbour">
          Takoradi Harbour
         </a>
         seaport was established in 1928 and is Ghana's main export outlet. Ghana maintains one of the world's fastest growing and expanding
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shipping_industry" title="Shipping industry">
          shipping industry
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In July 2013,
       <a href="/wiki/International_Enterprise_Singapore" title="International Enterprise Singapore">
        International Enterprise Singapore
       </a>
       opened its 38th global office in Accra, to develop trade and investment on logistics,
       <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">
        oil
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">
        gas
       </a>
       , aviation, transportation and consumer sectors.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IE_Singapore_opens_office_in_Ghana_124-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-IE_Singapore_opens_office_in_Ghana-124">
         [124]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Singapore and Ghana also signed four bilateral agreements to promote
       <a href="/wiki/Public_sector" title="Public sector">
        public sector
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Private_sector" title="Private sector">
        private sector
       </a>
       collaboration, as Ghana aims to predominantly shift its economic trade partnership to East Asia and Southeast Asia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IE_Singapore_opens_office_in_Ghana_124-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-IE_Singapore_opens_office_in_Ghana-124">
         [124]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The economic centre is
       <a href="/wiki/International_Enterprise_Singapore" title="International Enterprise Singapore">
        IE Singapore
       </a>
       's second office in Africa, coming six months after opening in Johannesburg, South Africa in January 2013.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IE_Singapore_opens_office_in_Ghana_124-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-IE_Singapore_opens_office_in_Ghana-124">
         [124]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ghana's labour force in 2008 totalled 11.5 million Ghanaian citizens.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-afdb_125-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-afdb-125">
         [125]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126">
        <a href="#cite_note-126">
         [126]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Tema_Harbour" title="Tema Harbour">
        Tema Harbour
       </a>
       is Africa's largest
       <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/manmade" title="wikt:manmade">
        manmade
       </a>
       harbour and
       <a href="/wiki/Takoradi_Harbour" title="Takoradi Harbour">
        Takoradi Harbour
       </a>
       along with Tema harbour in Ghana handles goods and exports for Ghana. They are also traffic junctions where goods are transhipped; the Tema harbour handles the majority of the nation's export cargo and most of the country's chief exports is shipped from Takoradi harbour.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GPHA-Sekond-Takoradi_127-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-GPHA-Sekond-Takoradi-127">
         [127]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GPHA-Tema_128-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-GPHA-Tema-128">
         [128]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Takoradi harbour and Tema harbour are operated by the state-owned
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Ports_and_Harbours_Authority" title="Ghana Ports and Harbours Authority">
        Ghana Ports and Harbours Authority
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GPHA-Sekond-Takoradi_127-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-GPHA-Sekond-Takoradi-127">
         [127]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GPHA-Tema_128-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-GPHA-Tema-128">
         [128]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Electricity_generation_sector">
        Electricity generation sector
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Electricity generation sector">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Electricity_sector_in_Ghana" title="Electricity sector in Ghana">
        Electricity sector in Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Shortages of electricity have led to
       <a href="/wiki/Dumsor" title="Dumsor">
        dumsor
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-germany_129-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-germany-129">
         [129]
        </a>
       </sup>
       (persistent, irregular and unpredictable electric power outages), increasing the interest in renewables.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-graphic1_130-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-graphic1-130">
         [130]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ghana plans to become a major regional exporter of electrical power using oil from the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jubilee_oil_field" title="Jubilee oil field">
        Jubilee oil field
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131">
        <a href="#cite_note-131">
         [131]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economic_transparency">
        Economic transparency
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Economic transparency">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       According to Transparency International's Corruption Perception Index of 2013, out of 177 countries, Ghana ranked 63rd with
       <a href="/wiki/Cuba" title="Cuba">
        Cuba
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">
        Saudi Arabia
       </a>
       . Ghana had a score of 46 on a scale where a 0–9 score means highly corrupt, and a 90–100 score means very clean. This was based on perceived levels of public sector corruption.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132">
        <a href="#cite_note-132">
         [132]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Previously in 2012, the country ranked 64 and scored 45. Thus, Ghana's public sector scored lower in 2013 than in 2012, according to CPI's scores.
      </p>
      <p>
       Local reports have claimed that Ghana loses US$4.5 billion annually from
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nominal_GDP" title="Nominal GDP">
        nominal gross domestic product
       </a>
       (Nominal GDP) growth as a result of economic corruption and economic crime by the incumbent
       <a href="/wiki/National_Democratic_Congress_(Ghana)" title="National Democratic Congress (Ghana)">
        National Democratic Congress
       </a>
       (NDC)
       <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ghana" title="Government of Ghana">
        government of Ghana
       </a>
       led by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/John_Dramani_Mahama" title="John Dramani Mahama">
        John Dramani Mahama
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_Loses_$4b_Annually_To_Corruption_133-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_Loses_$4b_Annually_To_Corruption-133">
         [133]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is also said Ghana has lost an additional US$2.5 billion from
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nominal_GDP" title="Nominal GDP">
        nominal gross domestic product
       </a>
       (Nominal GDP) growth between the months of January 2013 to October 2013 through economic corrupt practices under the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Mahama_government_ministers" title="List of Mahama government ministers">
        Mahama administration
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Impeach_Mahama_134-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Impeach_Mahama-134">
         [134]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The incumbent president is however seen to be fighting corruption by some government members,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135">
        <a href="#cite_note-135">
         [135]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and a fellow politician of an opposition party,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136">
        <a href="#cite_note-136">
         [136]
        </a>
       </sup>
       after ordering investigations into scandals. Nonetheless others believe his actions are not sufficient in some cases.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137">
        <a href="#cite_note-137">
         [137]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       John Addo Kufuor, son of former President
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/John_Agyekum_Kufuor" title="John Agyekum Kufuor">
        John Agyekum Kufuor
       </a>
       , and Kojo Annan, son of former Secretary-General of the United Nations
       <a href="/wiki/Kofi_Annan" title="Kofi Annan">
        Kofi Annan
       </a>
       , have been named in association with the
       <a href="/wiki/Panama_Papers" title="Panama Papers">
        Panama Papers
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">
        <a href="#cite_note-138">
         [138]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">
        Science and technology
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Science and technology">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       Ghana was the first sub-Saharan African country to launch a cellular mobile network (1992). It was one of the first countries in Africa to be connected to the internet and to introduce ADSL broadband services.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghanaweb_139-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghanaweb-139">
         [139]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Space_and_satellite_programmes">
        Space and satellite programmes
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Space and satellite programmes">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Space_Science_and_Technology_Centre" title="Ghana Space Science and Technology Centre">
        Ghana Space Science and Technology Centre
       </a>
       (GSSTC) and Ghana Spacey CpCock (GhsA) oversee the
       <a href="/wiki/Space_exploration" title="Space exploration">
        space exploration
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Space_program" title="Space program">
        space programmes
       </a>
       of Ghana. GSSTC and GhsA worked to have a
       <a href="/wiki/National_security" title="National security">
        national security
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Earth_observation_satellite" title="Earth observation satellite">
        observational satellite
       </a>
       launched into orbit in 2015.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBCSpace_140-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-BBCSpace-140">
         [140]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141">
        <a href="#cite_note-141">
         [141]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The first practical step in its endeavor was a
       <a href="/wiki/CanSat" title="CanSat">
        CanSat
       </a>
       launched on 15 May 2013, a space programme spearheaded by the All Nations University College (ANUC) in Koforidua. The CanSat was deployed 200 metres (660 feet) high from a helium-filled balloon and took some aerial images as well as temperature readings. As its next step in advancing space science and satellite technology in the sub-region, an amateur ground station has been designed and built by the university. It has successfully tracked and communicated with several amateur radio satellites in orbit including the
       <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">
        International Space Station
       </a>
       , receiving
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slow-scan_TV" title="Slow-scan TV">
        slow-scan TV
       </a>
       images on 18 and 20 December 2014. The miniaturized earth observational satellite is to be launched into orbit in 2017.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VOASpace_142-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-VOASpace-142">
         [142]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Ghana's annual space exploration expenditure has been 1% of its gross domestic product (GDP), to support research in science and technology. In 2012 Ghana was elected to chair the
       <a href="/wiki/Commission_on_Science_and_Technology_for_Sustainable_Development_in_the_South" title="Commission on Science and Technology for Sustainable Development in the South">
        Commission on Science and Technology for Sustainable Development in the South
       </a>
       (Comsats); Ghana has a joint effort in
       <a href="/wiki/Space_exploration" title="Space exploration">
        space exploration
       </a>
       with South Africa's
       <a href="/wiki/South_African_National_Space_Agency" title="South African National Space Agency">
        South African National Space Agency
       </a>
       (SANSA).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBCSpace_140-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-BBCSpace-140">
         [140]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cybernetics_and_cyberwarfare">
        Cybernetics and cyberwarfare
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Cybernetics and cyberwarfare">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Sakawa" title="Sakawa">
        Sakawa
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wikimedia_Outreach_in_Ghana_6.jpeg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Wikimedia_Outreach_in_Ghana_6.jpeg/220px-Wikimedia_Outreach_in_Ghana_6.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Wikimedia_Outreach_in_Ghana_6.jpeg/330px-Wikimedia_Outreach_in_Ghana_6.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Wikimedia_Outreach_in_Ghana_6.jpeg/440px-Wikimedia_Outreach_in_Ghana_6.jpeg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Wikimedia_Outreach_in_Ghana_6.jpeg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Ghana" title="Education in Ghana">
          Ghana education system's
         </a>
         implementation of
         <a href="/wiki/Information_and_communications_technology" title="Information and communications technology">
          information and communications technology
         </a>
         at the
         <a href="/wiki/University_of_Ghana" title="University of Ghana">
          University of Ghana
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The use of computer technology for teaching and learning began to receive
       <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ghana" title="Government of Ghana">
        government of Ghana
       </a>
       's attention from the late 1990s.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pedagogical_Integration_of_ICT:_Ghana_Report_143-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Pedagogical_Integration_of_ICT:_Ghana_Report-143">
         [143]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Information_and_communications_technology" title="Information and communications technology">
        information and communications technology
       </a>
       in education policy of Ghana requires the use of information and communications technology for teaching and learning at all levels of the
       <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Ghana" title="Education in Ghana">
        education of Ghana
       </a>
       system.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pedagogical_Integration_of_ICT:_Ghana_Report_143-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Pedagogical_Integration_of_ICT:_Ghana_Report-143">
         [143]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Ghana)" title="Ministry of Education (Ghana)">
        Ministry of Education
       </a>
       (MOE) supports institutions in teaching of information and communications technology literacy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pedagogical_Integration_of_ICT:_Ghana_Report_143-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Pedagogical_Integration_of_ICT:_Ghana_Report-143">
         [143]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Majority of secondary, and some basic
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_schools_in_Ghana" title="List of schools in Ghana">
        schools of Ghana
       </a>
       have computer laboratories.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pedagogical_Integration_of_ICT:_Ghana_Report_143-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Pedagogical_Integration_of_ICT:_Ghana_Report-143">
         [143]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Ghana's intention of becoming the information technology hub of West Africa has led the government of Ghana to enact cyber crime legislation and enhance
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cyber_security" title="Cyber security">
        cyber security
       </a>
       practices.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Cyber_Index_–_International_Security_Trends_and_Realities_144-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-The_Cyber_Index_–_International_Security_Trends_and_Realities-144">
         [144]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Acting on that goal, in 2008 Ghana passed the
       <i>
        Electronic Communications Act
       </i>
       and the
       <i>
        Electronic Transactions Act
       </i>
       , which established the legal framework for governing information technology.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Cyber_Index_–_International_Security_Trends_and_Realities_144-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-The_Cyber_Index_–_International_Security_Trends_and_Realities-144">
         [144]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In November 2011, the Deputy
       <a href="/wiki/Minister_for_Communications_(Ghana)" title="Minister for Communications (Ghana)">
        Minister for Communications
       </a>
       and Technology announced the development of a national cyber security strategy, aimed at combating
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cyber_crime" title="Cyber crime">
        cyber crime
       </a>
       and securing critical infrastructure.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Cyber_Index_–_International_Security_Trends_and_Realities_144-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-The_Cyber_Index_–_International_Security_Trends_and_Realities-144">
         [144]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In June 2012, the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Information_Technology_Agency" title="National Information Technology Agency">
        National Information Technology Agency
       </a>
       (NITA) announced a national
       <a href="/wiki/Computer_emergency_response_team" title="Computer emergency response team">
        computer emergency response team
       </a>
       "strategy" designed to co-ordinate government response to cyberattacks, both internal and external.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Cyber_Index_–_International_Security_Trends_and_Realities_144-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-The_Cyber_Index_–_International_Security_Trends_and_Realities-144">
         [144]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Agency also establish
       <a href="/wiki/Computer_emergency_response_team" title="Computer emergency response team">
        computer emergency response teams
       </a>
       for each
       <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Ghana" title="Districts of Ghana">
        municipal, metropolitan, and district assembly
       </a>
       to improve co-ordination and information-sharing on
       <a href="/wiki/Threat_(computer)" title="Threat (computer)">
        cyberspace threats
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Cyber_Index_–_International_Security_Trends_and_Realities_144-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-The_Cyber_Index_–_International_Security_Trends_and_Realities-144">
         [144]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ghana is ranked 2nd on continental Africa and 7th globally in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cyber_warfare" title="Cyber warfare">
        cyber warfare
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Cyberterrorism" title="Cyberterrorism">
        cyberterrorism
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cyber_crime" title="Cyber crime">
        cyber crime
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Internet_crime" title="Internet crime">
        internet crime
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145">
        <a href="#cite_note-145">
         [145]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Health_and_biotechnology">
        Health and biotechnology
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Health and biotechnology">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Centre_for_Scientific_Research_into_Plant_Medicine" title="Centre for Scientific Research into Plant Medicine">
        Centre for Scientific Research into Plant Medicine
       </a>
       is an agency of the
       <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Ghana)" title="Ministry of Health (Ghana)">
        Ministry of Health
       </a>
       that was set up in the 1970s for both
       <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">
        R&amp;D
       </a>
       and as a practical resource (product production &amp; distribution/provision) primarily in areas of
       <a href="/wiki/Biotechnology" title="Biotechnology">
        biotechnology
       </a>
       related to
       <a href="/wiki/Medicinal_plants" title="Medicinal plants">
        medicinal plants
       </a>
       . This includes both
       <a href="/wiki/Herbalism" title="Herbalism">
        herbal medicine
       </a>
       and work on more advanced applications. It also has a secondary role as an educational resource for foreign students in health, biotechnology and related fields.
      </p>
      <div style="clear:left;">
      </div>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Education">
        Education
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Education">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Ghana" title="Education in Ghana">
        Education in Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Overview">
        Overview
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Overview">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Ghanaian Education system is divided in three parts: "Basic Education", secondary cycle and tertiary education. "Basic Education" lasts 11 years (ages 4‒15).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GEScurr_146-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-GEScurr-146">
         [146]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is divided into
       <a href="/wiki/Kindergarten" title="Kindergarten">
        Kindergarten
       </a>
       (2 years), Primary School (2 module of 3 years) and Junior High (3 years). Junior High School (JHS) ends with the Basic Education Certificate Examination (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BECE" title="BECE">
        BECE
       </a>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GEScurr_146-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-GEScurr-146">
         [146]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GEScurr2_147-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-GEScurr2-147">
         [147]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Once the BECE achieved, the pupil can pursue into secondary cycle.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BECE_148-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-BECE-148">
         [148]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Hence, the pupil has the choice between general education (assumed by Senior High School) and vocational education (assumed by technical Senior High School, Technical and Vocational Institutes, completed by a massive private and informal offer). Senior High School lasts three years and ends on the West African Secondary School Certificate Examination (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/WASSCE" title="WASSCE">
        WASSCE
       </a>
       ). The WASSCE is needed to join a university bachelor's degree programme.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENUFFIC20137_149-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENUFFIC20137-149">
         [149]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Polytechnics are opened to vocational students, from SHS or from TVI.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNEVOC_150-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-UNEVOC-150">
         [150]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       A Bachelor's degree usually lasts 4 years, can be followed by a 1- or 2-year master's degree, which can be concluded in 3 years by a Ph.D.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENUFFIC20139_151-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENUFFIC20139-151">
         [151]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A polytechnic lasts 2 or 3 years.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNEVOC_150-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-UNEVOC-150">
         [150]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ghana also possesses numerous colleges of education.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAtuahene,_Ansah20132_152-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAtuahene,_Ansah20132-152">
         [152]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Ghanaian education system from Kindergarten up to an undergraduate degree level takes 20 years.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A_Brief_History_of_the_Ghanaian_Educational_System_153-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-A_Brief_History_of_the_Ghanaian_Educational_System-153">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The academic year usually goes from August to May inclusive.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENUFFIC20134–5_154-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENUFFIC20134–5-154">
         [154]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The school year in primary education lasts 40 weeks in Primary School and SHS, and 45 weeks in JHS.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENUFFIC20135_155-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENUFFIC20135-155">
         [155]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Enrollment">
        Enrollment
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Enrollment">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:554px;max-width:554px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:275px;max-width:275px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ghana_Ratio_of_Girls_to_Boys_in_Primary_and_Secondary_Education.png">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="710" height="115" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Ghana_Ratio_of_Girls_to_Boys_in_Primary_and_Secondary_Education.png/273px-Ghana_Ratio_of_Girls_to_Boys_in_Primary_and_Secondary_Education.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Ghana_Ratio_of_Girls_to_Boys_in_Primary_and_Secondary_Education.png/410px-Ghana_Ratio_of_Girls_to_Boys_in_Primary_and_Secondary_Education.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Ghana_Ratio_of_Girls_to_Boys_in_Primary_and_Secondary_Education.png/546px-Ghana_Ratio_of_Girls_to_Boys_in_Primary_and_Secondary_Education.png 2x" width="273"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          Ratio of females to males in education system.
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:275px;max-width:275px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ghana_Children_Out_Of_School.png">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="710" height="115" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Ghana_Children_Out_Of_School.png/273px-Ghana_Children_Out_Of_School.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Ghana_Children_Out_Of_School.png/410px-Ghana_Children_Out_Of_School.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Ghana_Children_Out_Of_School.png/546px-Ghana_Children_Out_Of_School.png 2x" width="273"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <center>
           Females and males out of education system.
          </center>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       With over 95% of its children in school, Ghana currently has one of the highest school enrollment rates in all of Africa.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNICEF_–_Basic_Education_and_Gender_Equality_156-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-UNICEF_–_Basic_Education_and_Gender_Equality-156">
         [156]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157">
        <a href="#cite_note-157">
         [157]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The ratio of females to males in the total education system was 0.98, in 2014.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-news.myjoyonline.com_158-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-news.myjoyonline.com-158">
         [158]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_students">
        Foreign students
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Foreign students">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Ghana's education system annually attracts a large number of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foreign_student" title="Foreign student">
        foreign students
       </a>
       particularly in the university sector.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">
        <a href="#cite_note-159">
         [159]
        </a>
       </sup>
       One noted product of the Ghana education system is
       <a href="/wiki/Robert_Mugabe" title="Robert Mugabe">
        Robert Mugabe
       </a>
       who completed both his elementary school education and high school education at the prestigious
       <a href="/wiki/Achimota_School" title="Achimota School">
        Achimota School
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160">
        <a href="#cite_note-160">
         [160]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Funding_of_education">
        Funding of education
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Funding of education">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The government largely funds basic education comprising public primary schools and public junior high schools. Senior high schools are highly subsidised by the government. At the higher education level, the government funds more than 80% of resources provided to public universities, polytechnics and teacher training colleges.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Provision_of_educational_material">
        Provision of educational material
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Provision of educational material">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       As part of the Free Compulsory Universal Basic Education, Fcube, the government supplies all basic education schools with all their textbooks and other educational supplies like exercise books. Senior high schools are also provided with all their textbook requirement by the government. Private schools acquire their educational material from private suppliers.
      </p>
      <p>
       Ghana has the largest bookshop in Africa, EPP Books Services located at the University of Ghana.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Kindergarten_and_education_structure">
        Kindergarten and education structure
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: Kindergarten and education structure">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ghana_Education_Structure.gif">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="422" data-file-width="617" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Ghana_Education_Structure.gif/220px-Ghana_Education_Structure.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Ghana_Education_Structure.gif/330px-Ghana_Education_Structure.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Ghana_Education_Structure.gif/440px-Ghana_Education_Structure.gif 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ghana_Education_Structure.gif" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <center>
          Education structure of Ghana
         </center>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The female and male ages 15–24 years literacy rate in Ghana was 81% in 2010, with males at 82%,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161">
        <a href="#cite_note-161">
         [161]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and females at 80%.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162">
        <a href="#cite_note-162">
         [162]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Ghanaian children begin their education at the age of three or four starting from
       <a href="/wiki/Kindergarten" title="Kindergarten">
        kindergarten
       </a>
       (nursery school and
       <a href="/wiki/Preschool" title="Preschool">
        preschool
       </a>
       ), then to elementary school (primary school), high school (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Junior_high_school" title="Junior high school">
        junior high school
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Senior_high_school" title="Senior high school">
        senior high school
       </a>
       ) and finally university. The average age at which a Ghanaian child enters primary school is 6 years.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNICEF_–_Basic_Education_and_Gender_Equality_156-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-UNICEF_–_Basic_Education_and_Gender_Equality-156">
         [156]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Ghana has a
       <a href="/wiki/Free_education" title="Free education">
        free education
       </a>
       6-year primary school education system beginning at age six,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_Lauded_for_Free_Primary_School_Program_163-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_Lauded_for_Free_Primary_School_Program-163">
         [163]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and, under the educational reforms implemented in 1988 and reformed in 2007, they pass on to a 3-year junior high school system. At the end of the third year of junior high, there is a mandatory "
       <a href="/wiki/Basic_Education_Certificate_Examination" title="Basic Education Certificate Examination">
        Basic Education Certificate Examination
       </a>
       ". Those continuing must complete the 4-year senior high school programme (which has been changed to three years) and take an admission exam to enter any university or tertiary programme. The Ghanaian
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Education_system" title="Education system">
        education system
       </a>
       from nursery school up to an
       <a href="/wiki/Undergraduate_degree" title="Undergraduate degree">
        undergraduate degree
       </a>
       level takes 20 years.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A_Brief_History_of_the_Ghanaian_Educational_System_153-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-A_Brief_History_of_the_Ghanaian_Educational_System-153">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2005, Ghana had 12,130 primary schools, 5,450 junior secondary schools, 503 senior secondary schools, 21 public training colleges, 18 technical institutions, two diploma-awarding institutions and 6 universities.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Education_in_Ghana_164-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Education_in_Ghana-164">
         [164]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nab.gov.gh_165-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-nab.gov.gh-165">
         [165]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2010, there were relatively more females (53.0%) than males (40.5%) with primary school and JSS (junior secondary school) / JHS (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Junior_high_school" title="Junior high school">
        junior high school
       </a>
       ) as their highest level of education.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_–_2010_Population_and_Housing_Census_3-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_–_2010_Population_and_Housing_Census-3">
         [3]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Elementary">
        Elementary
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: Elementary">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Ghana)" title="Ministry of Education (Ghana)">
        Ghanaian Ministry of Education
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Accreditation_Board_(Ghana)" title="National Accreditation Board (Ghana)">
        Ghanaian National Accreditation Board
       </a>
       provide
       <a href="/wiki/Free_education" title="Free education">
        free education
       </a>
       at the elementary school (primary school) level, and most Ghanaians have relatively easy access to high school education (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Junior_high_school" title="Junior high school">
        junior high school
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Senior_high_school" title="Senior high school">
        senior high school
       </a>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_Lauded_for_Free_Primary_School_Program_163-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_Lauded_for_Free_Primary_School_Program-163">
         [163]
        </a>
       </sup>
       These numbers can be contrasted with the single university and handful of secondary and primary schools that existed at the time of independence in 1957. Ghana's spending on education has varied between 28–40% of its annual budget in the past decade. All teaching is done in English, mostly by qualified Ghanaian educators.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A_Brief_History_of_the_Ghanaian_Educational_System_153-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-A_Brief_History_of_the_Ghanaian_Educational_System-153">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The courses taught at the primary or basic school level include English, Ghanaian language and culture, mathematics, environmental studies, social studies,
       <a href="/wiki/Standard_Chinese" title="Standard Chinese">
        Mandarin
       </a>
       and French as an
       <a href="/wiki/Organisation_internationale_de_la_Francophonie" title="Organisation internationale de la Francophonie">
        OIF
       </a>
       associated-member,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166">
        <a href="#cite_note-166">
         [166]
        </a>
       </sup>
       integrated or
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/General_science" title="General science">
        general science
       </a>
       , pre-
       <a href="/wiki/Vocational_education" title="Vocational education">
        vocational
       </a>
       skills and pre-
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Technical_education" title="Technical education">
        technical
       </a>
       skills, religious and moral education, and physical activities such as Ghanaian music and dance, and
       <a href="/wiki/Physical_education" title="Physical education">
        physical education
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A_Brief_History_of_the_Ghanaian_Educational_System_153-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-A_Brief_History_of_the_Ghanaian_Educational_System-153">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="High_school">
        High school
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: High school">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_senior_secondary_schools_in_Ghana" title="List of senior secondary schools in Ghana">
        List of senior secondary schools in Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The senior high level school curriculum has core subjects and elective subjects of which students must take four the core subjects of English language, mathematics, integrated science (including science, agriculture and environmental studies) and
       <a href="/wiki/Social_studies" title="Social studies">
        social studies
       </a>
       (economics, geography, history and government).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A_Brief_History_of_the_Ghanaian_Educational_System_153-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-A_Brief_History_of_the_Ghanaian_Educational_System-153">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       High school students also choose four elective subjects from five available programmes: agriculture programme, general programme (arts or science option),
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Business_program" title="Business program">
        business programme
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Vocational_education" title="Vocational education">
        vocational
       </a>
       programme and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Technical_education" title="Technical education">
        technical
       </a>
       programme.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A_Brief_History_of_the_Ghanaian_Educational_System_153-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-A_Brief_History_of_the_Ghanaian_Educational_System-153">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Apart from most primary and secondary schools which choose the Ghanaian system of schooling, there are also international schools such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Takoradi_International_School" title="Takoradi International School">
        Takoradi International School
       </a>
       , Tema International School,
       <a href="/wiki/Galaxy_International_School,_Accra" title="Galaxy International School, Accra">
        Galaxy International School
       </a>
       , The Roman Ridge School,
       <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Community_School" title="Lincoln Community School">
        Lincoln Community School
       </a>
       , Faith Montessori School, American International School,
       <a href="/wiki/Alpha_Beta_Christian_College" title="Alpha Beta Christian College">
        Alpha Beta Christian College
       </a>
       , Association International School, New Nation School, SOS Hermann Gmeiner International College, Vilac International School, Akosombo International School (which offers Cambridge O level certificate), North Legon Little Campus and International Community School, which offer the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Baccalaureat" title="International Baccalaureat">
        International Baccalaureat
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Advanced_Level_General_Certificate_of_Education" title="Advanced Level General Certificate of Education">
        Advanced Level General Certificate of Education
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/International_General_Certificate_of_Secondary_Education" title="International General Certificate of Secondary Education">
        International General Certificate of Secondary Education
       </a>
       (IGCSE).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Education_in_Ghana_164-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Education_in_Ghana-164">
         [164]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="University">
        University
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=44" title="Edit section: University">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Ghana" title="List of universities in Ghana">
        List of universities in Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:462px;max-width:462px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:152px;max-width:152px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:University_of_Education,_Winneba_(UEW)_North_Campus.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/University_of_Education%2C_Winneba_%28UEW%29_North_Campus.jpg/150px-University_of_Education%2C_Winneba_%28UEW%29_North_Campus.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/University_of_Education%2C_Winneba_%28UEW%29_North_Campus.jpg/225px-University_of_Education%2C_Winneba_%28UEW%29_North_Campus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/University_of_Education%2C_Winneba_%28UEW%29_North_Campus.jpg/300px-University_of_Education%2C_Winneba_%28UEW%29_North_Campus.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          Front view of the
          <a href="/wiki/University_of_Education,_Winneba" title="University of Education, Winneba">
           University of Education, Winneba
          </a>
          (UEW) North
          <a href="/wiki/Campus" title="Campus">
           Campus
          </a>
          in Winneba
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:152px;max-width:152px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:College_of_Engineering,_KNUST_Auditorium.JPG">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="2432" data-file-width="3648" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/College_of_Engineering%2C_KNUST_Auditorium.JPG/150px-College_of_Engineering%2C_KNUST_Auditorium.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/College_of_Engineering%2C_KNUST_Auditorium.JPG/225px-College_of_Engineering%2C_KNUST_Auditorium.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/College_of_Engineering%2C_KNUST_Auditorium.JPG/300px-College_of_Engineering%2C_KNUST_Auditorium.JPG 2x" width="150"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          Ghanaian college students at the
          <a href="/wiki/Kwame_Nkrumah_University_of_Science_and_Technology" title="Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology">
           Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology
          </a>
          (KNUST) in Kumasi, February 2011
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:152px;max-width:152px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Badme_Library_of_University_of_Ghana,_Accra,_Ghana.JPG">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Badme_Library_of_University_of_Ghana%2C_Accra%2C_Ghana.JPG/150px-Badme_Library_of_University_of_Ghana%2C_Accra%2C_Ghana.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Badme_Library_of_University_of_Ghana%2C_Accra%2C_Ghana.JPG/225px-Badme_Library_of_University_of_Ghana%2C_Accra%2C_Ghana.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Badme_Library_of_University_of_Ghana%2C_Accra%2C_Ghana.JPG/300px-Badme_Library_of_University_of_Ghana%2C_Accra%2C_Ghana.JPG 2x" width="150"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          Main entrance to the
          <a href="/wiki/University_of_Ghana" title="University of Ghana">
           University of Ghana
          </a>
          's Balme Library in Accra
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       There are eight national public universities in Ghana: the University of Ghana, Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology,
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Cape_Coast" title="University of Cape Coast">
        University of Cape Coast
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Education,_Winneba" title="University of Education, Winneba">
        University of Education
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/University_for_Development_Studies" title="University for Development Studies">
        University for Development Studies
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/University_of_Mines_and_Technology" title="University of Mines and Technology">
        University of Mines and Technology
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/University_of_Professional_Studies,_Accra" title="University of Professional Studies, Accra">
        University of Professional Studies, Accra
       </a>
       , University of Energy and Natural Resources, and University of Health and Allied Sciences.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167">
        <a href="#cite_note-167">
         [167]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Ghana has a growing number of accredited private universities including
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lancaster_University,_Ghana" title="Lancaster University, Ghana">
        Lancaster University, Ghana
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Technology_University_College" title="Ghana Technology University College">
        Ghana Technology University College
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ashesi_University_College" title="Ashesi University College">
        Ashesi University College
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Methodist_University_College_Ghana" title="Methodist University College Ghana">
        Methodist University College Ghana
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_University_College" title="Central University College">
        Central University College
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Accra_Institute_of_Technology" title="Accra Institute of Technology">
        Accra Institute of Technology
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Regent_University_College_of_Science_and_Technology" title="Regent University College of Science and Technology">
        Regent University College of Science and Technology
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Valley_View_University" title="Valley View University">
        Valley View University
       </a>
       , Catholic University College, Presbyterian university college, and
       <a href="/wiki/Zenith_University_College" title="Zenith University College">
        Zenith University College
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">
        <a href="#cite_note-168">
         [168]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The oldest university in Ghana, the
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Ghana" title="University of Ghana">
        University of Ghana
       </a>
       , was founded in 1948. It had 29,754 students in 2008. Its programmes in the arts,
       <a href="/wiki/Humanities" title="Humanities">
        humanities
       </a>
       , business, and the
       <a href="/wiki/Social_science" title="Social science">
        social sciences
       </a>
       , as well as medicine, are among the best in the country.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2017)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       Many universities—including
       <a href="/wiki/Harvard_University" title="Harvard University">
        Harvard University
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Cornell_University" title="Cornell University">
        Cornell University
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oxford_University" title="Oxford University">
        Oxford University
       </a>
       —have special study-abroad programmes with Ghanaian schools and provide their students the opportunity to study abroad at Ghanaian universities.
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_University" title="New York University">
        New York University
       </a>
       has a campus in Accra.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">
        <a href="#cite_note-169">
         [169]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The University of Ghana has seen a shift of its traditionally best students to the
       <a href="/wiki/Kwame_Nkrumah_University_of_Science_and_Technology" title="Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology">
        Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-University_of_Ghana_170-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-University_of_Ghana-170">
         [170]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since Ghana's independence, the country has been one of the most educational in sub-Saharan Africa. Former UN Secretary General
       <a href="/wiki/Kofi_Annan" title="Kofi Annan">
        Kofi Annan
       </a>
       has been chancellor of the University of Ghana since 2008.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-University_of_Ghana_170-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-University_of_Ghana-170">
         [170]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology, the second university to be established in the country, is the premier university of science and technology in Ghana and West Africa.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A_Brief_History_of_the_Ghanaian_Educational_System_153-6">
        <a href="#cite_note-A_Brief_History_of_the_Ghanaian_Educational_System-153">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">
        Demographics
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=45" title="Edit section: Demographics">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Ghana" title="Demographics of Ghana">
        Demographics of Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/Ghanaian_people" title="Ghanaian people">
        Ghanaian people
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The vast majority of Ghana's population—98% percent— identify as
       <a href="/wiki/Black_people" title="Black people">
        Black
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Africans" title="Africans">
        Africans
       </a>
       despite the majority of the population having some type of mixed heritage.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
        <a href="#cite_note-171">
         [171]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">
        <a href="#cite_note-172">
         [172]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173">
        <a href="#cite_note-173">
         [173]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ghana is a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Multiethnic_society" title="Multiethnic society">
        multiethnic country
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_–_2010_Population_and_Housing_Census_3-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_–_2010_Population_and_Housing_Census-3">
         [3]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The largest
       <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_group" title="Ethnic group">
        ethnic group
       </a>
       is the
       <a href="/wiki/Ashanti_people" title="Ashanti people">
        Ashanti people
       </a>
       . Ghana's territorial area within West Africa was unoccupied and uninhabited by humans until the 10th century BC.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A_Historical_Geography_of_Ghana_174-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-A_Historical_Geography_of_Ghana-174">
         [174]
        </a>
       </sup>
       By the 10th century AD. The Guans were the first settlers in Ghana long before the other tribes came. (
       <a href="/wiki/Akan_people" title="Akan people">
        Akans
       </a>
       ) had established
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bonoman" title="Bonoman">
        Bonoman
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Brong-Ahafo_Region" title="Brong-Ahafo Region">
        Brong Ahafo
       </a>
       region) and were joined by the current settlers and inhabitants in the 16th century.
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2010, the inhabiting population of Ghana was 71.2% Christian (28.3% are
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pentecostal" title="Pentecostal">
        Pentecostal
       </a>
       , 18.4%
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant" title="Protestant">
        Protestant
       </a>
       , 13.1%
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholic" title="Catholic">
        Catholic
       </a>
       and 11.4% other). Approximately 17.6% of the inhabiting population of Ghana were
       <a href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">
        Muslims
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana:_CIA_World_FactBook_15-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana:_CIA_World_FactBook-15">
         [15]
        </a>
       </sup>
       (51%
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sunni" title="Sunni">
        Sunni
       </a>
       , 16%
       <a href="/wiki/Ahmadiyya" title="Ahmadiyya">
        Ahmadiyya
       </a>
       , and 8%
