       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shia" title="Shia">
        Shia
       </a>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-religion2010_175-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-religion2010-175">
         [175]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pew_176-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-pew-176">
         [176]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       As of the year 2014, there are 375,000 registered legal
       <a href="/wiki/Skilled_worker" title="Skilled worker">
        skilled workers
       </a>
       (permanent residents) or
       <a href="/wiki/Foreign_worker" title="Foreign worker">
        foreign workers
       </a>
       /students (i.e.
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Card" title="Ghana Card">
        Ghana Card
       </a>
       holders) inhabitants with an annually 1.5 million transited airport
       <a href="/wiki/Layover" title="Layover">
        layovers
       </a>
       . In its first post-colonial census in 1960, Ghana had a population of 6.7 million.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177">
        <a href="#cite_note-177">
         [177]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The median age of Ghanaian citizens is 30 years old and the average household size is 3.6 persons. The Government of Ghana states that the
       <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">
        official language
       </a>
       of Ghana is English,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Ghanaian_Government_states_that_English_is_the_official_language_2-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-The_Ghanaian_Government_states_that_English_is_the_official_language-2">
         [2]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and is spoken by 67.1% of the inhabiting population of Ghana.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_–_2010_Population_and_Housing_Census_3-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_–_2010_Population_and_Housing_Census-3">
         [3]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Population">
        Population
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=46" title="Edit section: Population">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Immigration_Service" title="Ghana Immigration Service">
        Ghana Immigration Service
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ghanaian_nationality_law" title="Ghanaian nationality law">
        Ghanaian nationality law
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:722px;max-width:722px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:312px;max-width:312px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ghana_Card_biometric.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="640" data-file-width="928" height="214" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Ghana_Card_biometric.jpg/310px-Ghana_Card_biometric.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Ghana_Card_biometric.jpg/465px-Ghana_Card_biometric.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Ghana_Card_biometric.jpg/620px-Ghana_Card_biometric.jpg 2x" width="310"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Card" title="Ghana Card">
           Ghana Card
          </a>
          (Ghanaian electronic ID Card) – obverse (with
          <a href="/wiki/Biometric_passport" title="Biometric passport">
           chip
          </a>
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:EPassport_logo.svg">
           <img alt="EPassport logo.svg" data-file-height="58" data-file-width="105" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/EPassport_logo.svg/20px-EPassport_logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/EPassport_logo.svg/30px-EPassport_logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/EPassport_logo.svg/40px-EPassport_logo.svg.png 2x" width="20"/>
          </a>
          ).
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:152px;max-width:152px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ghana_Biometric_Passport.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="580" data-file-width="405" height="215" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Ghana_Biometric_Passport.jpg/150px-Ghana_Biometric_Passport.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Ghana_Biometric_Passport.jpg/225px-Ghana_Biometric_Passport.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Ghana_Biometric_Passport.jpg/300px-Ghana_Biometric_Passport.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          Contemporary
          <a href="/wiki/Ghanaian_passport" title="Ghanaian passport">
           Ghanaian biometric passport
          </a>
          (with chip
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:EPassport_logo.svg">
           <img alt="EPassport logo.svg" data-file-height="58" data-file-width="105" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/EPassport_logo.svg/20px-EPassport_logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/EPassport_logo.svg/30px-EPassport_logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/EPassport_logo.svg/40px-EPassport_logo.svg.png 2x" width="20"/>
          </a>
          )
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:252px;max-width:252px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ghana_Duel_Citizenship_Identity_Card.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="258" data-file-width="300" height="215" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Ghana_Duel_Citizenship_Identity_Card.jpg/250px-Ghana_Duel_Citizenship_Identity_Card.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f7/Ghana_Duel_Citizenship_Identity_Card.jpg 1.5x" width="250"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a href="/wiki/Multiple_citizenship" title="Multiple citizenship">
           Multiple citizenship
          </a>
          with Ghanaian biometric passport
          <a href="/wiki/Identity_document" title="Identity document">
           identity document
          </a>
          .
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 2010, the population was 24.2 million. The Ashanti Region had the most, (
       <a href="/wiki/Akan_people" title="Akan people">
        Akan
       </a>
       ) (
       <a href="/wiki/Ashanti_people" title="Ashanti people">
        Ashanti
       </a>
       ) (4.7 million in
       <a href="/wiki/Ashanti_Region" title="Ashanti Region">
        Ashanti
       </a>
       , 2.3 million in
       <a href="/wiki/Brong-Ahafo_Region" title="Brong-Ahafo Region">
        Brong-Ahafo
       </a>
       , 2.2 million in
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Region_(Ghana)" title="Central Region (Ghana)">
        Central
       </a>
       , 2.6 million in
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Region_(Ghana)" title="Eastern Region (Ghana)">
        Eastern
       </a>
       , 2.3 million in
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Region_(Ghana)" title="Western Region (Ghana)">
        Western
       </a>
       , and 4 million in the
       <a href="/wiki/Seat_of_government" title="Seat of government">
        seat of government
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Greater_Accra_Region" title="Greater Accra Region">
        Greater Accra
       </a>
       geographically and legally part of
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Region_(Ghana)" title="Eastern Region (Ghana)">
        Eastern
       </a>
       then administered separately on 23 July 1982).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-religion2010_175-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-religion2010-175">
         [175]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of 2010
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , 4.1 million persons reside in the
       <a href="/wiki/Dagomba_people" title="Dagomba people">
        Dagbani
       </a>
       territories or
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Dagbon" title="Kingdom of Dagbon">
        Kingdom of Dagbon
       </a>
       (2.4 million in
       <a href="/wiki/Northern_Region_(Ghana)" title="Northern Region (Ghana)">
        Northern
       </a>
       , 1 million in
       <a href="/wiki/Upper_East_Region" title="Upper East Region">
        Upper East
       </a>
       , and 0.7 million in
       <a href="/wiki/Upper_West_Region" title="Upper West Region">
        Upper West
       </a>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-religion2010_175-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-religion2010-175">
         [175]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       As of 2010
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , 2.1 million persons reside in
       <a href="/wiki/Ewe_people" title="Ewe people">
        Ewe
       </a>
       territory
       <a href="/wiki/Volta_Region" title="Volta Region">
        Volta
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-religion2010_175-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-religion2010-175">
         [175]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Legal_immigration">
        Legal immigration
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=47" title="Edit section: Legal immigration">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Ghana" title="Immigration to Ghana">
        Immigration to Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Due to the recent legal immigration of
       <a href="/wiki/Skilled_worker" title="Skilled worker">
        skilled workers
       </a>
       who possess
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Card" title="Ghana Card">
        Ghana Cards
       </a>
       , there is a small population of Chinese, Malaysian, Indian, Middle Eastern and European nationals.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Illegal_immigration">
        Illegal immigration
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=48" title="Edit section: Illegal immigration">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Illegal_immigration_in_Ghana" title="Illegal immigration in Ghana">
        Illegal immigration in Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 2010, the
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Immigration_Service" title="Ghana Immigration Service">
        Ghana Immigration Service
       </a>
       reported that there was a large number of
       <a href="/wiki/Economic_migrant" title="Economic migrant">
        economic migrants
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Illegal_immigrant" title="Illegal immigrant">
        Illegal immigrants
       </a>
       inhabiting Ghana 14.6% (or 3.1 million) of Ghana's 2010 population (predominantly
       <a href="/wiki/Nigerians" title="Nigerians">
        Nigerians
       </a>
       , Burkinabe citizens, Togolese citizens, and Malian citizens). In 1969, under the "Ghana Aliens Compliance Order" (GACO)
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Enactment_of_a_bill" title="Enactment of a bill">
        enacted
       </a>
       by the
       <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Ghana" title="Prime Minister of Ghana">
        Prime Minister of Ghana
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Kofi_Abrefa_Busia" title="Kofi Abrefa Busia">
        Kofi Abrefa Busia
       </a>
       ;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_Owes_no_Apology_to_Anybody_for_Aliens_Compliance_Order_178-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_Owes_no_Apology_to_Anybody_for_Aliens_Compliance_Order-178">
         [178]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Government of Ghana with BGU (
       <a href="/wiki/Border_Guard_Unit" title="Border Guard Unit">
        Border Guard Unit
       </a>
       )
       <a href="/wiki/Deportation" title="Deportation">
        deported
       </a>
       over 3,000,000
       <a href="/wiki/Alien_(law)" title="Alien (law)">
        aliens
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Illegal_immigrant" title="Illegal immigrant">
        illegal immigrants
       </a>
       in three months as they made up 20% of the inhabiting population at the time.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_Owes_no_Apology_to_Anybody_for_Aliens_Compliance_Order_178-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_Owes_no_Apology_to_Anybody_for_Aliens_Compliance_Order-178">
         [178]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_History_of_Ghana's_1969_Aliens_Compliance_Order_179-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-The_History_of_Ghana's_1969_Aliens_Compliance_Order-179">
         [179]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2013, there was a mass deportation of illegal miners, more than 4,000 of whom were Chinese nationals.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180">
        <a href="#cite_note-180">
         [180]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181">
        <a href="#cite_note-181">
         [181]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Language">
        Language
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=49" title="Edit section: Language">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Ghana" title="Languages of Ghana">
        Languages of Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Akan_Greetings_(Akwaba_%E2%80%93_Welcome;_Ete_sen_%E2%80%93_Hello).JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="375" data-file-width="880" height="94" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Akan_Greetings_%28Akwaba_%E2%80%93_Welcome%3B_Ete_sen_%E2%80%93_Hello%29.JPG/220px-Akan_Greetings_%28Akwaba_%E2%80%93_Welcome%3B_Ete_sen_%E2%80%93_Hello%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Akan_Greetings_%28Akwaba_%E2%80%93_Welcome%3B_Ete_sen_%E2%80%93_Hello%29.JPG/330px-Akan_Greetings_%28Akwaba_%E2%80%93_Welcome%3B_Ete_sen_%E2%80%93_Hello%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Akan_Greetings_%28Akwaba_%E2%80%93_Welcome%3B_Ete_sen_%E2%80%93_Hello%29.JPG/440px-Akan_Greetings_%28Akwaba_%E2%80%93_Welcome%3B_Ete_sen_%E2%80%93_Hello%29.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Akan_Greetings_(Akwaba_%E2%80%93_Welcome;_Ete_sen_%E2%80%93_Hello).JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Ashanti
         <a href="/wiki/Greeting" title="Greeting">
          greeting
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Phrase" title="Phrase">
          phrases
         </a>
         ; "akɔaba" (welcome) and "ɛte sɛn" (how is it?) in Ashanti Twi
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       There are eleven languages that have the status of government-sponsored languages: four are
       <a href="/wiki/Akan_language" title="Akan language">
        Akan ethnic languages
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Asante_dialect" title="Asante dialect">
        Asante Twi
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Akuapem_Twi" title="Akuapem Twi">
        Akuapem Twi
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Fante_dialect" title="Fante dialect">
        Mfantse
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Nzema_language" title="Nzema language">
        Nzema
       </a>
       ), two are
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oti-Volta_languages" title="Oti-Volta languages">
        Mole-Dagbani ethnic
       </a>
       languages (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dagaare" title="Dagaare">
        Dagaare
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dagomba_language" title="Dagomba language">
        Dagbanli
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Hausa_language" title="Hausa language">
        Hausa language
       </a>
       ). The rest are
       <a href="/wiki/Ewe_language" title="Ewe language">
        Ewe
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Adangme_language" title="Adangme language">
        Dangme
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ga_language" title="Ga language">
        Ga
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Gonja_language" title="Gonja language">
        Gonja
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kasem_language" title="Kasem language">
        Kasem
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NCA_182-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NCA-182">
         [182]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183">
        <a href="#cite_note-183">
         [183]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">
        English
       </a>
       is the language of the state and is widely used as a
       <a href="/wiki/Lingua_franca" title="Lingua franca">
        lingua franca
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">
        Religion
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=50" title="Edit section: Religion">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Ghana" title="Religion in Ghana">
        Religion in Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Eid_Al-Fittr_Parade.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="4608" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Eid_Al-Fittr_Parade.JPG/220px-Eid_Al-Fittr_Parade.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Eid_Al-Fittr_Parade.JPG/330px-Eid_Al-Fittr_Parade.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Eid_Al-Fittr_Parade.JPG/440px-Eid_Al-Fittr_Parade.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Eid_Al-Fittr_Parade.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Eid_al-Fitr" title="Eid al-Fitr">
          Eid al-Fitr
         </a>
         religious holiday in Ghana
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <table border="1" class="wikitable" style="width: 50%; float:left; font-size:90%;">

       </caption>

         </sup>

         2010 census

         </sup>
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">
          Christian
         </a>
        </td>

         68.8%
        </td>

         71.2%
        </td>
       </tr>

         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pentecostal" title="Pentecostal">

         </a>
         /
         <a href="/wiki/Charismatic_Christianity" title="Charismatic Christianity">
          Charismatic
         </a>
        </td>
        <td>

        </td>
        <td>
         28.3%
        </td>

        </td>

         18.4%
        </td>
       </tr>

         </a>

        </td>

        </td>

        </td>

        </td>

        </td>
       </tr>

         <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">
          Muslim
         </a>
        </td>
        <td>

        </td>

        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         Traditional
        </td>
        <td>

        </td>
        <td>
         5.2%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">
          None
         </a>
        </td>
        <td>
         6.1%
        </td>
        <td>
         5.2%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>

        </td>

        </td>
        <td>
         0.8%
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <p>
       Ghana is a largely Christian country, although a sizable Muslim minority exists. Traditional (indigenous) beliefs are also practiced.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Fertility_and_reproductive_health">
        Fertility and reproductive health
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=51" title="Edit section: Fertility and reproductive health">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The fertility rate of Ghana declined from 3.99 (2000) to 3.28 (2010) with 2.78 in urban region and 3.94 in rural region.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186">
        <a href="#cite_note-186">
         [186]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       As of 2010
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maternal_mortality" title="Maternal mortality">
        maternal mortality
       </a>
       rate was 350 deaths/100,000 live births, and the
       <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">
        infant mortality
       </a>
       rate was 38.52 deaths/1,000 live births.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Library_publications_185-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Library_publications-185">
         [185]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       According to a 2013 UNICEF report,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNICEF2013p27_187-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-UNICEF2013p27-187">
         [187]
        </a>
       </sup>
       4% of women in Ghana have undergone
       <a href="/wiki/Female_genital_mutilation" title="Female genital mutilation">
        female genital mutilation
       </a>
       (FGM). The practice has been made illegal in the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188">
        <a href="#cite_note-188">
         [188]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ghana is also the birth country of anti-FGM campaigner
       <a href="/wiki/Efua_Dorkenoo" title="Efua Dorkenoo">
        Efua Dorkenoo
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Universal_health_care_and_health_care_provision">
        Universal health care and health care provision
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=52" title="Edit section: Universal health care and health care provision">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/National_Health_Insurance_Scheme_(Ghana)" title="National Health Insurance Scheme (Ghana)">
        NHIS
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Ghana" title="Health in Ghana">
        Health in Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/Eye_care_in_Ghana" title="Eye care in Ghana">
        Eye care in Ghana
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Optometry_in_Ghana" title="Optometry in Ghana">
        Optometry in Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Ghana has a
       <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">
        universal health care
       </a>
       system strictly designated for
       <a href="/wiki/Ghanaian_people" title="Ghanaian people">
        Ghanaian nationals
       </a>
       , National Health Insurance Scheme (NHIS).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189">
        <a href="#cite_note-189">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Health care is very variable throughout Ghana and in 2012, over 12 million Ghanaian nationals were covered by the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Health_Insurance_Scheme_(Ghana)" title="National Health Insurance Scheme (Ghana)">
        National Health Insurance Scheme (Ghana)
       </a>
       (NHIS).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana:_National_Health_Insurance_Scheme_(NHIS)_190-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana:_National_Health_Insurance_Scheme_(NHIS)-190">
         [190]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Urban centres are well served, and contain most of the hospitals, clinics, and pharmacies in Ghana. There are over 200 hospitals in Ghana and Ghana is a destination for
       <a href="/wiki/Medical_tourism" title="Medical tourism">
        medical tourism
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">
        <a href="#cite_note-191">
         [191]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2013,
       <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">
        life expectancy
       </a>
       at birth had increased to an average of 66 years with males at 66 years and females at 67 years,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Field_Listing:_Life_expectancy_at_birth_192-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Field_Listing:_Life_expectancy_at_birth-192">
         [192]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and in 2013
       <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">
        infant mortality
       </a>
       decreased to 39 per 1,000 live births.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Listing:_Infant_mortality_rate_193-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Listing:_Infant_mortality_rate-193">
         [193]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There was an estimation of 15 physicians and 93 nurses per 100,000 persons in 2010.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-afro.who.int_194-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-afro.who.int-194">
         [194]
        </a>
       </sup>
       5.2% of Ghana's GDP was spent on health in 2010,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Field_Listing:_Health_expenditures_195-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Field_Listing:_Health_expenditures-195">
         [195]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and all
       <a href="/wiki/Ghanaian_people" title="Ghanaian people">
        Ghanaian
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Citizenship" title="Citizenship">
        citizens
       </a>
       have the right to access
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Primary_health_care" title="Primary health care">
        primary health care
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bill_Gates_Ghana_196-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Bill_Gates_Ghana-196">
         [196]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       As of 2012
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/HIV/AIDS" title="HIV/AIDS">
        HIV/AIDS
       </a>
       prevalence was estimated at 1.40% among adults aged 15–49.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197">
        <a href="#cite_note-197">
         [197]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div style="clear:right;">
      </div>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">
        Culture
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=53" title="Edit section: Culture">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Ghana" title="Culture of Ghana">
        Culture of Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:FB_20151104_19_47_22_Saved_Picture(1).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="540" data-file-width="720" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/FB_20151104_19_47_22_Saved_Picture%281%29.jpg/220px-FB_20151104_19_47_22_Saved_Picture%281%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/FB_20151104_19_47_22_Saved_Picture%281%29.jpg/330px-FB_20151104_19_47_22_Saved_Picture%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/FB_20151104_19_47_22_Saved_Picture%281%29.jpg/440px-FB_20151104_19_47_22_Saved_Picture%281%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:FB_20151104_19_47_22_Saved_Picture(1).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Hogbetsotso_festival" title="Hogbetsotso festival">
          Hogbetsotso festival
         </a>
         in the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volta_region" title="Volta region">
          Volta region
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Ghanaian culture is a diverse mixture of the practices and beliefs of many different
       <a href="/wiki/Ghanaian_people" title="Ghanaian people">
        Ghanaian
       </a>
       ethnic groups.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Food_and_drink">
        Food and drink
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=54" title="Edit section: Food and drink">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Ghanaian_cuisine" title="Ghanaian cuisine">
        Ghanaian cuisine
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Ghanaian_cuisine" title="Ghanaian cuisine">
        Ghanaian cuisine
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Gastronomy" title="Gastronomy">
        gastronomy
       </a>
       is diverse, and includes an assortment of
       <a href="/wiki/Soup" title="Soup">
        soups
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Stew" title="Stew">
        stews
       </a>
       with varied seafoods and most Ghanaian soups are prepared with vegetables, meat, poultry or fish.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghanaian_cuisine,_banku,_okra_and_soup_198-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghanaian_cuisine,_banku,_okra_and_soup-198">
         [198]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Fish is important in the Ghanaian
       <a href="/wiki/Diet_(nutrition)" title="Diet (nutrition)">
        diet
       </a>
       with
       <a href="/wiki/Tilapia" title="Tilapia">
        tilapia
       </a>
       , roasted and fried
       <a href="/wiki/Whitebait" title="Whitebait">
        whitebait
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Smoked_fish" title="Smoked fish">
        smoked fish
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Crayfish" title="Crayfish">
        crayfish
       </a>
       all being common components of Ghanaian dishes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghanaian_cuisine,_banku,_okra_and_soup_198-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghanaian_cuisine,_banku,_okra_and_soup-198">
         [198]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Banku (Akple) is a common Ghanaian
       <a href="/wiki/Starch" title="Starch">
        starchy
       </a>
       food made from ground corn (maize),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghanaian_cuisine,_banku,_okra_and_soup_198-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghanaian_cuisine,_banku,_okra_and_soup-198">
         [198]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and cornmeal based staples, dokonu (
       <a href="/wiki/Kenkey" title="Kenkey">
        kenkey
       </a>
       ) and banku (akple) are usually accompanied by some form of
       <a href="/wiki/Fried_fish" title="Fried fish">
        fried fish
       </a>
       (chinam) or grilled tilapia and a very spicy condiment made from raw red and green
       <a href="/wiki/Chili_pepper" title="Chili pepper">
        chillies
       </a>
       , onions and tomatoes (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pepper_sauce" title="Pepper sauce">
        pepper sauce
       </a>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghanaian_cuisine,_banku,_okra_and_soup_198-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghanaian_cuisine,_banku,_okra_and_soup-198">
         [198]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Banku and tilapia is a combo served in most Ghanaian restaurants.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghanaian_cuisine,_banku,_okra_and_soup_198-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghanaian_cuisine,_banku,_okra_and_soup-198">
         [198]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Fufu" title="Fufu">
        Fufu
       </a>
       is the most common exported Ghanaian dish in that it is a delicacy across the
       <a href="/wiki/African_diaspora" title="African diaspora">
        African diaspora
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghanaian_cuisine,_banku,_okra_and_soup_198-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghanaian_cuisine,_banku,_okra_and_soup-198">
         [198]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">
        Literature
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=55" title="Edit section: Literature">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The Ghanaian national literature radio programme and accompanying publication
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Voices_of_Ghana" title="Voices of Ghana">
         Voices of Ghana
        </a>
       </i>
       was one of the earliest on the African continent. The most prominent Ghanaian authors are novelists;
       <a href="/wiki/J._E._Casely_Hayford" title="J. E. Casely Hayford">
        J. E. Casely Hayford
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ayi_Kwei_Armah" title="Ayi Kwei Armah">
        Ayi Kwei Armah
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nii_Ayikwei_Parkes" title="Nii Ayikwei Parkes">
        Nii Ayikwei Parkes
       </a>
       , who gained international acclaim with the books,
       <i>
        Ethiopia Unbound
       </i>
       (1911),
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/The_Beautyful_Ones_Are_Not_Yet_Born" title="The Beautyful Ones Are Not Yet Born">
         The Beautyful Ones Are Not Yet Born
        </a>
       </i>
       (1968) and
       <i>
        Tail of the Blue Bird
       </i>
       (2009), respectively.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LIT_199-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-LIT-199">
         [199]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In addition to novels, other literature arts such as Ghanaian theatre and poetry have also had a very good development and support at the national level with prominent Ghanaian playwrights and poets
       <a href="/wiki/Joe_de_Graft" title="Joe de Graft">
        Joe de Graft
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Efua_Sutherland" title="Efua Sutherland">
        Efua Sutherland
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LIT_199-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-LIT-199">
         [199]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Adinkra">
        Adinkra
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=56" title="Edit section: Adinkra">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Adinkra_symbols" title="Adinkra symbols">
        Adinkra symbols
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Adinkra_motifs_Rattray_1927.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="214" data-file-width="390" height="121" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Adinkra_motifs_Rattray_1927.jpg/220px-Adinkra_motifs_Rattray_1927.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Adinkra_motifs_Rattray_1927.jpg/330px-Adinkra_motifs_Rattray_1927.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/2a/Adinkra_motifs_Rattray_1927.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Adinkra_motifs_Rattray_1927.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Adinkra_symbols" title="Adinkra symbols">
          Adinkra symbols
         </a>
         by
         <a href="/wiki/Robert_Sutherland_Rattray" title="Robert Sutherland Rattray">
          Robert Sutherland Rattray
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       During the 13th century, Ghanaians developed their unique art of
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Adinkra_symbols" title="Adinkra symbols">
         adinkra
        </a>
       </i>
       printing. Hand-printed and hand-
       <a href="/wiki/Embroidery" title="Embroidery">
        embroidered
       </a>
       adinkra clothes were made and used exclusively by the then Ghanaian royalty for devotional ceremonies. Each of the
       <a href="/wiki/Motif_(visual_arts)" title="Motif (visual arts)">
        motifs
       </a>
       that make up the
       <a href="/wiki/Text_corpus" title="Text corpus">
        corpus
       </a>
       of adinkra symbolism has a name and meaning derived from a proverb, a historical event, human attitude,
       <a href="/wiki/Ethology" title="Ethology">
        ethology
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Plant_life-form" title="Plant life-form">
        plant life-form
       </a>
       , or
       <a href="/wiki/Shape" title="Shape">
        shapes
       </a>
       of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Inanimate" title="Inanimate">
        inanimate
       </a>
       and man-made objects. These are graphically rendered in stylised geometric shapes. The meanings of the motifs may be categorised into
       <a href="/wiki/Aesthetics" title="Aesthetics">
        aesthetics
       </a>
       , ethics,
       <a href="/wiki/Interpersonal_relationship" title="Interpersonal relationship">
        human relations
       </a>
       , and concepts.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LIT_199-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-LIT-199">
         [199]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Adinkra symbols have a decorative function as
       <a href="/wiki/Tattoo" title="Tattoo">
        tattoos
       </a>
       but also represent objects that encapsulate evocative messages that convey traditional wisdom, aspects of life or the environment. There are many different symbols with distinct meanings, often linked with
       <a href="/wiki/Proverb" title="Proverb">
        proverbs
       </a>
       . In the words of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anthony_Appiah" title="Anthony Appiah">
        Anthony Appiah
       </a>
       , they were one of the means in a pre-literate society for "supporting the transmission of a complex and nuanced body of practice and belief".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200">
        <a href="#cite_note-200">
         [200]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Traditional_clothing">
        Traditional clothing
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=57" title="Edit section: Traditional clothing">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Kente_cloth" title="Kente cloth">
        Kente cloth
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Along with the
       <i>
        Adinkra cloth
       </i>
       Ghanaians use many different cloth fabrics for their traditional attire.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghanaian_Kente_Cloth_201-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghanaian_Kente_Cloth-201">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The different ethnic groups have their own individual cloth. The most well known is the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kente" title="Kente">
        Kente
       </a>
       cloth.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghanaian_Kente_Cloth_201-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghanaian_Kente_Cloth-201">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Kente is a very important Ghanaian
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_costume" title="National costume">
        national costume
       </a>
       and clothing and these cloths are used to make traditional and modern Ghanaian Kente
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Attire" title="Attire">
        attire
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghanaian_Kente_Cloth_201-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghanaian_Kente_Cloth-201">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Different symbols and different colours mean different things.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghanaian_Kente_Cloth_201-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghanaian_Kente_Cloth-201">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Kente_cloth" title="Kente cloth">
        Kente
       </a>
       is the most famous of all the Ghanaian cloths.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghanaian_Kente_Cloth_201-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghanaian_Kente_Cloth-201">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Kente is a ceremonial cloth hand-woven on a horizontal
       <a href="/wiki/Loom" title="Loom">
        treadle loom
       </a>
       and strips measuring about 4 inches wide are sewn together into larger pieces of cloths.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghanaian_Kente_Cloth_201-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghanaian_Kente_Cloth-201">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Cloths come in various colours, sizes and designs and are worn during very important social and religious occasions.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghanaian_Kente_Cloth_201-6">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghanaian_Kente_Cloth-201">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In a cultural context, kente is more important than just a cloth and it is a visual representation of history and also a form of written language through weaving.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghanaian_Kente_Cloth_201-7">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghanaian_Kente_Cloth-201">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The term kente has its roots in the Akan word
       <i>
        kɛntɛn
       </i>
       which means a basket and the first kente weavers used raffia fibres to weave cloths that looked like kenten (a basket); and thus were referred to as
       <i>
        kenten ntoma
       </i>
       ; meaning basket cloth.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghanaian_Kente_Cloth_201-8">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghanaian_Kente_Cloth-201">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The original Akan name of the cloth was
       <i>
        nsaduaso
       </i>
       or
       <i>
        nwontoma
       </i>
       , meaning "a cloth hand-woven on a loom"; however, "kente" is the most frequently used term today.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghanaian_Kente_Cloth_201-9">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghanaian_Kente_Cloth-201">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div style="clear:left;">
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_clothing">
        Modern clothing
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=58" title="Edit section: Modern clothing">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:308px;max-width:308px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:152px;max-width:152px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Comtemporary_Ghanaian_men_fashion.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="2000" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Comtemporary_Ghanaian_men_fashion.jpg/150px-Comtemporary_Ghanaian_men_fashion.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Comtemporary_Ghanaian_men_fashion.jpg/225px-Comtemporary_Ghanaian_men_fashion.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Comtemporary_Ghanaian_men_fashion.jpg/300px-Comtemporary_Ghanaian_men_fashion.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          Contemporary Ghanaian men's fashion with Kente and other traditional styles
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:152px;max-width:152px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Comtemporary_Ghanaian_womenswear.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="2000" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/17/Comtemporary_Ghanaian_womenswear.jpg/150px-Comtemporary_Ghanaian_womenswear.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/17/Comtemporary_Ghanaian_womenswear.jpg/225px-Comtemporary_Ghanaian_womenswear.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/17/Comtemporary_Ghanaian_womenswear.jpg/300px-Comtemporary_Ghanaian_womenswear.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          Contemporary Ghanaian women's fashion with African print/Ankara and other fabrics
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Contemporary Ghanaian fashion include traditional and modern styles and fabrics and has made its way into the African and global fashion scene. The cloth known as
       <a href="/wiki/African_waxprints" title="African waxprints">
        African print fabric
       </a>
       was created out of Dutch wax textiles, it is believed that in the late 1800s, Dutch ships on their way to Asia stocked with machine-made textiles that mimicked Indonesian Batik stopped at many West African ports on the way. The fabrics did not do well in Asia. However, in West Africa — mainly Ghana where there was an already established market for cloths and textiles — the client base grew and it was changed to include local and traditional designs, colours and patterns to cater to the taste of the new consumers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202">
        <a href="#cite_note-202">
         [202]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Today outside of Africa it is called "Ankara" and it has a client base well beyond Ghana and Africa as a whole. It is very popular among Caribbean peoples and African Americans; celebrities such as
       <a href="/wiki/Solange_Knowles" title="Solange Knowles">
        Solange Knowles
       </a>
       and her sister
       <a href="/wiki/Beyonc%C3%A9" title="Beyoncé">
        Beyoncé
       </a>
       have been seen wearing African print attire.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
        <a href="#cite_note-203">
         [203]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Many designers from countries in North America and Europe are now using African prints and it has gained a global interest.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">
        <a href="#cite_note-204">
         [204]
        </a>
       </sup>
       British luxury fashion house
       <a href="/wiki/Burberry" title="Burberry">
        Burberry
       </a>
       created a collection around Ghanaian styles.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205">
        <a href="#cite_note-205">
         [205]
        </a>
       </sup>
       American musician
       <a href="/wiki/Gwen_Stefani" title="Gwen Stefani">
        Gwen Stefani
       </a>
       has repeatedly incorporated African prints into her clothing line and can often be seen wearing it.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206">
        <a href="#cite_note-206">
         [206]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Internationally acclaimed Ghanaian-British designer
       <a href="/wiki/Ozwald_Boateng" title="Ozwald Boateng">
        Ozwald Boateng
       </a>
       introduced African print suits in his 2012 collection.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207">
        <a href="#cite_note-207">
         [207]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Music_and_dance">
        Music and dance
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=59" title="Edit section: Music and dance">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Ghana" title="Music of Ghana">
        Music of Ghana
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Azonto" title="Azonto">
        Azonto
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Kpanlogo" title="Kpanlogo">
        Kpanlogo
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <div class="PopUpMediaTransform" id="mwe_player_3" style="width:220px;" videopayload='&lt;div class="mediaContainer" style="width:360px"&gt;&lt;video id="mwe_player_4" poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Traditional_Adowa_dance_form_and_music_performance.ogv/360px--Traditional_Adowa_dance_form_and_music_performance.ogv.jpg" controls="" preload="none" autoplay="" style="width:360px;height:480px" class="kskin" data-durationhint="15.394829931973" data-startoffset="0" data-mwtitle="Traditional_Adowa_dance_form_and_music_performance.ogv" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons"&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/8/85/Traditional_Adowa_dance_form_and_music_performance.ogv/Traditional_Adowa_dance_form_and_music_performance.ogv.480p.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp8, vorbis&amp;quot;" data-title="SD WebM (480P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 480P" data-transcodekey="480p.webm" data-width="360" data-height="480" data-bandwidth="1072504" data-framerate="30"/&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/85/Traditional_Adowa_dance_form_and_music_performance.ogv" type="video/ogg; codecs=&amp;quot;theora, vorbis&amp;quot;" data-title="Original Ogg file, 480 × 640 (4.22 Mbps)" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-width="480" data-height="640" data-bandwidth="4222854" data-framerate="30"/&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/8/85/Traditional_Adowa_dance_form_and_music_performance.ogv/Traditional_Adowa_dance_form_and_music_performance.ogv.160p.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp8, vorbis&amp;quot;" data-title="Low bandwidth WebM (160P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 160P" data-transcodekey="160p.webm" data-width="120" data-height="160" data-bandwidth="219848" data-framerate="30"/&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/8/85/Traditional_Adowa_dance_form_and_music_performance.ogv/Traditional_Adowa_dance_form_and_music_performance.ogv.240p.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp8, vorbis&amp;quot;" data-title="Small WebM (240P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 240P" data-transcodekey="240p.webm" data-width="180" data-height="240" data-bandwidth="319080" data-framerate="30"/&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/8/85/Traditional_Adowa_dance_form_and_music_performance.ogv/Traditional_Adowa_dance_form_and_music_performance.ogv.360p.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp8, vorbis&amp;quot;" data-title="WebM (360P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 360P" data-transcodekey="360p.webm" data-width="270" data-height="360" data-bandwidth="568536" data-framerate="30"/&gt;&lt;/video&gt;&lt;/div&gt;'>
         <img alt="File:Traditional Adowa dance form and music performance.ogv" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Traditional_Adowa_dance_form_and_music_performance.ogv/220px--Traditional_Adowa_dance_form_and_music_performance.ogv.jpg" style="width:220px;height:293px"/>
         <a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/85/Traditional_Adowa_dance_form_and_music_performance.ogv" target="new" title="Play media">
          <span class="play-btn-large">
           <span class="mw-tmh-playtext">
            Play media
           </span>
          </span>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Traditional_Adowa_dance_form_and_music_performance.ogv" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Traditional
         <a href="/wiki/Adowa_dance" title="Adowa dance">
          Adowa dance
         </a>
         form and music performance.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Ghana" title="Music of Ghana">
        music of Ghana
       </a>
       is diverse and varies between different ethnic groups and regions. Ghanaian music incorporates several distinct types of musical instruments such as the talking drum ensembles,
       <a href="/wiki/Akan_Drum" title="Akan Drum">
        Akan Drum
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Goje" title="Goje">
        goje
       </a>
       fiddle and koloko lute, court music, including the Akan
       <a href="/wiki/Seperewa" title="Seperewa">
        Seperewa
       </a>
       , the Akan atumpan, the Ga kpanlogo styles, and log
       <a href="/wiki/Xylophone" title="Xylophone">
        xylophones
       </a>
       used in asonko music.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana:_From_Highlife_to_Hiplife_208-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana:_From_Highlife_to_Hiplife-208">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The most well known genres to have come from Ghana are African jazz, which was created by Ghanaian artist
       <a href="/wiki/Guy_Warren" title="Guy Warren">
        Kofi Ghanaba
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209">
        <a href="#cite_note-209">
         [209]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and its earliest form of secular music, called
       <a href="/wiki/Highlife" title="Highlife">
        highlife
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana:_From_Highlife_to_Hiplife_208-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana:_From_Highlife_to_Hiplife-208">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Highlife originated in the late 19th century and early 20th century and spread throughout West Africa.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana:_From_Highlife_to_Hiplife_208-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana:_From_Highlife_to_Hiplife-208">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the 1990s a new genre of music was created by the youth incorporating the influences of highlife, Afro-reggae,
       <a href="/wiki/Dancehall" title="Dancehall">
        dancehall
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hiphop" title="Hiphop">
        hiphop
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana:_From_Highlife_to_Hiplife_208-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana:_From_Highlife_to_Hiplife-208">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This hybrid was called
       <a href="/wiki/Hiplife" title="Hiplife">
        hiplife
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana:_From_Highlife_to_Hiplife_208-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana:_From_Highlife_to_Hiplife-208">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ghanaian artists such as "Afro Roots" singer, activist and songwriter
       <a href="/wiki/Rocky_Dawuni" title="Rocky Dawuni">
        Rocky Dawuni
       </a>
       , R&amp;B and soul singer
       <a href="/wiki/Rhian_Benson" title="Rhian Benson">
        Rhian Benson
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Sarkodie_(rapper)" title="Sarkodie (rapper)">
        Sarkodie
       </a>
       have had international success.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rhian_Benson's_global_soul_sound_210-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Rhian_Benson's_global_soul_sound-210">
         [210]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sarkodie_211-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Sarkodie-211">
         [211]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In December 2015, Rocky Dawuni became the first Ghanaian musician to be nominated for a Grammy award in the
       <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Reggae_Album" title="Grammy Award for Best Reggae Album">
        Grammy Award for Best Reggae Album
       </a>
       category for his 6th studio album titled
       <i>
        Branches of The Same Tree
       </i>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212">
        <a href="#cite_note-212">
         [212]
        </a>
       </sup>
       released 31 March 2015.
      </p>
      <p>
       Ghanaian dance is as diverse as its music, and there are traditional dances and different dances for different occasions.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dance,_Ghana_213-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Dance,_Ghana-213">
         [213]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The most known Ghanaian dances are those for celebrations. These dances include the
       <a href="/wiki/Adowa_dance" title="Adowa dance">
        Adowa
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kpanlogo" title="Kpanlogo">
        Kpanlogo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Azonto" title="Azonto">
        Azonto
       </a>
       , Klama, and Bamaya.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dance,_Ghana_213-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Dance,_Ghana-213">
         [213]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Film">
        Film
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=60" title="Edit section: Film">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:319px;max-width:319px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:101px;max-width:101px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Van_Vicker_(Cropped).jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="261" data-file-width="179" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Van_Vicker_%28Cropped%29.jpg/99px-Van_Vicker_%28Cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Van_Vicker_%28Cropped%29.jpg/149px-Van_Vicker_%28Cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d7/Van_Vicker_%28Cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="99"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:110px;max-width:110px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Boris_Kodjoe_2010.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="2048" data-file-width="1536" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Boris_Kodjoe_2010.jpg/108px-Boris_Kodjoe_2010.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Boris_Kodjoe_2010.jpg/162px-Boris_Kodjoe_2010.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Boris_Kodjoe_2010.jpg/216px-Boris_Kodjoe_2010.jpg 2x" width="108"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:102px;max-width:102px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Idris_Elba_2014.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="1350" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Idris_Elba_2014.jpg/100px-Idris_Elba_2014.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Idris_Elba_2014.jpg/150px-Idris_Elba_2014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Idris_Elba_2014.jpg/200px-Idris_Elba_2014.jpg 2x" width="100"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left;background-color:transparent">
         <center>
          Popular
          <a href="/wiki/List_of_Ghanaian_actors" title="List of Ghanaian actors">
           actor of Ghanaian ancestry
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="/wiki/Van_Vicker" title="Van Vicker">
           Van Vicker
          </a>
          , and international actors
          <a href="/wiki/Boris_Kodjoe" title="Boris Kodjoe">
           Boris Kodjoe
          </a>
          and
          <a href="/wiki/Idris_Elba" title="Idris Elba">
           Idris Elba
          </a>
         </center>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Ghana has a budding and thriving film industry. Ghana's film industry dates as far back as 1948 when the Gold Coast Film Unit was set up in the Information Services Department.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
        <a href="#cite_note-214">
         [214]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Some internationally recognised films have come from Ghana. In 1970,
       <i>
        I Told You So
       </i>
       was one of the first Ghanaian films to receive international acknowledgement and great reviews by
       <i>
        The New York Times
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215">
        <a href="#cite_note-215">
         [215]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It was followed by the 1973 Ghanaian and Italian production
       <i>
        The African Deal
       </i>
       also known as "
       <i>
        Contratto carnale
       </i>
       " featuring
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bahamian_American" title="Bahamian American">
        Bahamian American
       </a>
       actor
       <a href="/wiki/Calvin_Lockhart" title="Calvin Lockhart">
        Calvin Lockhart
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216">
        <a href="#cite_note-216">
         [216]
        </a>
       </sup>
       1983's
       <i>
        Kukurantumi: the Road to Accra
       </i>
       , a Ghanaian and German production directed by King Ampaw, was written about by famous American film critic
       <a href="/wiki/Vincent_Canby" title="Vincent Canby">
        Vincent Canby
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217">
        <a href="#cite_note-217">
         [217]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1987,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Cobra_Verde" title="Cobra Verde">
         Cobra Verde
        </a>
       </i>
       , another Ghanaian and German production directed by Werner Herzog, received international acclamation and in 1988,
       <i>
        Heritage Africa
       </i>
       won more than 12 film awards.
      </p>
      <p>
       In recent times there has been some collaboration between Ghanaian and Nigerian crew and cast with a number of productions being turned out. Many Ghanaian films are co-produced with
       <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Nigeria" title="Cinema of Nigeria">
        Nollywood
       </a>
       , the Nigerian film industry and some are distributed by Nigerian marketers. Also, Nigerian filmmakers usually feature Ghanaian actors and actresses in their movies and Ghanaian filmmakers feature Nigerian actors and actresses in theirs.
       <a href="/wiki/Nadia_Buari" title="Nadia Buari">
        Nadia Buari
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Yvonne_Nelson" title="Yvonne Nelson">
        Yvonne Nelson
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lydia_Forson" title="Lydia Forson">
        Lydia Forson
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Jackie_Appiah" title="Jackie Appiah">
        Jackie Appiah
       </a>
       all popular Ghanaian actresses and
       <a href="/wiki/Van_Vicker" title="Van Vicker">
        Van Vicker
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Majid_Michel" title="Majid Michel">
        Majid Michel
       </a>
       both popular Ghanaian actors, have starred in many Nigerian movies. As a result of these collaborations, Western viewers oftentimes confused Ghanaian movies with Nollywood and count their sales as one; however, they are two independent industries that sometimes share the colloquial
       <i>
        Nollywood
       </i>
       . In 2009,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unesco" title="Unesco">
        Unesco
       </a>
       described Nollywood as being the second-biggest film industry in the world after
       <a href="/wiki/Bollywood" title="Bollywood">
        Bollywood
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">
        <a href="#cite_note-218">
         [218]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Media">
        Media
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=61" title="Edit section: Media">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Ghana" title="Media of Ghana">
        Media of Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ghana_Trustworthiness_of_Media.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="310" data-file-width="445" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Ghana_Trustworthiness_of_Media.jpg/220px-Ghana_Trustworthiness_of_Media.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Ghana_Trustworthiness_of_Media.jpg/330px-Ghana_Trustworthiness_of_Media.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Ghana_Trustworthiness_of_Media.jpg/440px-Ghana_Trustworthiness_of_Media.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ghana_Trustworthiness_of_Media.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Ghana mass media,
         <a href="/wiki/News" title="News">
          news
         </a>
         and information provided by television.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Ghana" title="Media of Ghana">
        media of Ghana
       </a>
       are amongst the most free in Africa. Chapter 12 of the 1992 Constitution of Ghana guarantees
       <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">
        freedom of the press
       </a>
       and independence of the media, while Chapter 2 prohibits censorship.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gov_219-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-gov-219">
         [219]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Post-independence, the government and media often had a tense relationship, with private outlets closed during the military governments and strict media laws that prevent criticism of government.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Anokwa_220-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Anokwa-220">
         [220]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Media freedoms were restored in 1992, and after the election in 2000 of
       <a href="/wiki/John_Kufuor" title="John Kufuor">
        John Agyekum Kufuor
       </a>
       the tensions between the private media and government decreased. Kufuor was a supporter of press freedom and repealed a
       <a href="/wiki/Defamation" title="Defamation">
        libel
       </a>
       law, though maintained that the media had to act responsibly.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pr_221-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-pr-221">
         [221]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Ghanaian media has been described as "one of the most unfettered" in Africa, operating with little restriction on private media. The private press often carries criticism of government policy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc_222-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-bbc-222">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">
        Sports
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=62" title="Edit section: Sports">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Sports_in_Ghana" title="Sports in Ghana">
        Sports in Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics" title="Ghana at the 2010 Winter Olympics">
        Ghana at the Winter Olympics
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_at_the_Olympics" title="Ghana at the Olympics">
        Ghana at the Olympics
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:20150331_Mali_vs_Ghana_042.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2400" data-file-width="3599" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/20150331_Mali_vs_Ghana_042.jpg/220px-20150331_Mali_vs_Ghana_042.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/20150331_Mali_vs_Ghana_042.jpg/330px-20150331_Mali_vs_Ghana_042.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/20150331_Mali_vs_Ghana_042.jpg/440px-20150331_Mali_vs_Ghana_042.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:20150331_Mali_vs_Ghana_042.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Black Stars, the
         <a href="/wiki/Ghana_national_football_team" title="Ghana national football team">
          Ghana national football team
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Association football (or soccer) is the most spectated
       <a href="/wiki/Sports_in_Ghana" title="Sports in Ghana">
        sport in Ghana
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_national_football_team" title="Ghana national football team">
        national men's football team
       </a>
       is known as the Black Stars, with the
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_national_under-20_football_team" title="Ghana national under-20 football team">
        under-20 team
       </a>
       known as the Black Satellites.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_thrilled_by_historic_title_223-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_thrilled_by_historic_title-223">
         [223]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ghana has won the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_Cup_of_Nations" title="African Cup of Nations">
        African Cup of Nations
       </a>
       four times, the
       <a href="/wiki/FIFA_U-20_World_Cup" title="FIFA U-20 World Cup">
        FIFA U-20 World Cup
       </a>
       once, and has participated in three consecutive
       <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">
        FIFA World Cups
       </a>
       dating back to 2006.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_thrilled_by_historic_title_223-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_thrilled_by_historic_title-223">
         [223]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the
       <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2010 FIFA World Cup">
        2010 FIFA World Cup
       </a>
       , Ghana became the third African country to reach the quarter-final stage of the World Cup after Cameroon in 1990 and Senegal in 2002.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224">
        <a href="#cite_note-224">
         [224]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ghana national U-20 football team, known as the
       <i>
        Black Satellites
       </i>
       , is considered to be the feeder team for the
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_national_football_team" title="Ghana national football team">
        Ghana national football team
       </a>
       . Ghana is the first and only country on the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_continent" title="African continent">
        Africa continent
       </a>
       to be crowned
       <a href="/wiki/2009_FIFA_U-20_World_Cup" title="2009 FIFA U-20 World Cup">
        FIFA U-20 World Cup Champions
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_thrilled_by_historic_title_223-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_thrilled_by_historic_title-223">
         [223]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and two-time runners up in
       <a href="/wiki/1993_FIFA_World_Youth_Championship" title="1993 FIFA World Youth Championship">
        1993
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/2001_FIFA_World_Youth_Championship" title="2001 FIFA World Youth Championship">
        2001
       </a>
       . The Ghana national U-17 football team known as the Black Starlets are two-time
       <a href="/wiki/FIFA_U-17_World_Cup" title="FIFA U-17 World Cup">
        FIFA U-17 World Cup
       </a>
       champions in
       <a href="/wiki/1991_FIFA_U-17_World_Championship" title="1991 FIFA U-17 World Championship">
        1991
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/1995_FIFA_U-17_World_Championship" title="1995 FIFA U-17 World Championship">
        1995
       </a>
       , two-time runners up in
       <a href="/wiki/1993_FIFA_U-17_World_Championship" title="1993 FIFA U-17 World Championship">
        1993
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/1997_FIFA_World_Youth_Championship" title="1997 FIFA World Youth Championship">
        1997
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225">
        <a href="#cite_note-225">
         [225]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:296px;max-width:296px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:294px;max-width:294px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Black_Stars_Goal_Celebration_(Ghana_national_football_team).jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="533" data-file-width="800" height="195" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Black_Stars_Goal_Celebration_%28Ghana_national_football_team%29.jpg/292px-Black_Stars_Goal_Celebration_%28Ghana_national_football_team%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Black_Stars_Goal_Celebration_%28Ghana_national_football_team%29.jpg/438px-Black_Stars_Goal_Celebration_%28Ghana_national_football_team%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Black_Stars_Goal_Celebration_%28Ghana_national_football_team%29.jpg/584px-Black_Stars_Goal_Celebration_%28Ghana_national_football_team%29.jpg 2x" width="292"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          Black Stars
          <a href="/wiki/Goal_celebration" title="Goal celebration">
           goal celebration
          </a>
          ; football is the most popular sport in Ghana
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Ghanaian
