       <a href="/wiki/Football_team" title="Football team">
        football teams
       </a>
       Asante Kotoko SC and Accra Hearts of Oak SC are the 5th and 9th best
       <a href="/wiki/Football_team" title="Football team">
        football teams
       </a>
       on the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_continent" title="African continent">
        Africa continent
       </a>
       and have won a total of five Africa continental association football and
       <a href="/wiki/Confederation_of_African_Football" title="Confederation of African Football">
        Confederation of African Football
       </a>
       trophies; Ghanaian football club
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asante_Kotoko_SC" title="Asante Kotoko SC">
        Asante Kotoko SC
       </a>
       has been crowned two-time
       <a href="/wiki/CAF_Champions_League" title="CAF Champions League">
        CAF Champions League
       </a>
       winners in
       <a href="/wiki/1970_African_Cup_of_Champions_Clubs" title="1970 African Cup of Champions Clubs">
        1970
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/1983_African_Cup_of_Champions_Clubs" title="1983 African Cup of Champions Clubs">
        1983
       </a>
       and five-time CAF Champions League runners up, and Ghanaian football club
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Accra_Hearts_of_Oak_SC" title="Accra Hearts of Oak SC">
        Accra Hearts of Oak SC
       </a>
       has been crowned
       <a href="/wiki/2000_CAF_Champions_League" title="2000 CAF Champions League">
        2000 CAF Champions League
       </a>
       winner and two-time CAF Champions League runners up, 2001
       <a href="/wiki/CAF_Super_Cup" title="CAF Super Cup">
        CAF Super Cup
       </a>
       champions and
       <a href="/wiki/2004_CAF_Confederation_Cup" title="2004 CAF Confederation Cup">
        2004 CAF Confederation Cup
       </a>
       champions.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Africa's_club_of_the_Century_226-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Africa's_club_of_the_Century-226">
         [226]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Federation_of_Football_History_and_Statistics" title="International Federation of Football History and Statistics">
        International Federation of Football History and Statistics
       </a>
       crowned Asante Kotoko SC as the
       <a href="/wiki/International_Federation_of_Football_History_%26_Statistics#Continental_Clubs_of_the_20th_Century" title="International Federation of Football History &amp; Statistics">
        African club of the 20th century
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Africa's_club_of_the_Century_226-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Africa's_club_of_the_Century-226">
         [226]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There are several club football teams in Ghana that play in the
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Premier_League" title="Ghana Premier League">
        Ghana Premier League
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Football_Leagues" title="Ghana Football Leagues">
        Division One League
       </a>
       , both administered by the
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana_Football_Association" title="Ghana Football Association">
        Ghana Football Association
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227">
        <a href="#cite_note-227">
         [227]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:683px;max-width:683px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:407px;max-width:407px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Obuasi_Golf_course.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1200" height="270" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Obuasi_Golf_course.jpg/405px-Obuasi_Golf_course.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Obuasi_Golf_course.jpg/608px-Obuasi_Golf_course.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Obuasi_Golf_course.jpg/810px-Obuasi_Golf_course.jpg 2x" width="405"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          A view of the
          <a href="/wiki/Obuasi" title="Obuasi">
           Obuasi
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Golf_course" title="Golf course">
           Golf Course
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:272px;max-width:272px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2010_Opening_Ceremony_-_Ghana_entering.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="1206" data-file-width="1207" height="270" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/2010_Opening_Ceremony_-_Ghana_entering.jpg/270px-2010_Opening_Ceremony_-_Ghana_entering.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/2010_Opening_Ceremony_-_Ghana_entering.jpg/405px-2010_Opening_Ceremony_-_Ghana_entering.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/2010_Opening_Ceremony_-_Ghana_entering.jpg/540px-2010_Opening_Ceremony_-_Ghana_entering.jpg 2x" width="270"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          Ghanaian
          <a href="/wiki/Winter_sport" title="Winter sport">
           winter sports
          </a>
          Olympic team at the
          <a href="/wiki/Opening_ceremony" title="Opening ceremony">
           opening ceremony
          </a>
          of the 2010
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Winter_Olympics" title="Winter Olympics">
           Winter Olympics
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Ghana competed in the Winter Olympics in 2010 for the first time. Ghana qualified for the 2010 Winter Olympics, scoring 137.5
       <a href="/wiki/International_Ski_Federation" title="International Ski Federation">
        International Ski Federation
       </a>
       points, within the qualifying range of 120–140 points.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-0-21_228-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-0-21-228">
         [228]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ghanaian
       <a href="/wiki/Skiing" title="Skiing">
        skier
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kwame_Nkrumah-Acheampong" title="Kwame Nkrumah-Acheampong">
        Kwame Nkrumah-Acheampong
       </a>
       , nicknamed "The
       <a href="/wiki/Snow_leopard" title="Snow leopard">
        Snow Leopard
       </a>
       ", became the first
       <a href="/wiki/Ghanaian_people" title="Ghanaian people">
        Ghanaian
       </a>
       to take part in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Winter_Olympics" title="Winter Olympics">
        Winter Olympics
       </a>
       , at the
       <a href="/wiki/2010_Winter_Olympics" title="2010 Winter Olympics">
        2010 Winter Olympics
       </a>
       held in
       <a href="/wiki/Vancouver" title="Vancouver">
        Vancouver, British Columbia
       </a>
       , Canada,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Independent_229-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Independent-229">
         [229]
        </a>
       </sup>
       taking part in the
       <a href="/wiki/Slalom_skiing" title="Slalom skiing">
        slalom skiing
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vancouver_2010_230-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Vancouver_2010-230">
         [230]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Ghana finished 47th out of 102 participating nations, of whom 54 finished in the
       <a href="/wiki/Alpine_skiing_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_slalom" title="Alpine skiing at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Men's slalom">
        Alpine skiing slalom
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231">
        <a href="#cite_note-231">
         [231]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Results_232-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Results-232">
         [232]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Kwame_Nkrumah-Acheampong" title="Kwame Nkrumah-Acheampong">
        Kwame Nkrumah-Acheampong
       </a>
       broke on the international
       <a href="/wiki/Skiing" title="Skiing">
        skiing
       </a>
       circuit, being the second
       <a href="/wiki/Black_people" title="Black people">
        black African
       </a>
       skier to do so.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana's_first_winter_Olympian_233-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana's_first_winter_Olympian-233">
         [233]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Ghanaian athletes have won a total of four Olympics medals in thirteen appearances at the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Summer_Olympics" title="Summer Olympics">
        Summer Olympics
       </a>
       , three in
       <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">
        boxing
       </a>
       , and a
       <a href="/wiki/Bronze_medal" title="Bronze medal">
        bronze medal
       </a>
       in association football, and thus became the first country on the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_continent" title="African continent">
        Africa continent
       </a>
       to win a
       <a href="/wiki/Medal" title="Medal">
        medal
       </a>
       at association football.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_Olympic_234-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_Olympic-234">
         [234]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The country has also produced a number of world class boxers, including
       <a href="/wiki/Azumah_Nelson" title="Azumah Nelson">
        Azumah Nelson
       </a>
       a three-time world champion and considered as Africa's greatest
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Boxer" title="Boxer">
        boxer
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235">
        <a href="#cite_note-235">
         [235]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Top_5_Ghanaian_Boxers_236-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Top_5_Ghanaian_Boxers-236">
         [236]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Nana_Konadu" title="Nana Konadu">
        Nana Yaw Konadu
       </a>
       also a three-time world champion,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Top_5_Ghanaian_Boxers_236-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Top_5_Ghanaian_Boxers-236">
         [236]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Ike_Quartey" title="Ike Quartey">
        Ike Quartey
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Top_5_Ghanaian_Boxers_236-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Top_5_Ghanaian_Boxers-236">
         [236]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Joshua_Clottey" title="Joshua Clottey">
        Joshua Clottey
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Top_5_Ghanaian_Boxers_236-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Top_5_Ghanaian_Boxers-236">
         [236]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Ghana's women's football team won bronze at the
       <a href="/wiki/Africa_Women_Cup_of_Nations" title="Africa Women Cup of Nations">
        Africa Women Cup of Nations
       </a>
       2016 edition in Yaoundé, Cameroon. The team beat South Africa 1–0.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237">
        <a href="#cite_note-237">
         [237]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cultural_heritage_and_architecture">
        Cultural heritage and architecture
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=63" title="Edit section: Cultural heritage and architecture">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Ghana%27s_material_cultural_heritage" title="Ghana's material cultural heritage">
        Ghana's material cultural heritage
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_museums_in_Ghana" title="List of museums in Ghana">
        Ghanaian museums
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ghan%C3%A9s_Arquitectura_Postmoderna_y_Arquitectura_Futurista_(Ghanaian_Postmodern_Architecture_and_Futurist_Architecture).JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="449" data-file-width="992" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Ghan%C3%A9s_Arquitectura_Postmoderna_y_Arquitectura_Futurista_%28Ghanaian_Postmodern_Architecture_and_Futurist_Architecture%29.JPG/220px-Ghan%C3%A9s_Arquitectura_Postmoderna_y_Arquitectura_Futurista_%28Ghanaian_Postmodern_Architecture_and_Futurist_Architecture%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Ghan%C3%A9s_Arquitectura_Postmoderna_y_Arquitectura_Futurista_%28Ghanaian_Postmodern_Architecture_and_Futurist_Architecture%29.JPG/330px-Ghan%C3%A9s_Arquitectura_Postmoderna_y_Arquitectura_Futurista_%28Ghanaian_Postmodern_Architecture_and_Futurist_Architecture%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Ghan%C3%A9s_Arquitectura_Postmoderna_y_Arquitectura_Futurista_%28Ghanaian_Postmodern_Architecture_and_Futurist_Architecture%29.JPG/440px-Ghan%C3%A9s_Arquitectura_Postmoderna_y_Arquitectura_Futurista_%28Ghanaian_Postmodern_Architecture_and_Futurist_Architecture%29.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ghan%C3%A9s_Arquitectura_Postmoderna_y_Arquitectura_Futurista_(Ghanaian_Postmodern_Architecture_and_Futurist_Architecture).JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Ghanaian
         <a href="/wiki/Postmodern_architecture" title="Postmodern architecture">
          postmodern architecture
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       There are two types of Ghanaian traditional construction: the series of adjacent buildings in an enclosure around a common are common and the traditional round huts with grass roof.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ARC_238-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ARC-238">
         [238]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The round huts with grass roof architecture are situated in the northern regions of Ghana (
       <a href="/wiki/Northern_Region_(Ghana)" title="Northern Region (Ghana)">
        Northern
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Upper_East_Region" title="Upper East Region">
        Upper East
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Upper_West_Region" title="Upper West Region">
        Upper West
       </a>
       regions), while the series of adjacent buildings are in the southern regions of Ghana (
       <a href="/wiki/Ashanti_Region" title="Ashanti Region">
        Ashanti
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Brong-Ahafo_Region" title="Brong-Ahafo Region">
        Brong-Ahafo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Region_(Ghana)" title="Central Region (Ghana)">
        Central
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Region_(Ghana)" title="Eastern Region (Ghana)">
        Eastern
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Greater_Accra_Region" title="Greater Accra Region">
        Greater Accra
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Region_(Ghana)" title="Western Region (Ghana)">
        Western
       </a>
       regions).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ARC_238-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-ARC-238">
         [238]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Ghanaian
       <a href="/wiki/Postmodern_architecture" title="Postmodern architecture">
        postmodern architecture
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/High-tech_architecture" title="High-tech architecture">
        high-tech architecture
       </a>
       buildings are predominant in the Ghanaian southern regions, while the Ghanaian
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Heritage_site" title="Heritage site">
        heritage sites
       </a>
       are most evident by the more than thirty
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fort" title="Fort">
        forts
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Castle" title="Castle">
        castles
       </a>
       built in Ghana. Some of these forts are
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fort_William_(fort)" title="Fort William (fort)">
        Fort William
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fort_Amsterdam_(Ghana)" title="Fort Amsterdam (Ghana)">
        Fort Amsterdam
       </a>
       . Ghana has museums that are situated inside castles, and two are situated inside a fort.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Museums_and_Monuments_Board_239-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Museums_and_Monuments_Board-239">
         [239]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_Museum_(Ghana)" title="Armed Forces Museum (Ghana)">
        Military Museum
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Ghana" title="National Museum of Ghana">
        National Museum
       </a>
       organise temporary exhibitions.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Museums_and_Monuments_Board_239-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Museums_and_Monuments_Board-239">
         [239]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Ghana has museums that show a in-depth look at specific
       <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Ghana" title="Regions of Ghana">
        Ghanaian regions
       </a>
       , there are a number of museums that provide insight into the traditions and history of their own geographical area in Ghana.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Museums_and_Monuments_Board_239-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Museums_and_Monuments_Board-239">
         [239]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Cape_Coast_Castle" title="Cape Coast Castle">
        Cape Coast Castle
       </a>
       Museum and St. Georges Castle (
       <a href="/wiki/Elmina_Castle" title="Elmina Castle">
        Elmina Castle
       </a>
       ) Museum offer
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guided_tour" title="Guided tour">
        guided tours
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Kwame_Nkrumah_University_of_Science_and_Technology" title="Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology">
        Museum of Science and Technology
       </a>
       provides its visitors with a look into the domain of Ghanaian
       <a href="/wiki/Science" title="Science">
        scientific
       </a>
       development, through exhibits of objects of scientific and
       <a href="/wiki/Technology" title="Technology">
        technological
       </a>
       interest.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Museums_and_Monuments_Board_239-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Museums_and_Monuments_Board-239">
         [239]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="National_symbols">
        National symbols
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=64" title="Edit section: National symbols">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tawny_Eagle_(Aquila_rapax)_1.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="531" data-file-width="800" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Tawny_Eagle_%28Aquila_rapax%29_1.jpg/220px-Tawny_Eagle_%28Aquila_rapax%29_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Tawny_Eagle_%28Aquila_rapax%29_1.jpg/330px-Tawny_Eagle_%28Aquila_rapax%29_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Tawny_Eagle_%28Aquila_rapax%29_1.jpg/440px-Tawny_Eagle_%28Aquila_rapax%29_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tawny_Eagle_(Aquila_rapax)_1.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <center>
          The
          <a href="/wiki/Tawny_eagle" title="Tawny eagle">
           tawny eagle
          </a>
          appears on the
          <a href="/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Ghana" title="Coat of arms of Ghana">
           coat of arms of Ghana
          </a>
          .
         </center>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Blackstar.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="743" data-file-width="770" height="212" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Blackstar.jpg/220px-Blackstar.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Blackstar.jpg/330px-Blackstar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Blackstar.jpg/440px-Blackstar.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Blackstar.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <center>
          <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Ghana" title="Flag of Ghana">
           Flag of Ghana
          </a>
         </center>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Ghana" title="Coat of arms of Ghana">
        coat of arms
       </a>
       depicts two animals: the
       <a href="/wiki/Tawny_eagle" title="Tawny eagle">
        tawny eagle
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        Aquila rapax
       </i>
       , a very large
       <a href="/wiki/Bird_of_prey" title="Bird of prey">
        bird
       </a>
       that lives in the savannas and deserts
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240">
        <a href="#cite_note-240">
         [240]
        </a>
       </sup>
       ; 35% of Ghana's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Land_mass" title="Land mass">
        landmass
       </a>
       is
       <a href="/wiki/Desert" title="Desert">
        desert
       </a>
       , 35% is forest, 30% is
       <a href="/wiki/Savanna" title="Savanna">
        savanna
       </a>
       ) and the lion (
       <i>
        Panthera leo
       </i>
       , a
       <a href="/wiki/Big_cat" title="Big cat">
        big cat
       </a>
       ); a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ceremonial_sword" title="Ceremonial sword">
        ceremonial sword
       </a>
       , an
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Heraldic" title="Heraldic">
        heraldic
       </a>
       castle on an heraldic sea, a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cocoa_tree" title="Cocoa tree">
        cocoa tree
       </a>
       and a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mine_shaft" title="Mine shaft">
        mine shaft
       </a>
       representing the
       <a href="/wiki/Industrial_mineral" title="Industrial mineral">
        industrial mineral
       </a>
       wealth of Ghana, and a five-pointed black star rimmed with gold representing the mineral gold wealth of Ghana and the lodestar of the
       <a href="/wiki/Ghanaian_people" title="Ghanaian people">
        Ghanaian people
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_National_Emblems_241-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_National_Emblems-241">
         [241]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It also has the legend
       <i>
        Freedom and Justice
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_National_Emblems_241-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_National_Emblems-241">
         [241]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Ghana" title="Flag of Ghana">
        flag of Ghana
       </a>
       consists of three horizontal bands (strips) of red (top), gold (middle) and green (bottom); the three bands are the same height and width; the middle band bears a five-pointed black
       <a href="/wiki/Star" title="Star">
        star
       </a>
       in the centre of the gold band, the colour red band stands for the blood spilled to achieve the nation's independence: gold stands for Ghana's
       <a href="/wiki/Industrial_mineral" title="Industrial mineral">
        industrial mineral
       </a>
       wealth, and the color green symbolises the rich
       <a href="/wiki/Tropical_rainforest" title="Tropical rainforest">
        tropical rainforests
       </a>
       and natural resources of Ghana.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_flag_and_description_40-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_flag_and_description-40">
         [40]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ghana_National_Emblems_241-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ghana_National_Emblems-241">
         [241]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">
        Tourism
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=65" title="Edit section: Tourism">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Ghana" title="Tourism in Ghana">
        Tourism in Ghana
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Surfers_Surfing_at_Busua_Beach_in_Western_region,_Ghana.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Surfers_Surfing_at_Busua_Beach_in_Western_region%2C_Ghana.jpg/220px-Surfers_Surfing_at_Busua_Beach_in_Western_region%2C_Ghana.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Surfers_Surfing_at_Busua_Beach_in_Western_region%2C_Ghana.jpg/330px-Surfers_Surfing_at_Busua_Beach_in_Western_region%2C_Ghana.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Surfers_Surfing_at_Busua_Beach_in_Western_region%2C_Ghana.jpg/440px-Surfers_Surfing_at_Busua_Beach_in_Western_region%2C_Ghana.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Surfers_Surfing_at_Busua_Beach_in_Western_region,_Ghana.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Surfer" title="Surfer">
          Surfers
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Surfing" title="Surfing">
          surfing
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Big_wave_surfing" title="Big wave surfing">
          big wave surfing
         </a>
         at
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Busua_Beach" title="Busua Beach">
          Busua Beach
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Western_Region_(Ghana)" title="Western Region (Ghana)">
          Western region
         </a>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11_of_the_world's_most_unusual_surf_spots_242-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-11_of_the_world's_most_unusual_surf_spots-242">
           [242]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 2011, 1,087,000 tourists visited Ghana.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WAO_243-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-WAO-243">
         [243]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Tourist arrivals to Ghana include South Americans, Asians, Europeans, and North Americans.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Trade_Expo_International_Ghana_244-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Trade_Expo_International_Ghana-244">
         [244]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The attractions and major tourist destinations of Ghana include a warm, tropical climate year-round; diverse
       <a href="/wiki/Wildlife" title="Wildlife">
        wildlife
       </a>
       ; exotic
       <a href="/wiki/Waterfall" title="Waterfall">
        waterfalls
       </a>
       such as Kintampo Waterfalls and the largest waterfall in west Africa,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wli_Waterfalls" title="Wli Waterfalls">
        Wli Waterfalls
       </a>
       ; Ghana's coastal palm-lined sandy beaches; caves; mountains, rivers;
       <a href="/wiki/Meteorite" title="Meteorite">
        meteorite
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Impact_crater" title="Impact crater">
        impact crater
       </a>
       and reservoirs and lakes such as
       <a href="/wiki/Lake_Bosumtwi" title="Lake Bosumtwi">
        Lake Bosumtwi
       </a>
       or Bosumtwi
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Meteorite_crater" title="Meteorite crater">
        meteorite crater
       </a>
       and the largest man-made lake in the world by surface area,
       <a href="/wiki/Lake_Volta" title="Lake Volta">
        Lake Volta
       </a>
       ; dozens of
       <a href="/wiki/Castle" title="Castle">
        castles
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fort" title="Fort">
        forts
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">
        UNESCO
       </a>
       World Heritage Sites;
       <a href="/wiki/Nature_reserve" title="Nature reserve">
        nature reserves
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/National_park" title="National park">
        national parks
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Trade_Expo_International_Ghana_244-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Trade_Expo_International_Ghana-244">
         [244]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/World_Economic_Forum" title="World Economic Forum">
        World Economic Forum
       </a>
       statistics in 2010 showed that out of the world's favourite tourist destinations, Ghana was ranked 108th out of 139 countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RANK_245-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-RANK-245">
         [245]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The country had moved two places up from the 2009 rankings. In 2011,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Forbes" title="Forbes">
         Forbes
        </a>
       </i>
       magazine, published that Ghana was ranked the eleventh most friendly country in the world. The assertion was based on a survey in 2010 of a cross-section of travellers. Of all the African countries that were included in the survey, Ghana ranked highest.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RANK_245-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-RANK-245">
         [245]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Tourism is the fourth highest earner of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foreign_exchange_reserves" title="Foreign exchange reserves">
        foreign exchange
       </a>
       for the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RANK_245-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-RANK-245">
         [245]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2017, Ghana ranks as the
       <a href="/wiki/Global_Peace_Index" title="Global Peace Index">
        43rd–most peaceful country
       </a>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/Earth" title="Earth">
        world
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-About_the_Global_Peace_Index_246-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-About_the_Global_Peace_Index-246">
         [246]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       To enter Ghana, it is necessary to have a visa authorised by the
       <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ghana" title="Government of Ghana">
        Government of Ghana
       </a>
       . Travelers must apply for this visa at a Ghanaian embassy; this process can take approximately two weeks. By law, visitors entering Ghana must be able to produce a yellow fever vaccination certificate.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-travel_247-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-travel-247">
         [247]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb noresize tnone" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right:auto; overflow:hidden; width:auto; max-width:908px;">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="">
        <div class="overflowbugx" style="overflow:auto;">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Panorama_view_of_Kakum_Nationalpark.jpg" title="Panorama view of Kakum National Park, located in the coastal environs of the Central region on the Gulf of Guinea and Atlantic Ocean, covers an area of 375 square kilometres (145 sq mi). Established in 1931 as a Game reserve and Nature reserve, it was gazetted as a national park only in 1992 after an initial survey of avifauna was conducted. The national park is covered with tropical rainforest. Kakum National Park is the only national park in Africa with a canopy walkway, which is 350 metres (1,150 ft) long and connects seven canopy tree tops which provides access to the rainforests.">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="1080" data-file-width="3621" height="268" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Panorama_view_of_Kakum_Nationalpark.jpg/900px-Panorama_view_of_Kakum_Nationalpark.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Panorama_view_of_Kakum_Nationalpark.jpg/1350px-Panorama_view_of_Kakum_Nationalpark.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Panorama_view_of_Kakum_Nationalpark.jpg/1800px-Panorama_view_of_Kakum_Nationalpark.jpg 2x" width="900"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:center">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Panorama_view_of_Kakum_Nationalpark.jpg" title="File:Panorama view of Kakum Nationalpark.jpg">
          </a>
         </div>
         Panorama view of
         <a href="/wiki/Kakum_National_Park" title="Kakum National Park">
          Kakum National Park
         </a>
         , located in the
         <a href="/wiki/Coast" title="Coast">
          coastal
         </a>
         environs of the
         <a href="/wiki/Central_Region_(Ghana)" title="Central Region (Ghana)">
          Central region
         </a>
         on the
         <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Guinea" title="Gulf of Guinea">
          Gulf of Guinea
         </a>
         and Atlantic Ocean, covers an area of 375 square kilometres (145 sq mi). Established in 1931 as a
         <a href="/wiki/Game_reserve" title="Game reserve">
          Game reserve
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Nature_reserve" title="Nature reserve">
          Nature reserve
         </a>
         , it was
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gazetted" title="Gazetted">
          gazetted
         </a>
         as a
         <a href="/wiki/National_park" title="National park">
          national park
         </a>
         only in 1992 after an initial survey of
         <a href="/wiki/Bird" title="Bird">
          avifauna
         </a>
         was conducted. The
         <a href="/wiki/National_park" title="National park">
          national park
         </a>
         is covered with
         <a href="/wiki/Tropical_rainforest" title="Tropical rainforest">
          tropical rainforest
         </a>
         .
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Parks_248-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-Parks-248">
           [248]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Unesco_249-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-Unesco-249">
           [249]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NGO_250-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-NGO-250">
           [250]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <a href="/wiki/Kakum_National_Park" title="Kakum National Park">
          Kakum National Park
         </a>
         is the only
         <a href="/wiki/National_park" title="National park">
          national park
         </a>
         in Africa with a
         <a href="/wiki/Canopy_walkway" title="Canopy walkway">
          canopy walkway
         </a>
         , which is 350 metres (1,150 ft) long and connects seven
         <a href="/wiki/Canopy_(biology)" title="Canopy (biology)">
          canopy
         </a>
         tree
         <a href="/wiki/Crown_(botany)" title="Crown (botany)">
          tops
         </a>
         which provides access to the
         <a href="/wiki/Rainforest" title="Rainforest">
          rainforests
         </a>
         .
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Unesco_249-1">
          <a href="#cite_note-Unesco-249">
           [249]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Life_251-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-Life-251">
           [251]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>

            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Coastal_plain" title="Coastal plain">

            </a>
            with the
            <a href="/wiki/Seat_of_government" title="Seat of government">

            </a>
            and
            <a href="/wiki/Capital_city" title="Capital city">
             capital city
            </a>
            , several
            <a href="/wiki/Castle" title="Castle">

            </a>
            and
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fort" title="Fort">

            </a>

            <a href="/wiki/Rainforest" title="Rainforest">

          <tr>
           <td style="background:#bf88bf;width:5px">

            </a>
           </td>
           <td>
            <a href="/wiki/Tamale,_Ghana" title="Tamale, Ghana">
             Tamale
            </a>
           </td>
           <td>
            massive and world's largest
            <a href="/wiki/Lake_Volta" title="Lake Volta">

            </a>
            , the river system that feeds it and Ghana eastern
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Border_crossing" title="Border crossing">
             border crossing
            </a>
           </td>

           <td style="background:#b2be9b;width:5px">

         </a>

          Seat of Government
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Capital_city" title="Capital city">
          Capital City
         </a>
         .
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/Bolgatanga" title="Bolgatanga">
          Bolgatanga
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;">
         <a href="/wiki/Paga_Crocodile_Pond" title="Paga Crocodile Pond">
          Paga Crocodile Pond
         </a>
         location.
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/Cape_Coast" title="Cape Coast">
          Cape Coast
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;">
         <a href="/wiki/Cape_Coast_Castle" title="Cape Coast Castle">
          Cape Coast castle
         </a>
         is a
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_site" title="UNESCO World Heritage site">
          UNESCO World Heritage site
         </a>
         .
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/Elmina" title="Elmina">
          Elmina
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;">
         Coastal town with a quite harrowing fort
         <a href="/wiki/Elmina_Castle" title="Elmina Castle">
          Elmina Castle
         </a>
         .
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/Koforidua" title="Koforidua">
          Koforidua
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;">
         <a href="/wiki/Aburi_Botanical_Gardens" title="Aburi Botanical Gardens">
          Aburi Botanical Gardens
         </a>
         location.
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/Kumasi" title="Kumasi">
          Kumasi
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;">
         Traditional centre of the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ashanti" title="Kingdom of Ashanti">
          Kingdom of Ashanti
         </a>
         .
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/Obuasi" title="Obuasi">
          Obuasi
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;">
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Earth" title="Earth">
          Earth
         </a>
         's 9th largest
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gold_mine" title="Gold mine">
          gold mine
         </a>
         location; and
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mining_town" title="Mining town">
          Mining town
         </a>
         .
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/Sekondi-Takoradi" title="Sekondi-Takoradi">
          Sekondi-Takoradi
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;">
         Renowned
         <a href="/wiki/Surfing" title="Surfing">
          surfing
         </a>
         beaches such as
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Busua_Beach" title="Busua Beach">
          Busua Beach
         </a>
         ,
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11_of_the_world's_most_unusual_surf_spots_242-1">
          <a href="#cite_note-11_of_the_world's_most_unusual_surf_spots-242">
           [242]
          </a>
         </sup>
         and
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_site" title="UNESCO World Heritage site">
          UNESCO World Heritage sites
         </a>
         .
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/Tamale,_Ghana" title="Tamale, Ghana">
          Tamale
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;">
         Largest settlement in the
         <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Dagbon" title="Kingdom of Dagbon">
          Kingdom of Dagbon
         </a>
         and gateway to
         <a href="/wiki/Mole_National_Park" title="Mole National Park">
          Mole National Park
         </a>
         .
        </td>
       </tr>

            ^

         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140512213620/https://www.iafrica.tv/ghana-welcomed-irans-president-mahmoud-ahmadinejad/" rel="nofollow">

          </a>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">

         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          ^
          <a href="#cite_ref-Ghana_Entering_A_Sweet,_Golden_Era_102-0">
           <sup>

             <b>
              a

           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              b
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>

         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="http://africanbusinessmagazine.com/special-reports/country-reports/ghana-celebrates/is-ghana-entering-a-sweet-golden-era" rel="nofollow">
            "Is Ghana Entering A Sweet, Golden Era?"
           </a>
           .

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=African+Business&amp;rft.atitle=Is+Ghana+Entering+A+Sweet%2C+Golden+Era%3F&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fafricanbusinessmagazine.com%2Fspecial-reports%2Fcountry-reports%2Fghana-celebrates%2Fis-ghana-entering-a-sweet-golden-era&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AGhana">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>

        <li id="cite_note-103">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-103">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation journal">
           Jedwab, Rémi; Moradi, Alexander (2012).
           <a class="external text" href="http://eprints.lse.ac.uk/42263/" rel="nofollow">
            "Revolutionizing Transport: Modern Infrastructure, Agriculture and Development in Ghana"
           </a>
           .
           <a href="/wiki/London_School_of_Economics" title="London School of Economics">
            London School of Economics
           </a>
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">
             15 June
            </span>
            2013
           </span>
           .
           <q>
            Two railway lines were built between 1901 and 1923 to connect the coast to mining areas and the large hinterland city of Kumasi. This unintendedly opened vast expanses of tropical forest to cocoa cultivation, allowing Ghana to become the world's largest producer.
           </q>
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=Revolutionizing+Transport%3A+Modern+Infrastructure%2C+Agriculture+and+Development+in+Ghana&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.aulast=Jedwab&amp;rft.aufirst=R%C3%A9mi&amp;rft.au=Moradi%2C+Alexander&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Feprints.lse.ac.uk%2F42263%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AGhana">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>

         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-111">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20071226200944/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20071222/ap_on_re_af/ghana_oil_discovery_3" rel="nofollow">
            "Ghana leader: Oil reserves at 3B barrels"
           </a>
           . Yahoo News. 22 December 2007. Archived from
           <a class="external text" href="https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20071222/ap_on_re_af/ghana_oil_discovery_3" rel="nofollow">

           </a>
           on 26 December 2007
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">

            </span>

           </span>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Ghana+leader%3A+Oil+reserves+at+3B+barrels&amp;rft.pub=Yahoo+News&amp;rft.date=2007-12-22&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fnews.yahoo.com%2Fs%2Fap%2F20071222%2Fap_on_re_af%2Fghana_oil_discovery_3&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AGhana">

         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-afdb_125-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a class="external text" href="https://africaknowledgelab.worldbank.org/akl/sites/africaknowledgelab.worldbank.org/files/report/Annexes%20for%20Ghana%20Education.pdf" rel="nofollow">
           Annex 1: Political and Administrative System
          </a>
          <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120501234849/https://africaknowledgelab.worldbank.org/akl/sites/africaknowledgelab.worldbank.org/files/report/Annexes%20for%20Ghana%20Education.pdf" rel="nofollow">

          </a>
          1 May 2012 at the

          .. World Bank. Retrieved 29 December 2011.

         <span class="reference-text">

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Library+publications&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cia.gov%2Flibrary%2Fpublications%2Fthe-world-factbook%2Frankorder%2F2155rank.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AGhana">

         </span>

      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">
        Further reading
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghana&amp;action=edit&amp;section=68" title="Edit section: Further reading">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Arhin, Kwame,
        <i>
         The Life and Work of Kwame Nkrumah
        </i>
        (Africa Research &amp; Publications, 1995)
       </li>
       <li>
        Babatope, Ebenezer,
        <i>
         The Ghana Revolution: From Nkrumah to Jerry Rawlings
        </i>
        (Fourth Dimension Publishing, 1982)
       </li>
       <li>
        Birmingham, David,
        <i>
         Kwame Nkrumah: Father Of African Nationalism
        </i>
        (Ohio University Press, 1998)
       </li>
       <li>
        Boafo-Arthur, Kwame,
        <i>
         Ghana: One Decade of the Liberal State
        </i>
        (Zed Books Ltd, 2007)
       </li>
       <li>
        Briggs, Philip,
        <i>
         Ghana (Bradt Travel Guide)
        </i>
        (Bradt Travel Guides, 2010)
       </li>
       <li>
        Clark, Gracia,
        <i>
         African Market Women: Seven Life Stories from Ghana
        </i>
        (Indiana University Press, 2010)
       </li>
       <li>
        Davidson, Basil,
        <i>
         Black Star: A View of the Life and Times of Kwame Nkrumah
        </i>
        (James Currey, 2007)
       </li>
       <li>
        Falola, Toyin and Salm, Stephen J,
        <i>
         Culture and Customs of Ghana
        </i>
        (Greenwood, 2002)
       </li>
       <li>
        Grant, Richard,
        <i>
         Globalizing City: The Urban and Economic Transformation of Accra, Ghana
        </i>
        (Syracuse University Press, 2008)
       </li>
       <li>
        Hadjor, Kofi Buenor,
        <i>
         Nkrumah and Ghana
        </i>
        (Africa Research &amp; Publications, 2003)
       </li>
       <li>
        Hasty, Jennifer,
        <i>
         The Press and Political Culture in Ghana
        </i>
        (Indiana University Press, 2005)
       </li>
       <li>
        James, C.L.R.,
        <i>
         Kwame Nkrumah and the Ghana Revolution
        </i>
        (Allison &amp; Busby, 1977)
       </li>
       <li>
        Kuada, John and Chachah Yao,
        <i>
         Ghana. Understanding the People and their Culture
        </i>
        (Woeli Publishing Services, 1999)
       </li>
       <li>
        Miescher, Stephan F,
        <i>
         Making Men in Ghana
        </i>
        (Indiana University Press, 2005)
       </li>
       <li>
        Milne, June,
        <i>
         Kwame Nkrumah, A Biography
        </i>
        (Panaf Books, 2006)
       </li>
       <li>
        Nkrumah, Kwame,
        <i>
         Ghana : The Autobiography of Kwame Nkrumah
        </i>
        (International Publishers, 1971)
       </li>
       <li>
        Utley, Ian,
        <i>
         Ghana – Culture Smart!: the essential guide to customs &amp; culture
        </i>
        (Kuperard, 2009)
       </li>
       <li>
        Various,
        <i>
         Ghana: An African Portrait Revisited
        </i>
        (Peter E. Randall Publisher, 2007)
       </li>
       <li>
        Younge, Paschal Yao,
        <i>
         Music and Dance Traditions of Ghana: History, Performance and Teaching
        </i>
        (Mcfarland &amp; Co Inc., 2011)
       </li>
       <li>
        <cite class="citation book">
         Laura Burke; Armando García Schmidt (2013).
         <i>
          Ghana: Staying on Track in a Challenging Environment
         </i>
         . Verlag Bertelsmann Stiftung, Gütersloh. pp. 127–147.
         <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
          ISBN
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-3-86793-491-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-3-86793-491-6">
          978-3-86793-491-6
         </a>
         .
        </cite>
        <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Ghana%3A+Staying+on+Track+in+a+Challenging+Environment&amp;rft.pages=127-147&amp;rft.pub=Verlag+Bertelsmann+Stiftung%2C+G%C3%BCtersloh&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft.isbn=978-3-86793-491-6&amp;rft.au=Laura+Burke&amp;rft.au=Armando+Garc%C3%ADa+Schmidt&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AGhana">

          <img alt="" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" height="27" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Wikibooks-logo.svg/27px-Wikibooks-logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Wikibooks-logo.svg/41px-Wikibooks-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Wikibooks-logo.svg/54px-Wikibooks-logo.svg.png 2x" style="vertical-align: middle" width="27"/>
         </span>
         <span style="display: inline-block; margin-left: 4px; width: 182px; vertical-align: middle;">
          <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/y" title="b:y">
           Textbooks
          </a>
          from Wikibooks
         </span>
        </li>
        <li style="min-height: 31px;">
         <span style="display: inline-block; width: 31px; line-height: 31px; vertical-align: middle; text-align: center;">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="193" data-file-width="193" height="27" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Wikivoyage-Logo-v3-icon.svg/27px-Wikivoyage-Logo-v3-icon.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Wikivoyage-Logo-v3-icon.svg/41px-Wikivoyage-Logo-v3-icon.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Wikivoyage-Logo-v3-icon.svg/54px-Wikivoyage-Logo-v3-icon.svg.png 2x" style="vertical-align: middle" width="27"/>
         </span>
         <span style="display: inline-block; margin-left: 4px; width: 182px; vertical-align: middle;">
          <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikivoyage.org/wiki/y#Q117" title="voy:y">
           Travel guide
          </a>
          from Wikivoyage
         </span>
        </li>
        <li style="min-height: 31px;">
         <span style="display: inline-block; width: 31px; line-height: 31px; vertical-align: middle; text-align: center;">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="900" data-file-width="1000" height="24" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Wikiversity-logo-en.svg/27px-Wikiversity-logo-en.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Wikiversity-logo-en.svg/41px-Wikiversity-logo-en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Wikiversity-logo-en.svg/54px-Wikiversity-logo-en.svg.png 2x" style="vertical-align: middle" width="27"/>
         </span>
         <span style="display: inline-block; margin-left: 4px; width: 182px; vertical-align: middle;">
          <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikiversity.org/wiki/y" title="v:y">

       <b>
        Government

       <li>

        official website

       <li>
        The
        <a class="external text" href="http://africanactivist.msu.edu/" rel="nofollow">
         African Activist Archive Project
        </a>
        website has photographs of the All Africa People's Conference held in Accra, Ghana, 5–13 December 1958 including
        <a class="external text" href="http://africanactivist.msu.edu/image.php?objectid=476" rel="nofollow">
         Kwame Nkrumah, Prime Minister of Ghana
        </a>
        , addressing the conference, the
        <a class="external text" href="http://africanactivist.msu.edu/image.php?objectid=85" rel="nofollow">
         American Committee on Africa delegation
        </a>
        meeting with Nkrumah, and of
        <a class="external text" href="http://africanactivist.msu.edu/image.php?objectid=470" rel="nofollow">
         Patrick Duncan and Alfred Hutchinson
        </a>
        of South Africa at the conference.
       </li>

        <a class="external text" href="http://www.ifs.du.edu/ifs/frm_CountryProfile.aspx?Country=GH" rel="nofollow">
         Key Development Forecasts for Ghana

                </a>
                <span class="nowrap">
                </span>
                Geographic locale
               </div>
              </th>
             </tr>
             <tr>
              <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" colspan="2" style="width:100%;padding:0px;font-size:114%;">
               <div style="padding:0px;">
                <b>
                 <a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">
                  Lat.
                  <small>
                   and
                  </small>
                  Long.
                 </a>
                 <span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion">
                  <a class="external text" href="//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Ghana&amp;params=5_33_N_0_12_W_">
                   <span class="geo-default">
                    <span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">
                     <span class="latitude">
                      5°33′N
                     </span>
                     <span class="longitude">
                      0°12′W
                     </span>
                    </span>
                   </span>
                   <span class="geo-multi-punct">
                    ﻿ / ﻿
                   </span>
                   <span class="geo-nondefault">
                    <span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">
                     5.550°N 0.200°W
                    </span>
                    <span style="display:none">
                     ﻿ /
                     <span class="geo">
                      5.550; -0.200
                     </span>
                    </span>
                   </span>
                  </a>
                 </span>
                 <span style="color:darkblue;">
                  (Accra)
                 </span>
                </b>
                <br/>
                <b>
                 <a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">
                  Lat.
                  <small>
                   and
                  </small>
                  Long.
                 </a>
                 <span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion">
                  <a class="external text" href="//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Ghana&amp;params=6_40_N_1_37_W_">
                   <span class="geo-default">
                    <span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">
                     <span class="latitude">
                      6°40′N
                     </span>
                     <span class="longitude">
                      1°37′W
                     </span>
                    </span>
                   </span>
                   <span class="geo-multi-punct">
                    ﻿ / ﻿
                   </span>
                   <span class="geo-nondefault">
                    <span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">
                     6.667°N 1.617°W
                    </span>
                    <span style="display:none">
                     ﻿ /
                     <span class="geo">
                      6.667; -1.617
                     </span>
                    </span>
                   </span>
                  </a>
                 </span>
                 <span style="color:darkblue;">
                  (Kumasi)
                 </span>

        <a class="interlanguage-link-target" href="https://zh.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%8A%A0%E7%BA%B3" hreflang="zh" lang="zh" title="加纳 – Chinese">
         中文
        </a>
       </li>
       <li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-dty">
        <a class="interlanguage-link-target" href="https://dty.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E0%A4%98%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%A8%E0%A4%BE" hreflang="dty" lang="dty" title="घाना – Doteli">
         डोटेली
        </a>
       </li>
       <li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-kbp">
        <a class="interlanguage-link-target" href="https://kbp.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kana" hreflang="kbp" lang="kbp" title="Kana – Kabiye">
         Kabɩyɛ
        </a>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <div class="after-portlet after-portlet-lang">
       <span class="wb-langlinks-edit wb-langlinks-link">
